150168015.review:
Great graphics and good music completely wasted in a short and mediocre game. It wants to be Symphony of the Night, to the point of lifting the main character's walking animation, but falls miserably short.

The biggest problem in this game is the map design, as there is none whatsoever. Rooms are randomly chained together without making any kind of sense, either thematically or in progression/gameplay terms. There is no reason for any room to exist in the way it does other than wasting your time and making travel from boss A to boss B slightly longer. Exploration is unrewarding and boring, as enemies pose no threat and most of the time you can destroy them way before they attack (except in cases where their placement puts them out of range, which is not fun to deal with). You can skip some travel time thanks to teleporter rooms, but they are often poorly placed, far from any checkpoint, boss room or interesting location.

In any case, backtracking is not generally required as the game follows a linear progression with separated 'zones'. You get some rewards in terms of weapons or stats if you backtrack and explore, but those are minor and not needed. All weapons play and feel the same so you should just simply get the one which deals more damage. A few weapons implement some gimmick, but it's always useless. For example, a sword drains enemy MP, but it drains so little you'd need to clear an entire room in order to gain enough MP for a single spell, or some bows fire multiple arrows, but then divide the damage between them, so it's also useless.

You get movement upgrades, which are a highlight of the game because your character handles well once upgraded, but most of the exploration areas are unlocked by colored doors instead.

Combat is simplistic. The game relies heavily in a elemental mechanic where you can change your color and everything has elemental affinity. This mechanic is poorly executed and removes the fun from dodging enemy attacks since it very often becomes a game of matching colors. 

Boss design is bad. The game overuses humanoid enemies all the time. In addition, bosses with multiple phases are poorly designed, more often than not with a second phase that has absolutely nothing to do with the first one. Boss attacks sometimes have missing or broken tells, but fortunately the game is easy and very often you can simply exploit boss weaknesses and magic to chesse them from a distance.

The story makes no sense and has nothing to do with Lodoss, and neither are the locations you visit. The characters have a Lodoss skin but that's all.

At the end of the day, there are a ton of far better metroidvanias to play, many of them with very similar mechanics and handling.

Con:

This is not as the same level as "Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night", which is, of course, had a bigger development budget.

141942445.review:
[i]---see where this game landed on my Metroidvania tier list beneath this review!---[/i]


Warning:  This is one of those games where the camera is a little too zoomed in, leaving you a small playing area.  As a result I am only narrowly recommending this.

A decent enough short Castlevania-style Metroidvania that is overpriced considering the length of the game.  

I chose not to finish the game, but it was fine enough.

The most notable thing is that your character has 2 forms, and you can press a button at any moment to switch between them.  When in one form, you are immune to red attacks, when in the other, blue.

The earliest example of this that I'm aware of is in a bullet hell shoot'em up game called Ikaruga.

This system is both good and bad, but I lean more toward bad.  While for the purposes of avoiding attacks, this mostly works, it can also lead to plenty of frustration as a result of the other things that occur when you switch forms.  Most notably the ability to hover in the air, which only works in one form.  If you avoid a bunch of attacks by changing form then need to jump and hover, it's very easy to lose track of which form you are in and end up taking needless damage.

The exploration has plenty of different ways to go, though the rooms are very small, and as a result often one-dimensional.

The camera is also too zoomed in, the game feels claustrophobic.

All in all, it's a fine metroidvania, though somewhat unremarkable.  It was narrowly playable/enjoyable enough to finish up in my C tier.  It is very overpriced as well.  I wouldn't pay more than $5 USD.  At that price it would be easier to justify the purchase.

141873956.review:
Weak recommendation.

The Short of it: It's a gorgeous and hilariously short metroidvania that might be among the easiest in the genre based on a old anime that was itself based on a D&D campaign.  Movement feels fantastic and there's some love, but most of it comes off feels shallow and forgettable, including the dialogue.  Their other game, Touhou: Luna Nights, is more unique and feels more complete, and I recommend that one over this one unless you're a big Lodoss fan.

The Long of it: I love the license this game is based off of, and the other works of team ladybug, but it's still a little difficult to recommend this one too much.  The fundamentals are there and feel incredible, and Deedlit has a decent repertoire of skills and equipment at her fingertips- hovering, two elemental states, magic, bows, five melee weapon types, a familiar that shoots automatically, an amazing backdash and three or four other simple metrovania pickups over the course of the game.  You get most of your abilities very quickly, which is both a blessing and a curse- you're stacked from the beginning, but it doesn't really feel like you get significantly stronger over the course of the game.

What works: The graphics and movement are stellar, and it's included most of the important players from the setting as well as well-realized the titular character's abilities.  There's a lot of items to choose from and the boss sprites are impressive in motion and have appropriate amounts of lead-up frames.  The later boss battles are all pretty interesting and can prove to be at least some challenge.

What's neutral: The soundtrack is solid, but not very memorable and maybe a bit ambient.  There's not a lot of the stings or tracks from the show (presumably way too expensive on a team like this's budget).  The story is pretty whatever and the characters are thrown in at points, but most everyone relevant (besides the story's actual villain and narrator) show up somewhere; some of the emotional beats land alright, but it fails somewhat as a companion piece and Record of Lodoss War probably could have been replaced with almost anything.

What doesn't work: You get almost all of your abilities off the bat with some jumps and things later.  Most of the hidden abilities don't do a heck of a lot.  Since your capabilities don't really expand, you end up just pressing switches to open things up.  What does increase is your damage- and if you're not entirely asleep at the wheel or doing a level 1 challenge,  you will generally be murdering non-flying enemies before you even know what they do up to the last area.  There's a couple enemies like the Dryad that take so long to even attack that I had to let them try to see how they attacked- and it still wasn't dangerous.  There's a couple tricky rooms, but all and all you will level and steamroll 80% of the game without even trying.

141685522.review:
Overall I found this Metroidvania to be solid. I don't have anything special to say about it, so I'll highlight a few things I liked and didn't like during my playthrough.

Let's start with the positive aspects. One of the enjoyable features is the ability to switch between Fire and Wind affinity to exploit enemy weaknesses. It's even more fun because you become immune to the element you're currently attuned to. The only downside is that the game only offers two elemental forms, so if you come across an enemy weak to the earth element, you better hope you've already found the earth spell, otherwise, you'll have to make do with Water or Fire. On top of that, the pixel art is simply stunning, and the game's environments and characters are visually appealing.

Another cool thing about the game is the unique healing mechanic. It rewards you for avoiding damage for a while, which coincides with the main way to heal. I haven't seen this kind of mechanic in many other games, and I think more games should try something similar. If you hit or kill enemies enough, you gain experience points for the element you didn't use. When that element reaches Level 3 (the maximum), you slowly regenerate HP when using it. But if you get hit, the element you're using loses one Level. Essentially, you're rewarded with some passive healing for playing well.

Now let's talk about the aspects that didn't sit well with me. Some of the challenges and achievements felt poorly designed. For example, the Bow challenge didn't actually reward me for aiming well; it was more about memorizing patterns and finding the best shooting angles, as the targets and obstacles always had the exact same movement patterns. Additionally, the achievement to "Acquire all weapons" required me to own all weapons at the same time, so I had to farm money and buy back some I sold, thinking I just needed a full weapon log. It became more annoying than fun to farm weapons from enemies, and it took a while due to the reliance on lucky drops.

Lastly, I must mention that the game is quite short. My total playtime was around 7 hours, but I estimate that the actual gameplay was closer to 4 hours. The remaining 3 hours were spent farming weapons, doing the archery range, and similar activities. I only played the Boss Rush mode once, achieved an S Rank, and didn't feel the need to revisit it. Considering the price of €16.79, I found the amount of content to be lacking compared to other games like Hollow Knight, which is priced at €15 and offers a much longer and more fulfilling experience.

To sum it up, if you're looking for a decent Metroidvania game that can scratch that itch after playing top-tier titles like Hollow Knight, Blasphemous, or Bloodstained, this game might do the trick. It has its positives, like the elemental mechanics and gorgeous pixel art, but it also has flaws, such as poorly designed challenges and a relatively short gameplay length.

139504847.review:
[b][i]Record of Lodoss War ~Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth~[/i][/b] is a Metroidvania. 

The story follows the titular protagonist Deedlit as she navigates the Labyrinth and has only one ending. The exploration is reasonably interesting and the bosses are diverse and engaging. The graphics and sound are gorgeous. The controls are comfortable and rebindable, but mice are not supported. The game uses checkpoints, overwriting into the same slot. 

The two elemental spirits, Sylph (wind) and Salamander (fire), used for both combat and exploration, and utilised heavily during boss battles. Additionally, there are several elemental spells, melee weapon types, and bows to equip. 

The only negative aspects are that the protagonist is knocked back upon taking damage, including out of an area, the foes revive upon exiting a "room", and the story is hard to understand at the beginning without being familiar with the original work (novels or anime series). 

One bug was encountered during the playthrough - the uncompressed screenshots are saved in the game's save folder (C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Deedlit_in_Wonder_Labyrinth) and removed upon restarting the game.

139013517.review:
A neat little Metroidvania. I'd seen absolutely glowing reviews, putting it up there with Symphony of the Night and, umm, not quite.

It does a lot of good. I suspect the main reason it gets compared to SotN is the animation and controls. Deedlit controls wonderfully, with subtleties to the control like different attack angles during a jump and such, and is very well animated, top notch. It's nice to have different weapon types ALA SotN (daggers, straight swords, large overheard-swinging swords, boomerangs etc), and the skill and Spirit systems add a bit more depth.

It's weaknesses are the same ones shared by 95% of Metroidvanias, and wouldn't really be noticeable if SotN hadn't been looming over the entire genre for the past quarter of a century; the weapons aren't varied enough to be interesting, the map and room layouts are far too samey, it doesn't make good enough use of it's upgrades, and there aren't enough cool little secrets. Let's get design document-y, and go over these one at a time... just keep in mind that this isn't really criticism of Deedlit specifically, but more just the entire genre missing what made SotN magical.

(If you want to avoid spoilers, then stop reading now. Suffice to say, this is a solid Metroidvania with great controls, I'd recommend it, but don't expect something as good as SotN.)

Like I said, Deedlit's has a range of different kinds of weapon, that's all good. This problem is that, within each category, there's a pretty linear progression; later daggers are, for the most part, the same as the older ones, just doing a bit more damage and maybe having a slightly different attack speed. I think there's only one weapon that breaks the pattern, a sword that absorbs HP, but that's it. There are no unique weapons, no special moves, no combinations with other skills/equipment. Deedlit has no equivalent to a Shield Rod, or Sword Of Dawn, or Crissaegram, and that's a shame, because it makes the choice of weapon to use purely utilitarian; you'd never pick a weapon because it does something fun, or has a special move that's circumstantially useful. You just pick the one with the biggest DPS that has enough range for what you're fighting. Things are slightly better with Bows, with a couple having effects like multi-shot, homing arrows, or MP stealing, but that's about it.

If you look at Symphony's map screen alone, it's evocative and clear. You can see long corridors, staircases crawling up, tunnels down into the depths. Areas are clearly delineated by position and style, just from the map layout alone, and it's easy to learn how to get between areas. Deedlit (again, like most Metroidvanias) instead bunches the whole map. The completed map has no space; it is a big jagged rectangle, devoid of character, and finding your way from your one area to another always involves dropping to the map and tracing your zig-zagging, bunched-up route.

This is mirrored with the individual rooms. In Symphony, almost every individual room is identifiable on sight. They all have different visual touches, platform arrangements, and often completely unique backgrounds; to a seasoned SotN player, if you showed them any given screenshot from the game, they could easily place a pin on the map showing exactly where it represents. In Deedlit, it again has an issue common to most Metroidvanias, in that almost every room is either a mostly straight horizontal corridor,  or a vertical room with zig-zag of platforms on the sides and middle to let you up, all done up in whatever the area's standard tileset is.

That isn't a separate issue to the map layout; the two matters are inter-related. In SotN, for example, the Grand Staircase works because it isn't a set of straight horizontal/vertical rooms, but one massive diagonal space. By having it this way, the room itself is distinct, with it's long upwards slope matched with enemies to make it in interesting climb, and that aids the distinctive map layout, with the room visually mirroring a staircase, and connecting lower and upper areas without just having a bunch of vertical chambers with zig-zag jumps... Which also spaces out those related areas to make them more clear and identifiable. Metroidvania devs, I am begging you, find more creative ways to let players go upwards through the map than zig-zagging up vertical rooms. You can do that, just... also do other things, y'know?

I said the game doesn't make the most of it's upgrades, so let me link that in with the map design thing. In Deedlit, one upgrade is water breathing (from a mermaid statue, a direct SotN reference). This is used in about 4 places in the games. They're all the same layout; a horizontal corridor, with the bulk of it being a straight, waterlogged path slightly lower than the doors on each end, with a couple of crocodiles in it as enemies, and usually one of the same sword barriers opened with a bow that you get elsewhere in the middle. And... that's it. The item serves no other purpose other than going through these rooms, and these rooms are essentially identical, and without any creative challenge coming from the water you're in. It may as well have just been a key.

Imagine how much more could've been done. Imagine small waterlogged areas in earlier stages hiding secrets. Imagine a boss battle where you have to enter the water to do damage, but can't stay in the water because it slows you down. Imagine a whole water area, with different thematically appropriate enemies. Deedlit gives you ~4 identikit corridors with 1 (one) water-based enemy that doesn't require any special tactic to defeat, and no special physical obstacles to overcome. There are really only 4 upgrades that have a functional, interesting use outside of a couple of specifics rooms, and 2 of those are the two spirits you get in the first area, essentially being core mechanics of the game. The other two are both varieties of double-jump.

The flame spirit can be used to destroy big boxes. There are about 3 of these boxes, all in the first area of the game. You never use it in a way like this again.

I mentioned little secrets, and... Deedlit does have a little of this. There're the little rooms dotted about with side tasks to perform, those are good. There's an interesting meta secret in one room that I won't discuss here, anyone who's found it will know what I mean. A couple of particular actions can get you lines of unique dialogue. And... I think that's about it? Of course, this is all an outgrowth of the above issues. If your weapons aren't interesting, and your levels aren't interesting, and your upgrades aren't interesting, there's not really a lot of room for clever little things.

This is hard to discuss, because the point is that these things aren't obvious, but their lack is notable. Like... Think about SotN's chapel room, where you get secret little interactions based on sitting in chairs and waiting. Or the bat summon. which behaves differently if you use the bat transformation. Or the sword summon that becomes a usable sword if you level it enough. Or Red Rust, a sword that gets stuck in the scabbard half the time you try to use it. Or the bridge you destroy by luring an enemy to chuck a barrel at it. Or getting secret items from the merchant by high-jumping up into his chair from below. Or the fact that [i]a full half of the game is hidden away behind a fetch quest[/i] in such a way that some players never realised they hadn't completed the game. Deedlit, and all Metroidvanias, need a healthy chunk of these to shine.

This all sounds like I'm ripping Deedlit to shreds. I'm not. It's a good solid game, and it you like Metroidvanias, you should buy it. It's a fine modern example. It's just a shame that the modern Metroidvania so often falls so short of the example they're all drawing from, and despite everything I'd heard, Deedlit doesn't hit anywhere close to that height. I hope it gets a sequel. And I hope that sequel flies a little higher.

This is a good sold game whether your a fan of the anime or not, do know this is a short licensed game, but a good one. It wont knock your socks off, but you will enjoy yourself. 
This is a modern Castlevania knock off, in a good way.

In the 90's I rented a VHS of Record of the Lost War (the long running anime this is based on), I didn't like it, even for a fantasy fan desperate for anything it was way too dry, Although I think I couldn't get the first episodes, I may have tried to watch it in the middle. 
== Pros ==
--- You don't need to know anything about the anime. 
--- Great Art, I love the cute elf girl sprite art. (If you want to play as a Elf girl this a good one)
--- Great game to get your Castlevania Fix.
--- I really liked how they incorporated a bow as a always available action, that's one sold way it's different.
== Cons ==
--- Shops feel a little pointless, they charge quite a lot for weapons I replaced pretty quickly.
--- It's one of those games that feels like if they added a bit more, it would be great.
--- Character feels a little sluggish compared to other Castlevania games, the character looks like she should be faster.
--- Writing is very basic, If your not familiar with the Anime it's best ignored thankfully that's pretty easy to do. The Anime looked to be a very by the numbers LotR's inspired fantasy, maybe just let you imagination wander.
--- Short game, wait for sale

137920991.review:
Score:  93.9% (A)
A lovely game that makes up for its lack of innovation with excellent design and a profound story.
WARNING: You will need to be familiar with Chronicles of the Heroic Knight and/or Record of the Lodoss War to get the most out of this.

    = Weaknesses =
The game doesn't have weaknesses, except perhaps that its presentation can easily mislead one to think it's just a good, if uninspired, excuse to cameo beloved characters from Record of the Lodoss War. This isn't the case, but one can't be blamed for thinking it. Especially since early character interactions just sound like gibberish.

    + Strengths +
It takes everything good from its Symphony of the Night inspiration and condenses it. The mechanics are tight, fun, easy to learn, difficult to master. Difficulty is perfect for those weary of tedious metroidvanias. The art is gorgeous, the enemies varied and interesting, and of course there's bonus for the Lodoss fans out there. Music is nice and atmospheric, level design is clever, sounds are crisp and uniqe and satisfying. Just solid all around!

    * Exceptional Qualities *
Its length is absolutely perfect for what it wants to deliver. Just enough to tell the story it wants to tell and satisfy the variety of skills it wants to introduce without overstaying its welcome.
The story! The ending was handled so beautifully. It's a timelessly important message about living that most people need to take to heart. I was moved to tears, and it'll stick with me for a long time.

136936057.review:
First off I am a huge Lodoss War fan. i am also a huge Super Metriod, and Castlevaina 2d fan. I love the "Metroidvania" games in the Castlevania series, and have a very special love for Simon's Quest.

So I am the total target for this game.

Now I played a lot of this on a different platform before getting it on steam. On the other platform I played up to about the halfway point and then just stopped. I don't have a particular reason why I stopped..i just did, Now the steam version..I will see if I go farther.

But it is a good solid game even if you are not a Lodoss War fan. The story might not really hit you if you are not...but the story really isn't that important. It is a Metriodvania for the most part. It still treats the castle in stages, but backtracking is possible.

The thing I am not too fond of is its big difference it brings...switching elements. The switching parts is ok, but the way you lose elements when you are hit for the one you are using and then having to level it back up with the one you aren't using is...off to me. And then having that drop damage until you level it back up can become a little annoying.

Other than that...no complaints. Its a fun entry into the Metroidvania genre. Thumbs up for me.

136832868.review: Fun game, great flow to combat, and movement. Amazing boss designs and fights, but the power ups make it all a bit too easy and you can breeze through the entire game in under 10 hrs. 136793991.review: Beautiful graphics, very good game engine, and the developers job was truly magnificent. Congratulations, a must have for people who like the serious 2-D Retro games

136750367.review:
If you are old enough to remember the Record of Lodoss war - then you don't even need to think, just get this game and sail through the nostalgia ocean once more. 100% recommended for the title admirers.

As for those, who have no attachments to the franchise and just looking for a good metroidvania... I can still recommend the game, as long as you understand that this is a good, but not the best metroidvania on the market. It's better than average, sure, but it's not on the same level as "Ori" or  the "Hollow knight".

The only aspect that is definitely an S-tier about this game is bosses. Every single boss fight is beautiful, memorable, exciting and... easy enough, which is great for those of us who don't have the teen's reaction speed anymore. On average most bosses will take 1-3 attempts from an ordinary gamer. The last one is a b**ch tho, stock fully on HP and mana potions before engaging him.

Everything else is between an A to C tiers.

Enemy variety - A-tier, many different opponents to play with, you won't get bored with them.

Weapon variety - B-tier, while there are many different weapons, the truly unique ones are sparse, while the rest have the same patterns and move sets.

Labyrinth layout - C-tier. Well, you have seen a similar layout countless times in like 90% of metroidvania games, not much to talk about here. 

Music - between A and B tiers depending on your tastes. Each zone has it's own melody and i'v liked most of them.

Movement - B-tier. Mostly fluid and responsible, but the "dash" works only backwards and is kinda unreliable, while the forward one needs a flame spirit to be present and 2 buttons combo instead of 1 button. I did not understand the dev's reasoning behind that and in the end finished the game practically ignoring it.

Play time - between 6 to 8 hours, depending on how fast you are. For me (personally) this is definitely an S-tier, i prefer shorter games, rather than artificially inflated ones, but for those who measure a game's worth by length that would be C-tier i guess?

So in overall i'd say the game sits somewhere between an A- or B+ tiers, depending on the personal tastes.
With a very reasonable price it's definitely worth a buy in my opinion. And even more so during the sale.

136389156.review:
This game is absolutely incredible. As a Castlevania fan, I legitimately felt like having played an 8th Castlevania game in the “Metroidvania” subgenre. I think it perfectly delivered what makes Castlevania games fun and nailed the style really nicely.

[u]Things that are great[/u]
- Awesome music that establishes its own style. Clean, loveable aesthetics reminiscent of SotN. The main character looks really cool.
- Great character animations, which leads to smooth and fun combat
- The tile-based map screen is clean and well indicative of where you may now go. A welcome improvement over Castlevania
- The whole bow mechanic is incredibly fun and nicely integrated with puzzles and some enemy designs
- Amazingly designed, fast-paced boss battles that challenge player’s strategy and skills (also the dialogue doesn’t play when you re-do a boss battle after failing, which is another nice touch that shows the devs really don’t want anything to bore players)
- A few very cool mini-games to spice things up

Very little can be said about what’s bad about this game. Subjectively, some of the designs have room for improvements, but by no means should they hinder anyone from enjoying the game, especially if you’re like me who’s dying for another Castlevania game after Order of Ecclesia.

Also that cover art looks absolutely sick.

Solid metroidvania with good gameplay.  The spirit switching is a cool mechanic.  Bosses are fun but not especially difficult; none of them took more than a couple of tries, and they all have nearby save points.  I found that despite the numerous weapons in the game, it didn't feel like most of them were worth using (especially not the ones for sale), so farming them felt unnecessary.  The music is mostly pretty good and sufficiently energetic for the genre.

One thing annoying about combat was the knockback and stun, as in a few circumstances you could find yourself chain stunned and getting sucked back into a long attack animation for multiple hits.  Thankfully it didn't happen all that often.

The monsters all have elemental resistance denoted by dice icons, but I honestly almost never felt the need to use magic since the water and fire spirits that buff your weapons were plenty powerful and nothing resists both at once.

Storywise, as someone who knows nothing of the anime beyond the name, this is total gibberish.  I quickly found myself skipping cut scenes to get back to the gameplay.

135065253.review:
The best description I can give to this game would be "Symphony of the Night meets Ikaruga"

The game really wears its SOTN proudly, from the aesthetics, the music, the animations, everything feels like SOTN. But the twist this time is the implementation of Ikaruga's polarity system. With the press of a button you can switch between fire and ice spirits. Each spirit makes you absorb attacks of their element, and deal elemental damage. Some enemies will be weak or immune to an element, some attacks can be completely neutrilized by having the correct spirit, and so on.

Not onlt that, but each spirit can range from levels 1 - 3. Dealing damage and killing enemies raised the level of the opposite spirit you have equipped, while taking damage lowers the level of your current spirit. Being at lv 3 regenerates your health slowly. So your goal is to always have a lv 3 spirit equipped (unless the enemy requires a specific element), a design decision made to further incentivize the constant swapping of spirits.

The story might be more meaningful if you know the source material, but to me it was pretty whatever. The pixel art as great, with a fantastic care for the animation. The gameplay is fast, fluid and responsive. The exploration is a bit more straightforward than most metroidvanias. Not once I felt stuck, just looking at the map was enough to figure where I needed to go, and new bosses kept popping up constantly.

The only major complaint I have with this game is its length. I beat the game with 100% map completion in around 5 hours. This is not an expensive game of course, but it is pretty short even compared to most metroidvanias on the same price range. It is bittersweet because the game is such a joy to play that I really left wanting more. Sequel plz?

134665489.review:
First off, don't be put off by my tiny playtime. I played this on another platform and accidentally repurchased it whilst trying to find a Metroidvania I hadn't played yet (there aren't many left)

As a fan of Metrodvania gameplay, I was thoroughly entertained from start to finish.

The large variety of pixel graphic creatures you get to fight are lovingly drawn, and the animations are smooth, yet every action feels responsive and satisfying. The game strikes the perfect balance between being visually impressive without overdoing it on the animations.

The story in the game is good enough to keep you interested, but it never gets in the way of the fun. The objectives are well-signposted, so even in a large area, you rarely feel lost. The game's map falls a little short of sprawling, but it does give you enough space to explore and feel a sense of adventure.

Overall, Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth is a game that I wholeheartedly recommend to any Metrodvania fans out there. The gameplay is well-balanced, the graphics are excellent, and the story is engaging enough to keep you interested. Don't miss out on this hidden gem!

134448521.review: It's not a particularly big game, but it's clear that a great deal of love and care went into designing both the visuals and mechanics.  I can't overstate just how smooth and responsive the controls feel, and the animations really bring each character and enemy to life.  It's just a pleasure to play and behold, and while the music can be rather grating at times, that is easily forgiven.  It's also not a particularly difficult game.  There are a handful of potentially difficult fights, but you're provided with a lot of different tools (if you can find them) to help take the edge off.  The influx of new weapons and spells is pretty much constant, so combat never gets repetitive.  Fast travel is well-implemented, and there are plenty of shortcuts to unlock, ensuring that backtracking is as painless as possible.  Also, I'm happy to report that there aren't any of those obnoxious platforming challenges you find in so many of these metroidvania style games.  Overall, Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth is an easy recommend.

131832332.review:
[h1]Overview[/h1]
RoLW:DiWL (henceforth “The Game”) is a Metroidvania that is limited in scope but well-polished within that scope. Excellent visuals and a kickin’ soundtrack accompany an accessible, entertaining experience that feels a bit like “[i]Symphony of the Night[/i] Lite” and is worth the $20 asking price.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
This game leans towards the “Vania” side of its genre; some of the developers also worked on [i]Symphony of the Night[/i] and it shows. You’ll utilize melee weapons, a bow, and spells to work through enemies, along with movement tech that expands as you go. The game’s standout mechanic are the two “spirits” you’ll acquire early on—one wind and one fire—that you can swap between on the fly. When a spirit is “equipped”, matching attacks and obstacles will be absorbed as MP, and a good chunk of the game’s challenges come from juggling the spirits. This is most apparent with the game’s bosses, which use attacks of both types (and neither)  that you must quickly swap spirits to counter. Defeating enemies (and just landing attacks on bosses) raises your unequipped spirit’s level to a max of three, and the higher their level, the more damage you do with them equipped, and at max level they’ll also heal you. However, getting hit drops their level, so you’ll need to manage swapping them to keep them as powerful as possible.

In combat, enemies have resistances and weaknesses to various elements (including those of the spirits, which apply their elements to all of your weapon attacks), represented by a six-sided die: 1-3 means weak, 4-5 means resistant, and 6 means immune. Spells and weapons will have the elements not represented by your spirits, like earth or water. Defeating enemies gives you XP to level up, but each level only marginally increases your damage output and defense; HP is raised through a few pickups, and there’s no apparent way to raise MP (for spells/arrows) at all. The majority of significant upgrades come from the weapons, spells, movement abilities, and spirit upgrades scattered about the map.

The game presents a smallish map by Metroidvania standards, though not cramped. There’s a sufficient variety of zones, each with unique enemies and challenges—unlike many MVs, the game doesn’t reuse palette-swapped enemies at all, which keeps each zone feeling fresh. There are a few bow-related puzzles as well that provide the occasional non-combat challenge. Unfortunately, the map is [i]very[/i] light on discoverables, with precious few upgrades and no real secrets to discover; a few are out of the way and not immediately available, but you’ll clearly see them while exploring and can go back for them once you’ve opened the door they’re stuck behind. There’s a [i]lot[/i] of backtracking as well, though mercifully there [i]are[/i] portals that allow you to warp around the map.

For the most part, this game is fairly easy; even the most casual gamer is unlikely to struggle with it much until the last stage, where dominant strategy may trip them up a bit. “Dominant strategy” is where a player will stick to the simplest way to address the game’s challenge, and ignore more complicated mechanics if they aren’t needed. For most of the game, it isn’t necessary to juggle equipment, spells, movement tech, items, etc. because the game doesn’t present challenges that really require it—until the last stage, when doing so is suddenly [i]required,[/i] and may present a wall to players who haven’t gotten adept at utilizing the full breadth of the game’s mechanics. Be aware that you have a lot of abilities to use, and to try all of them if you run into trouble. And [i]remember the shop,[/i] which provides healing items; I totally forgot about the shop at the end of the game because I hadn’t needed it at all up to that point, and acquiring a few restoratives made all the difference.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
The pixel-art visuals clearly show their [i]Symphony[/i] heritage—the character even has Alucard’s “afterimage trail” (although you can disable it in the options if you prefer). They are masterfully crafted, with fluid and varied animations, and though the environments aren’t particularly unique—a planty zone, a castley zone, an underground zone, etc.—they are colorful, diverse, and well-executed.

My only real complaint with the visuals is the HUD, which is quite large; while it looks very nice, it also takes up a [i]lot[/i] of the top of the screen, which can get in the way, especially when climbing upwards. The amount of information it conveys could have been condensed a great deal and spread to the other corners without sacrificing flourish. …Also, I’d have liked to see a more interesting dialogue font, but that’s getting picky.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
This soundtrack [i]slaps,[/i] providing energy to the sometimes slow traversal of the environment, but I kept finding myself thinking “this music is perfect for a Mega Man X game”. It’s excellent, but the rock stylings are, [i]in my opinion,[/i] not a perfect fit. A bit more orchestration might have blended it better with the tone of the game’s environment and story. Aside from that nitpick, however, the soundtrack is solid.

The overall sound design is clear and balanced, and I while I thought the voice calling out “LEVEL THREE” every time you max out one of your spirits would get annoying quickly, it actually proved to be quite helpful when the action got hectic and a subtler sound alert could have been lost in the chaos.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story in this game is quite light, with only a handful of interactions with other characters carrying the entirety of the story. It tips its hand quite early in the game; the ending is fairly easy to suss out well before any reveals happen. The lack of deep story doesn’t detract from the gameplay experience, however, so it’s just a bit of a missed opportunity.

As a part of the [i]Record of Lodoss War[/i] franchise, it draws characters and themes from that lore, but it doesn’t provide any introductions or backstory for the player unfamiliar with the franchise (like myself). As such, if there’s any significance to or subtext in any of the interactions between the characters, it will be lost on many players, rendering them fairly generic fantasy placeholders. This is a shame because [i]Lodoss War[/i] is, if the wiki is any indication, a fairly deep well of lore to pull from, and providing even some of that backstory could have helped set this game apart from others in its genre and introduced and enticed players to the franchise who otherwise wouldn’t have known it existed.

[h1]Additional Thoughts[/h1]
Being so relatively small, this game feels very much like a “first step” game for this dev team that may have been limited in scope by budget and time constraints. The end teases a sequel; I quite hope it gets one that allows the team room to make a larger and more full experience, as it’s clear they know how to make a polished and enjoyable game in this genre.

130493745.review:
I absolutely adored Touhou Luna Nights, so I was all in after discovering another Team Ladybug Metroidvania. Sadly TLN is a better game in just about every way, but RoLW is still worth playing!

Starting with the positives, the pixel art is done to a very good level, & the animations are spectacular. There's nothing truly memorable about the game aesthetically, but the art is clean, & never interferes with the gameplay in a negative manner.

The gameplay is snappy & fluid, with the two element system making for some interesting gameplay moments. There's plenty of weaponry to find, but the majority are simple stat-sticks with nothing really noteworthy about them. Spells are passable, & mostly just seem to exist as hard counters to certain bosses: None of them feel particularly meaningful to push outside of those few scenarios. 

Game difficulty is very low without some sort of self-imposed challenge. I found several bosses to be comfortable one-shots, & while it wasn't comfortable, even the last boss died first attempt without the use of any potions. A no magic replay might be an option, & would undoubtedly offer a very tough challenge for those who fancied it, but if you're the kind of person who just wants to get through the game as fast as possible using the tools at your disposal, you might find yourself done in 4 hours.

Overall, it's not a bad game, it's just nowhere near the quality of Ladybug's previous title TLN, & my overwhelming feeling having finished it is wondering what could've been if the game just had that little bit more going on, both mechanically & length-wise. I'd still recommend playing it if you've finished TLN & find yourself wanting more, but if you're yet to play anything by Ladybug, certainly start there first.

130412118.review:
A short and sweet SOTN clone for fans of Lodoss. The various weapons, bows, excellent spell variety, and an Ikaruga element resistance system make for ultimately deeper gameplay than with Alucard, though the environments here don't come close to the memorability of those in SOTN. The mechanics are fun and satisfying, and the bosses deliver spectacle though only few are challenging. With a runtime of about five to six hours, Deedlit doesn't outstay her welcome.

Although the main cast of RoLW is present here, I wouldn't say they are well represented: the sprites are beautiful, but their interactions are so minimal that the characters are effectively absent. There is unfortunately very little dialogue, and what is there is stilted. This is good fanservice, but it only makes me wish for a robust game with more than a superficial plot, like an RPG, to bring this series back to prominence. These characters deserve a full revival, and so it is impossible not to be a little disappointed when they are underutilised even in their own latest game.

129979772.review:
Wonder Labyrinth is a refreshing, yet familiar moderately casual metroidvania. The sprite combat system is interesting and gives you a bit of challenge during combat, and lets you pause to think for environmental puzzles. WL rewards you for paying attention, as it really pays off especially with boss fights when you keep your eyes open to enemy strengths and weaknesses.

 WL is generally a forgiving game. I love that WL is not a grindfest like Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night, because you can focus on gameplay. Another nifty thing about WL is you can skip the shop and worrying about credits because the weapons you find through exploration are more than adequate. While upgrades are limited and simple, the gameplay mechanics like HP healing when your attach meter is full allows for worry-free exploration in most areas. (There were only a few after mid-game where I started sweating looking for a save point.) 

Even then, most areas on the map are forgiving enough that you can just switch rooms back and forth and farm to build up your attach meter to regenerate HP. Map-wise, I was able to get 99% completion playing on my own without online resources, so this is a pretty accessible title. Boss fights can usually be finished in two or three tries (most require pattern recognition, while some are first time goes that allow you to face tank if you're equipped with the right spells and recovery items). Enemies are generally pretty easy to defeat once you figure them out (and somewhat repetitive), but thankfully you can run through most of them when backtracking which is much appreciated compared to some titles. 

Plot-wise, it's nothing to write home about, but again, the focus is on gameplay. It's a fun, relatively quick jaunt that rewards you for being a player rather than farmer slogging through half an hour to get a spell like in other games. Price-wise, I paid about $16 and it's a bit more compared to similar titles when on sale, but I think it's fair. Especially if it encourages them to make more titles like this.

129828125.review:
10/10
TLDR - Awesome game, had a great time clearing it, no complaints. This is going on my fav game list. Would def recommend. 

Player sprite - Very smooth and silky, very reminiscent of Alucard in Castlevania SotN

Combat - I was unsure at first since I hate it when games make you lose your powered up state when you take a hit, but after I understood you have 2 power states that you ebb/flow between if you take a hit, I was totally into. I LOVE the dual element system in this, I wish more games had this combat mechanic.

Difficulty - Bosses are a good challenge, and the difficulty curve as you progress thru the game is prefect.
As long as you stay calm and remember all the battle mechanics/tools, you'll be fine after a few solid tries. 

Story - Good, I was touched by the ending, cried a little. I never watched the original anime, but that didn't make it any harder to follow. I actually want to try and watch it now after beating this.

Overall - Great experience, no technical issues or bugs. Would definitely recommend if you like metroidvanias, or like the original anime. 

Side note - I'll mention this on the separately since I don't really fault the developers for this. There are many color-coded doors that you unlock on the map as your progress, and I have partial color blindness, so it was difficult at times to tell which doors to revisit, I ended up spending time revisiting them all until I found the right one. It would've been great if the devs could've assigned a unique symbol in addition to the colors for the various doors, probably would've helped me a bit. Again, this is mostly my deficiency, so won't blame the devs. Awesome game otherwise, very satisfied.

129756074.review:
This game is every bit as good as it looks.  Easily the best Metroidvania I've played since Symphony of the Night, and it isn't even close.  Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth hews a little closer to Metroid in terms of game design than SOTN, despite its appearance, in that it relies a little more heavily on backtracking.  But it doesn't overdo it.  It doesn't get tiresome (like, say, Circle of the Moon).  

I'd say the biggest difference is where in Symphony of the Night, new areas feel like areas to conquer, and bosses feel like a part of those areas, in this game there is less of a sense of distinctness to the different areas, and the bosses are kind of their own thing.  While the game is divided into "stages" they don't really feel that distinct, like a thing to be conquered independent of the whole.  That's also how the game reminds me of a Metroid game.  Your immediate goal is always to reveal the blank parts of the map.  The various areas are obstacles to that.  

This game gives most of the standard mobility power ups, but perhaps uniquely grants you the ability to fly almost immediately.  It is less useful than it sounds.

There are no overpowered game-breaking weapons.  As you open up the map, enemies scale to continue to pose a threat.  Every boss will kick your ass if you don't use the right strategy.  Almost everything every boss does can be countered or avoided.  There is nothing cheap in this game.  

It has been a while since I enjoyed a game this much.

129607006.review:
[h1] [b] An Absolute Must-Have, especially for any "Metroidvania" fans. [/b] [/h1]

RoLW Deedlit is an absolutely gorgeous, and VERY well made game that runs insanely smooth. It has tons of stuff, and still maintains a small disk space which is a huge plus.

I remember playing this when it first came out, and seeing all the new heavy updates, additions, etc, the game has really grown to be just outstanding. If any of you have played Castlevania SoTN, you'll definitely see A LOT of big inspirations in such a new, refreshing, charming way.

There's only 2 or 3 "major" cons I'd like to share because I genuinely feel these changes? Would spice the game up 100x over:

[h1] [b] No Other "Playable Characters" [/b] [/h1]
They introduce so many outstanding characters with amazing designs, and movesets, and I feel it'd be amazing to unlock them somehow or have a "Passcode" to enter on a new-game to play as them. This is probably my biggest thing.

[h1] [b] Drop-Rate System is very grindy [/b] [/h1]
I've heard, seen, and experienced personally, of trying to grind for weapons for completion, and just to generally find out what each monster drops, but even after hours of grinding, you may not even find the item. The rates definitely need to be touched up.

[h1] [b] No DLC, and or Expansion areas, items, characters, etc [/b] [/h1]
Even though you can easily spend 8hours+ like I have, and still haven't found everything, having much more to explore and discover would be very fun indeed. 

[h1] [b] Review Results [/b] [/h1]
Despite these few things that semi-impact things heavily? I would easily give RoLW a solid 9/10. For just so many reasons. From character design, to development, lore, level designing, music, special fx, etc, it's just a very beautiful game to relax to, and really dive into a charming environment.

129278960.review: This was a very disappointing game that feels unfinished. During the Steam Christmas sale, this game was $14.99. That's twice the price of Hollow Knight and three times the price of Ori and the Blind Forest. This game is far from the experience of those games as it's beatable in a day. There is no sense of exploration as you progress from stage to stage. Backtracking is a formality as the best items are on the way to the final boss. Color-coded doors separate areas instead of requiring the player to use movement skills or solve puzzles. Simply kill the boss, step on a switch, and walk to the new location. Bosses are easy since there are obvious safe spots you can sit in to hack away. Enemies plod toward you while you mow them down. The experience and leveling system is useless since you do enough damage as you progress through the game and enemies give very little experience making grinding inefficient. The pixel art and soundtrack are nice, but it feels like a Castlevania SotN mod more than an original experience. Even Deedlit’s cape is animated the same way Alucard’s is, except he wore it better 24 years ago. The story is mush and the characters are forgettable. Skip this one as there are better games to play in this genre.

128862105.review:
[h1]Disclaimer[/h1]
I finished the game once before reviewing. I played without grinding or using restorative items (which could make the game easier).

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
It wears Symphony of The Night on it's sleeve, but that's not a bad thing. If you're gonna copy your homework, make sure you copy from the best.

It was a great palette cleanser after I didn't like Blasphemous. I loved it so much that it made me check out the anime. Game is a bit short, but pretty sweet and the only real issue is some jarring difficulty spikes and maybe a bit too much linearity in progression.

Recommended to any Metroidvania fan.

[h1]Description[/h1]
I will refer to this game as "Lodoss War" since full title is too much.

Lodoss War is a metroidvania very similar to the granddaddy of the genre - Castlevania Symphony of The Night, down to the long-ass title.

You play as Deedlit - an elven warrior who finds herself trapped in the titular Labirynth. She doesn't have any memory of how she got there or what's her goal, but she receives weird, sometimes sinister visions that slowly uncover the truth. The game does the bare minimum to provide context for the story, but I'm sure knowing the source material would be at least helpful in easing yourself into this one. I didn't know anything about it before playing and it didn't really bother me. I will say that the game could very much contain spoilers for the original material, since it's set after the events of Record of Lodoss War.

Gameplay-wise this is, again, a copy of Symphony of The Night. You have a jump, a backwards dash and an attack button. Where it differs is how fluid your attacks combo together and that you can attack in more directions (although I may just misrimember that Symphony had no diagonal or upward/downward attacks). You will also unlock 2 spirits - fire and wind - which you can switch between. Spirits provide immunity to their damage type as well as provide other abilities like gliding or dodging, some of which get unlocked later on. You also unlock a bow, which you can use to solve puzzles and of course - shoot enemies. You also have some magic spells, some for damage, some for support.

A lot of the game's bosses and platforming segments rely on quickly switching between your spirits to make use of their abilities and dealing damage whenever you have the chance.

The world is divided into several, non-linear levels that usually contain some key items you need to obtain to move on to the next boss.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[b]+ Responsive[/b]
Controls are snappy. You can switch directions quick, you can control how high your jumps are, switching between spirits and using different abilities works as expected...

Really this is just fun to play because you feel in control of every move, as opposed to something like Blasphemous (a game I played before this), where your character woudln't react in a busy avalanche of button presses. No matter what amount of inputs you throw at Deedlit - she has no problem with responding in the way you tell her to.

Just like a woman should.

Did the joke land? Man, I hope I haven't insulted anyone with this one.

It's not altogether true though, I just said that for the joke. Some inputs, like attacks for some weapons, commit you to pretty long animations (compared to quicker weapons). This may result in having to wait to readjust your orientation or stop you from ducking quickly. You could say that this is acceptable due to slower weapons having usually longer reach and higher damage, so you need to learn to use them more mindfully.

[b]+ Looks great[/b]
Movement animation is smooth just like in Symphon...

If I have to say that name again...

Environments are crisp and nice to look at. Would love native resolution to be a little higher, but that's not a huge problem. Enemies explode in a satisfying manner and visual detail goes well to form a cohesive whole with the game's mechanics. You can clearly tell when you kill something or when it's immune to your damage, etc.

[b]+ Dynamic[/b]
I probably wouldn't mention this if I haven't played Blasphemous before it, but Lodoss War is quick. Most enemies take just a few hits to kill, they explode and you move on. It's satisfying to rush through stages. Enemies also respawn when you re-enter the room, so having a quick fighting system was a must and this game delivers. Especially compared to Blasphemous, which was slow, cumbersome, unresponsive and felt like a horrid grind with enemies having far too much HP and being able to do a lot of damage per hit.

Situation in Lodoss War is further helped by the spirit system, which powers you up to the point where you regenerate HP if you can deal a lot of hits without getting hit yourself. It's integral for making good progress or when fighting tough bosses.

[b]+ Takes me back[/b]
To the time where a lot of stuff were simple. Deedlit is a good-looking female protagonist who achieves being a strong fighter without sacrificing her feminine beauty. The mechanics are similar to... other metroidvania titles without much new, but also without anything feeling implemented badly.

It's very easy to like Lodoss War for what it is, because what it is was already tried and tested before and it's not a bad thing that it follows the footsteps of those games.

Innovation is good, but sometimes it's good to play something familiar and fun.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[b]- A bit short[/b]
It's always nice when the main bad thing I have to say about a game is that I would have liked more of the game to be in the game. Maps ain't big and since it's not super-difficult - you will probably finish it quite quick. 4.5h - that's what I got for my first playthrough.

[b]- Uneven difficulty[/b]
This is a pretty easy game for about 95% of it, most bosses I would defeat on first try. Some I would have to redo 2-3 times, but nothing too tough. But then there are just a few bosses that are HUGE difficulty spikes, with very nasty stunlock attacks, huge damage and attack patterns that are quite difficult to react to.

I feel the game would benefit a lot from an even difficulty curve where you could get eased into the difficult parts gradually instead of having just some bosses be that much of a difference.

[b]- Linear[/b]
The only non-linear part of the game comes in form of special items hidden about or behind abilities like double-jump (which you unlock during main quest). Unlike some Metroidvanias that have whole areas hidden behind optional key items - this one does not seem to have that.

[h1]Lowdown[/h1]
It's not cheap for the amount of playtime, so you may want to wait for a discount. But game itself is quality and if you like metroidvanias - you will enjoy it.

I'd give Lodoss War an
[h1]8/10[/h1]
It's been a nice palette cleanser after slogging through Blasphemous, which was overdesigned, slow, cumbersome, inconsistent and frankly not fun, despite looking great. Lodoss War is a great example that it's more important to focus on making the game play well than making it look nice.

128332300.review:
No hay mucho que decir de esta belleza, Metroidvania inspirado en CV-SOTN cuya trama y lore están basados en las Crónicas de las Guerras de Lodoss y plasmado en el motor del Touhou Luna Nights, hermoso pixel art, animaciones y transiciones pulidos (buenas coreografías en pixel art) mecánica arcade adictiva, si bien es un RPG side-scroll difiere en profundidad al mencionado CV-SOTN (ver Strider Hiryu e Ikaruga) y una variedad de armas, enemigos y bosses de las OVAS.

127519877.review:
Great metroidvania.  Short, but that's kind of to be expected with it's lower price tag.

I'm totally green when it comes to the Lodoss franchise, so the characters were unfamiliar to me. Yet, despite typically skipping cutscenes I actually found myself somewhat invested nearing the end of the game, wishing that I had taken it a bit slower.

My only real gripe is the arrow puzzles, which were often dead simple and could either be removed all together or made significantly harder.  The only time these puzzles (if you can even call them that) ever posed any sort of challenge was when you end up just searching the magic angle to shoot at by spamming arrows, gradually lowering your aim until you find it.  Another, smaller gripe is that the coolest/most interesting weapons are obsoleted very quickly after obtaining them, or in my case, I found many of them while cleaning up the map before the final boss, already completely obsolete by the most easily attainable mid/endgame weapons.  My other, very minor issue is that it is occasionally hard to tell what constitutes as background and what constitutes as foreground: background assets are occasionally just foreground assets that have been very slightly darkened making it hard to tell if you can walk in front of an object, or if it's a wall of some sort.

/Nitpicking aside, the combat is fun and the Ikaruga style switching mechanic is very satisfying to get a hold on.  Movement is very tight and responsive, and barring one specific enemy it was rare to get hit and feel cheesed by janky hitboxes.  Music/sound design was generally pretty good and captured what I think they devs were going for well.  The biggest strength of the game is probably the art design: the sprites, background, weapons, and animations are all amazing looking.

It's a decent metroidvania.  If you are a fan of Symphony of the Night, then this is probably going to be to your tastes, as they stick VERY close to that game's design, and seemingly used the SoTN animations as references.

  However, they spice things up by adding Ikaruga's colour matching system to the mix to charge your mana bar, and negate damage from certain enemies.

  It's about a 4 - 6 hour playthough (depending on familiarity with similar mechanics), but the map layout is fairly intuitive, and the game is brisk, but very enjoyable.  The pacing is VERY good, and you will spend very little time backtracking, and all of the bosses are both decently engaging, and spaced out so that you should be seeing a cool boss fight every 45 min or so.

  It's not a masterpiece, but it shows love for the original source material, and it respects the audience's time.    You might not get as much as you could out of the game if you are not familiar with the franchise, but going in blind won't hurt the experience.

  8/10 solid game.  The elemental system could have stood to be fleshed out a little, but what's there is not bad at all.

You should also be aware that this game has a unique dodge and heal mechanic which you may not find fun. 124212679.review:
As others have said, overall a very solid Metroidvania based on the section I've played (up to Shooting Star).  A few minor- to medium-tier complaints worth noting, though:

First, the game does have some persistent flashing effects (e.g. magic power gauge when full) that I didn't see any option to turn off.  It was limited enough that I didn't really notice, myself, but a friend of mine sensitive to strobing/flickering had to stop watching on account of it.  A video options control to turn it off or at least moderate it substantially would have been helpful for players (and viewers) with optical sensitivities, and it's not as though flashing lights in video games being a problem was unheard of in 2021.  Frankly it's a little weird for any modern game to neglect flashing issues.

Second, while the air/fire elemental mode thing is a cool mechanic, it can be pretty annoying to get the hang of, and the fragility of the fully powered state, together with the time needed to recover it and the amount of damage Deedlit takes from most enemies means that stopping to grind magic levels is a thing.  If the power gauge didn't get knocked down so much faster than it builds up, or HP weren't quite so precious, the impact on the pacing of the game wouldn't be so significant.  The mode swapping during boss fights is fun and makes it feel really dynamic, which is great, but then you get hit twice and pretty much have to stop the boss fight to rebuild your gauge and heal and hope you don't get hit again while doing that.

Third, a few of the controls are either a little odd or absent.  A few that especially stood out to me were: (1) the controller mapping seems confused about the face button numbering, (2) the control guides in-game only specify default keyboard key bindings but not the controller bindings, (3) the timing on the downstab feels very strange and it's been a bit of a struggle to get a feel for it, and (4) there's no control to look up/down which is especially annoying during some blind drops and when dealing with enemies in tall chambers.  The last especially seems like it would have been a great use for the analog sticks standard on modern controllers.

Again, overall a great game, especially for those of us with late-90s platformer (and anime) nostalgia, and the flaws are limited in scope... but they also all seem like they should have been easy to fix in beta, especially the flashing issues, which makes them that much more grating.  Based on the section I played through so far, it seems like roughly an 8 that could have--and [i]should[/i] have--been a 10.

121174236.review:
A slightly above average experience. The game itself feels like a tiny, but polished castlevania game. It sets itself apart with a few features, but every other feature feels like it's a dumbed down castlevania feature.

[h1](unique feature) Elemental spirits and Elemental damage/weakness[/h1]
If there's one thing I think this game will be remembered for it's the way it handles elemental damage. In most castlevania games (and RPGs) elemental weaknesses are only useful against a handful of enemies and having elemental immunity was rarely very useful. I rarely picked an elemental weapon/armor over more general use ones, because it's just a nuisance.

At a glace this game uses the usual formula: Enemies take less damage if they are resistent to element or more if they are weak to it, The main difference is it makes different elements accessible using spirits and spells on the fly, which means exploiting elements is no longer a hassle, even if you only need to beat 1 specific enemy. Another big difference is elemental damage/defense is used as a central combat mechanic.

[b]Elemental spirits[/b]
You get 2 togglable elemental spirits, which you can freely swap between. They give you special effects (boring ones), matching elemental damage and complete immunity against damage of that element. These spirits also have something like a level that affects the damage you do while they are active. They can also heal at max level. You deal damage to charge the level and if you get hit you lose a level. You do not lose a level if you get hit by element you're immune to!

[b]Effect in gameplay[/b]
Despite there being more elements, many enemies have some sort of affinity towards the 2 elements you have full control over, so swapping between those can affect your damage a lot. 
Spells are only slightly strogner than normal attacks, but if you pick the corrent element, they can often nuke even strongest enemies (including some bosses) in seconds.
Spells can also grant elemental affinities, which means access to more elemental immunities.

Because getting hit means losing spirit levels (damage buff), and getting hit by element you are immune to does not reduce that level, avoiding damage or using elements to gain immunity well is rewarded with higher damage output.

Bosses (as well as few normal monsters) often spam attacks that are difficult to avoid, but easy to defend against by swapping elements. It's a very clever way to make elemental damage a part of gameplay. 

[h1]Combat(7/10)[/h1]
Combat is polished. Movement controls are tight, attacks always feel right (in terms of range and speed) and spells feel valuable (powerful and MP recovers slowly).
Monsters feel well balanced (nothing too strong or too weak) even if there are a few monsters with surprize attacks.

It resembles Syphony of the Night, however smaller weapon selections (and less weapon behaviors), does mean combat gamepaly variety suffers. 

[h1]Progression(6/10)[/h1]
Straightforward, linear and generally unremarkable.

You have 2 weapons (melee and bow) both of which have attack speed and attack damage.  Few weapons have special effects, but nothing too exciting.
As you go through the game, you constantly get better weapons and I never really had to wonder if it's worth keeping previous weapon over the one with better stat.

The other form of progression is spirit upgrades (they sometimes attack and their attacks gets stronger - boring), spells (very useful) and HP/MP upgrades (too little to matter).

[h1] Exploration(8/10) [/h1]
Nothing groundbreaking, but for how short the game is, it manages to keep things interesting. There are just enough metroivania puzzles to keep track of without map markers and taking notes. You're rewarded with weapons, spirit upgrades, spells and HP/MP upgrades as you explore. If it was a 20+ hour game, I would say boring progression ruins exploration rewards, but in ~8 it doesn't reach the point where it feels like busywork.

[h1]Presentation (8/10)[/h1]
To say this game draws stylistic inspiration from Castlevania games would be an understatement. Music, structure, animations and even most gameplay screams Castlevania. Whether it's a good thing or not is up to you, but it certainly invites comparison.

I would say it delivers everywhere apart from 2 areas
[list]
[*] Some enemies look stylistically out of place and some have awkward animations, but that's like 5 enemies total.
[*] Projectile sprites. Look at bullet hell "bullet" sprites (blue and orange) and tell me they fit in this gloomy visual style.
[/list]


[h1]Comparison to Castlevania: SotN[/h1]
It might not look it, but it feels increadibly similar to Castlevania: SotN. Movement, combat, weapons, music and many other things.  Here's the list of differences in Record of Lodoss War:
[list]
[*] Smaller.
[*] Dumbed down stats/items/equipment: less weapon types (and behaviors); no unique weapons; no armors or accessories; less stats (presumably because they would be pointless without equipment); barebone selection of consumables.
[*] Bow added as an alternate weapon. You can freely aim in ~90° arc. I can't say it's makes a huge difference, but I did use it to kill a few out of reach enemies.
[*] Elemental damage stuff I mentioned Above.
[*] Spells are on a button, rather than command based.
[*] Visuals. Art has similartities in how gloomy it is, and atmosphere is similar, but the style is more aimed at fantasy setting.
[/list]



Elemental stuff I mentioned creates fairly unique gameplay, so I do recommend it, but don't expect anything groundbreaking.

120665200.review:
This game takes basics of Castlevania games and copies them - the locations look similar, the walk cycle is similar, the attack animations are the same, but then it builds some additional systems around the core, which make the game unique.

Most of things in this game resolve around red/blue mechanic, where you are immune to the colour you currently have, while taking damage from the other one. This was previously seen in Ikaruga and Outland. It allows the bosses to throw full screen of attacks at Deedlit, while making it relatively easy to dodge once you master the system. I always liked it in Ikaruga, and here I really got the "Ikaruga 2D" vibes.

While red and blue represent wind and fire, there are other elements in the game, and those act outside of "Ikaruga" system, so you need to dodge them properly. For map traversal I found out that instead of finding out "proper" way to deal with most monsters I could just outright kill them before they managed to make their attacks by mixing my weapon attacks with first magic attack you learn in the game. Within 30 minutes you start to feel like overpowered build in some Castlevania games, but here it is just natural state for the game. Even most of the bosses are pushovers, and you can abuse the element system to take them out easily on first attempt. There are some exceptions, but even those are on easy side.

The most abusable element of the game is autohealing. If you use one element the opposite element levels up when you damage enemies. If the element you're using is at level 3(max) you're recovering health rather quickly. If you get hit your current element drops by 1 level. By switching between elements and keeping at least one at level 3 at all times you are very hard to kill. Against bosses you can easily turtle them out, and just attack from the distance until you've recharged the opposite element. Not useful for speedruns, but for regular players easy to use.

You also get a bow, which is useful for most of the puzzles in this game, and some monsters are much easier taken out with it. It's useful against some bosses too, but overall I didn't use it that much. The puzzles were decent, mixing a little bit of thinking with a little bit of dexterity. You also get access to few spells, and few mobility options, like hovering, double jumps, higher double jumps etc. Controlling Deedlit with the upgrades is fun, although I found the "higher double jump" input to be a bit irritating to do. There are many jumps where you have to use 95% of your double jump/higher double jump range to pass.

What I didn't care about too much was the map design. Unlike some other vanias where you get interconnected castle, and the areas flow into each other rather naturally, this game divides the map into stages. Each stage is pretty much micro-map, which is "solved" separately from all other stages. There are few rooms where you can't enter until you got an upgrade from the next stage, so you need to backtrack, but otherwise the map is... rather uninteresting exploration wise.

All you can find on the maps are weapons, 7 spells(1 is mandatory) and few HP/MP/power upgrades. The weapons also drop from monsters randomly. You can have up to 1 copy of each weapon. There are no usable items that you collect, the only source of such items are the shops you find in the dungeons. I've never used or bough any of those. Somehow the rewards from exploration are quite unrewarding, for the most of the game I had better weapons than I was finding.

The equipment system is very limited - you only select your two weapons, and they don't affect your stats or each other. So you just can select best weapons for the job and kill stuff. Usually you can settle for the higher raw damage, but against monsters with high weakness you can opt to choose elemental weapons. Or weapons with an animation that makes monsters easy to hit, or with some added special effect (like homing arrows). You won't be spending much time in the equipment screen.

As you can see on the screenshots and trailers the game is a sight to behold. Some areas make great use of parallax scrolling, and there are a lot of details in the environments. The music is serviceable. The story is serviceable and predictable. But still cool. There are no hidden endings, or time-consuming mechanics, unless you decide to collect all weapons or something.

In the end I've enjoyed my 5 hours with this game, completed it, but I don't think I'll be replaying it, unlike Castlevanias. I highly recommend this, but think of it as "Vania lite" or platform game with some Vania elements. 

SteamDeck note: I've completed the game fully on the Deck. If not the launcher where you might want to press F1 to toggle vsync this game probably would get "Great on Deck" instead of "Playable" label it currently has. It works perfect trough the game, shows proper controller symbols, and everything works fine. When I started I couldn't control music with the deck buttons, but subsequent update to the Deck seems to have fixed it.

120659059.review:
I grew up loving Lodoss War, and it has always been a shame that we never got a game, based on the anime, that was based on a game they played...

This game feels exactly like how you'd want a 2D pixel art game would.  It moves well, the challenge stays strong even when you've leveled up and gotten good.  Can you take ten of the enemies who used to kill you out in a row?  Flowing from one to the next?  Eventually, yes, you'll get there.  Will a mistake also have a single enemy wreck you?  Yep, the threat is real.  Unlike games that throw cheap shot deaths at you instead of balancing a difficulty curve, this one just hits the mark.

Gameplay: tight and responsive, you'll rarely find yourself calling BS on a creature killing you, or messing up a puzzle because controls didn't work.  In fact, you might get used to pulling off tricks.
Graphics: How is this actually pixel art?  It looks much better than it should.  Multilayered backdrops that shift and move, the details they managed to get out of it is impressive.  Deedlit moves better than AAA game characters.  
Story: Ok, one minor issue here: it's not the Anime.  Lodoss war was a big thing for me as a kid, and this is sort of a "look at these characters we made" game.  It feels like a mod to SoTN, and I mean that in the most complimentary way possible.  
Fun things: I managed to figure out how to get around a puzzle by "BotW'ing" the challenge, and I felt good about that.  

Highly recommend this game.

Some things I want:  
Extra bit where you play through as Pirotess?  Could be a lot of fun.

Seriously, find a way to make a version of this that's just the whole first run of the anime... I'd play that.

120305824.review:
I paid $16 and beat the game in 3.6 hours.  I think it's a solid enough game, but there's definitely some drawbacks.

In summary, it's similar enough to SOTN or Bloodstained.  There's distinct areas, you gain weapons as you progress along with a couple of spells, and it's the usual platforming with attacking to kill stuff.

Positives:
Innovation in some gameplay, especially with the red/blue energy system.  I liked switching between them and it generally added a lot of depth.
Art style was great.
Music was phenomenal.
No bugs (though one crash to desktop).
The map will mark locked doors you can't progress past yet with the appropriate color automatically.  Personally, I'd rather have pins ala Hollowknight, to place myself, because it feels more like exploring, but it's definitely better than having a plain map with nothing at all marked.

Downsides
It's short.  Like, really short.  I wouldn't necessarily mind that it's a condensed SOTN clone, but there were more than a few times where I picked up a weapon that was then immediately superseded by another weapon I'd pick up.
Item drops from enemies didn't really seem to be a thing past the first few enemies.
Combat is very bog standard, and there's not really spots where there's choices in what weapon you use.  Simply pick the one with the highest numbers.  Same for spells.
Normal enemy combat is super boring, excluding the final area.  I don't even know what the dark elves attack is, because none of them ever lived long enough to attack.  Excluding the final area every single enemy dies incredibly quickly (except maybe the crocodiles who are evil).  Bosses were the right kind of challenging (or maybe even slightly too easy), and all normal enemies and areas were incredibly easy.  I just breezed through the whole game.  Walk into room, spam attack, everything dies super quickly.
The shop is pointless, both because the game is so easy and also that I found more than enough swords and bows that I never needed to buy any.
Secrets are barely a thing.
Exploration is barely a thing.
No interaction with torches like in Castlevania, so less need to pay attention to the background (personally I enjoy the constant need to interact with the environment).

So, in the end, I feel ok with this game.  Overpriced for what's there, but at least what's there is solid enough.  There's some innovation beyond SOTN, but there's also some things removed, so I suppose I'm still waiting for a castlevania-type exploration game that takes things to the next level.

All that said, I think developers that make bug-free, complete games should absolutely be supported, and these developers fit that, so they deserve support.  I'm hoping they can improve things for their next iteration.
