119970471.review:
Melee can aim every direction but if you walk back while spamming melee you turn around, but you don't with the bow. Wanna stand still and aim melee? Too bad, your lock in place button is overlapped with your backdash. Game lets you float and use position lock to aim bow or melee in air, except if you were moving down then it just doesn't work? But it will while moving up? Want to buffer a slide after your attack? Too bad, your attack animation can't be slide cancelled so your jumping right into what you wanted to slide under. Want to use the elevator platform by shooting a gear wheel? Too bad, you didn't hit it at the perfect angle while your on a moving platform or you just shot it too fast so now it's lowered and you have to try again and again till it decides you were lucky enough. Hope you didn't run out of mana either or your stuck here for 30 seconds. Did i mention it resets your aim back to default position after each volley?  Enemies have almost no windup and you either kill them before they try or you have pretty much no time to react. No reason to re use old weapons. all the weapons fall into 1 of about 5 animations that are used interchangeably same with bows the only differences you get are damage output, sometimes a passive that's barely even noticeable, or more arrows on the bow attacks. Magic is just 1 button easy mode and the first frickin spell they give you is just Tetra Spirit but shiny and takes up more screenspace than needed making it even harder to see what's going on in a cramped space (which is every...single....room outside of a boss) Majority of backtracking to find stuff that is optional isn't worth collecting or is just an extra 10 manna or health here or there. Map is blocked off into sections unlocked by colored switches and corresponding colored doors meaning there's pretty much no original routing options. No sorting your inventory.  Music often feels subpar. Game starts at 25% volume otherwise it will blow out your speakers. They trust you to press and hold a button while pressing another on the right side of your controller but then don't give you anything challenging to do with it. There's straightup unused triggers yet controls are frustratingly stacked ontop one another in a way that causes you to avoid using them The gambling mini game is fun, the archery range is fun, the art is beautiful, there's so much good here but It's a pale imitation of good ideas packaged in a subpar expirience. Enemy designs even blend in the backround at times, or just make you stand infront of them till they stop guarding. is it a pattern? No, they just start guarding as soon as you get close and then you have to wait. Want to use the I frames on your slide? Too bad, it makes you stop at their feet. Sometimes you can get another one out in time, other times it just slaps you for trying. Especially on slopes since your slide can't handle them and forces you into an airborne state removing your I frames. No zoom on mini map, every room look the same on the map. Are you colorblind? Good luck trying to figure out where you need to go since the colored doors are basically your only guide and there's no other routes. Story is non existent. Betrays ALOT of the source material in general when presenting it. The amount of tech in the game to learn is slim and the majority of it is functionally useless outside of speedrunning. Even then it is laughably hindered by it's own design decisions. Like a built in stunlock that will kill you at full HP from getting tapped once.

TLDR:
This is not even close to SOTN. It's the pretty looking vapid and vain one you should have let get away instead of wasting your time and dedication on.

119646480.review:
Japanese studio Team Ladybug delivers a masterpiece. Record of Lodoss War-Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth- is a cleverly designed Metroidvania.

Visually, the game delivers stunning pixel art and excellent animations. In fact, Deedlit movements are delightful, it feels wonderful to see her in action. The amount of different enemies is also welcome, for a short game it delivers a bestiary that puts other games to shame.

The soundtrack is also another point worth mentioning, the action is usually mixed with rocking tunes and the occasional atmospheric tune. It blends with the game perfectly, pushing you forward each room.

Last but not least, the game offers a fair challenge but it is not a walk in the park either. Actually, I felt it did not overstay its welcome which is something that can really leave a sour taste in your mouth.

All things considered, this is another gem from TL that has quickly became one of my favourite Metroidvanias ever.

119145237.review:
Overall: B+
Normally in reviews I like to start with a bit of a preamble but since this game is so obscure and my review might affect someone buying decision: this game is really good. It is a fantastically constructed Metroidvania (though leaning far more on the Castlevania side) whose short length and relatively easy difficulty makes it a great choice for those wanting to get into the genre. With fantastic visuals and surprisingly catchy music, there is little not to recommend about the game—other than the absolutely horrendous name which I have to look up every time I want to mention it to someone. 
	
With that out of the way, let’s talk about the game in more detail. Firstly, this game takes HEAVY inspiration from Symphony of the Night (and all of its bastard children) in terms of aesthetic direction and general game feel. Despite this, Record of Lodoss War has enough fresh ideas to keep things interesting. Most notably, it features two swappable spirits, one red the other blue, to change some basic properties about the main character and absorb incoming attacks of the same type. The red spirit controls fire and the blue, wind. Some enemies are weak to one or might resist the other so switching becomes important. Or it would but despite every enemy in the game having some amount of elemental weakness, having attacks of any other type than ‘fire’ and ‘wind’ is uncommon. The only good way to get attacks of all the element types is to hunt down the optional magic spells. For the record: magic is absurdly overpowered—especially against bosses. Having the right spell can almost invalidate the bosses in the game and break any remaining difficulty. The element system overall is woefully underutilized since changing your attack’s element isn’t easy for large sections of the game. It also uses the faces of a die to represent weakness and resistance for no good reason. Maybe dice play a big part in the franchise but I can’t be bothered to go down a Wikipedia rabbit hole right now.
	
This is not a challenging game. If you play games mainly to overcome trials, this simply isn’t the game for you. The joy of this game comes from how enjoyable moving about the world is and the very tangible sense of progression. New, more powerful weapons get handed down frequently and the primal joy of seeing ‘number go up’ feels great when exploring the world. The locals are different enough to give a sense of progression but they fall back on typical location tropes. 
	
Overall, the game grabbed me and hooked me in until the end. It is a thoroughly enjoyable game with wonderful visuals. If you like Metroidvanias, you should absolutely give it a shot. While, I don’t think this game will be on my mind in a month, the short time it had my attention, it did so fully.

118991190.review:
This is a short, but incredibly polished little Metroidvania.  The graphics are absolutely beautiful, the controls feel perfect, and it's constantly throwing new abilities and enemies at you.  If anything, I feel like the pace of the game is maybe a little too fast; near the beginning of the game, you acquire upgrades in such quick succession that it feels like you've barely had any time to use the previous one.  It smooths out a bit as you progress, but this definitely isn't like some Metroidvanias where you have to spend hours exploring before you find anything interesting.

The most interesting twist on the gameplay is the wind and fire spirits that Deedlit can equip and switch between at will.  Switching to a spirit causes all of your attacks to take on that element and also lets you absorb attacks of that element, and each one also gives you a movement upgrade (wind lets you hover, fire makes you invincible when sliding).  There are a few segments of the game where it gives it an Ikaruga-like feel where you have to rapidly switch between elements to protect yourself from enemy attacks, and there are a few puzzles where you have to switch between them or use their movement abilities to navigate through rooms, although it does feel like more could've been done with them.

My biggest complaint is that the story just isn't very interesting.  If you're not familiar with the Lodoss franchise, you will be completely lost; it does absolutely nothing to introduce any of the characters or references it makes.  If you are familiar with Lodoss, though, there's still not really anything compelling here; plenty of old characters will show up, only to say a few cryptic lines, maybe fight you, and then disappear.  It's pure fanservice with no substance.

Of course, nobody's playing Metroidvanias for the plot, anyway, and this game delivers a great 5 hours of gameplay while it lasts.  It's a good bite-sized appetizer between playing longer games.

118780852.review:
Let's compare two games clearly inspired by Castlevania, Symphony of the night:

a) Bloodstained ROTN ("ROTN" for short).
b) Deedlit in WL ("WL" for short).

Symphony of the night is for sure in my top 15 games of all time, without a single DOUBT.

Now ROTN, in my honest opinion, was the wrong route to take after SOTN. Instead of perfecting the gameplay, refining the flaws, improving on the presentation; they instead highlighted the negatives. The presentation has no style, which will absolutely age horribly in a couple of years (it already looks worse than SOTN). It is featurecrept up the butt, with crafting/grinding/LOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOONG rooms with slow gameplay, and a story that is so laughably predictable and boring that its biggest sin is the game's emphasis on it.

Now, I enjoyed ROTN, I am mainly highlighting the stuff I didnt like in that game because I felt like it was such unnecessary stuff to add in a game like SOTN. 20 or so years to theorycraft a great sequel, and instead the game feels like a step back.

Now WL.... where do I begin. Let's tackle its weakness first: WL is short.... really really short. Compared to SOTN, and ESPECIALLY ROTN, you are going to breeze through this game..... but that is a potential weakness for you, not for me fam.

The pacing of this game is so TIGHT that you will enjoy every single second of it. Comparing it to ROTN, this game is a 4th of its length, if even that, but in ROTN you will be counting the hours you have until finally getting it overwith. While ROTN overstays its welcome by a long mile, this game shows that shorter experiences can have a far better impact on the player.

Now that we got the "weakness" out of the way, let me speedrun of the positives for you:

1) The music is fantastic.
2) The visuals are STUNNING and stylized, compared to ROTN, this game will NOT age a day decades from now.
3) The story is intriguing yet not intrusive.  The presentation is laid out quite quickly and it does not kill the pace of the game in the slightest.
4) The map is VERY straightforward, and a lot of the mental map is diminished as the ingame map highlights doors that are locked for you.
5) The gameplay is very similar to SOTN and ROTN. But.... they added 8 directional attacks.... god bless

Just pick this game up....

118586197.review:
The game's a pretty solid metroidvania with it's main gimmic being around playing Ikaruga while platforming/fighting. Two different elements are tied to the melee hits (with the rest being accessible only though magic spells), with are the wind element for added mobility in the air, and the fire element which has a longer slide with i-frames. Enemy attacks of the same element as the one you're using can be absorbed as MP, making spellcasting and arrows much less prohibitive to use in combat, and allowing to properly exploit the elemental weakpoints though magic and letting you in on ways to hit the enemy from long range even while dodging. The Ikaruga-esque elemental mechanic also allows for interesting scenarios during combat, as several bosses will shoot out attacks that will require quick switching in order to avoid damage. 

Deedlit's movements are also very responsive, without delay between input an action. She also can attack in most directions and has a bow to deal with long range or flying enemies, in case they were becoming annoying. My only two gripes with the controls is that trying to slide in the middle of a down attack will instead lead to a jump (which wouldn't surprise me if it was made on purpose, to not make Fire Deedlit near invincible), and the bow will cancel itself when you don't fire in like 3 seconds, forcing you to aim again.

The main negatives you could probably draw from the game are the lenght, map design, and difficulty. I cleared the game in 7.5 hours, at like 99% of the map completed, so probably you'd be seeing about 5-6 hours of regular play to just see the ending, though there's some additional content to get upon game completion. Some people might see this as too little for what they pay, others will be seeing a game they actually get to complete in their limited free time. For the map, the areas look really pretty, but are also mostly lineal, with few big rooms to tackle. There're secret passages (visible if you pay attention) and rewards from backtracking (sometimes a bit too many, as I replaced my weapon like 3 times in 15 minutes from simple backtrack), but it does have a sort of claustrophobic feeling at times. Regarding difficulty, Deedlit actually takes quite a bit of damage per hit, but the game has an auto-recovery mechanic though usage of the elemental switch system, letting you recharge HP so long as you don't get hit, and in the meantime you're also charging the other element's level through hits and kills. I could use this mechanic, together with long range and MP recovery on hits, to recover from potentially deadly scenarios, so more avid players will find much less of a challenge.

All in all, the game plays too well and is lots of fun to not recomment, even if you are like me and knows Lodoss War by name only. Very good game for fans of the metroidvania genre.

118415347.review:
Nostalgic from the start, Record of Lodoss War drops our Deedlit into a lush pixelscape of Metroidvanian excellence. With a heavy influence from Symphony of the Night, the game will feel instantly familiar in all the right ways. Not enough? Want something fresh? Sure! The unique mechanics involving elemental resistance will have you swapping elemental alignments mid fight in a satisfying dance. Want to pop out higher numbers? Pay attention to the elemental charts. Faced with an unavoidable attack? Swap to the same element to absorb it.

Even if you are unfamiliar with the eclectic Lodoss series (who can blame you) the aesthetic and presentation will blend into a soulslike approach to storytelling. You know what you need to know from the opening sequence. If anything, familiarity  with the series will only throw you an extra bone or two with various references down the line. 

The game does have some minor performance issues, but nothing that some fiddling didn't smooth over. So if you are looking for that special 'je ne sais quoi' of backdashing, monster slashing, magic slinging, map exploring goodness... this is the complete package, and it comes wrapped up in a great DnD inspired aesthetic.

118368017.review:
Not terrible, but has it's issues.
-Biggest issue, for the price it's a bit short.

-It's extremely linear, only exploration is backtracking to find the occasional item or such you'll more often than not never use after getting a new key/ability.

-Lack of readability, many enemies are hard to read/understand visually. Some attacks being the same color as others that are elemental (you can ignore if the right element) while not being such so you think you can be safe but take damage. You'll learn these after taking damage/dying a bit to the enemies that do it... but it still happens often enough to be annoying on bosses.

-It bugged out so after I beat the final boss... it wouldn't continue on the ending cutscene area, I had to restart and it wanted me to fight the final boss again... I just watched it on youtube.

-Lacking lore or interesting story. It's extremely bare bones, and pretty predictable what the ending is just a short bit into the game.


Now, all these cons aside... it's not terrible. The core gameplay is... different and somewhat unique from other metroidvanias. You have an elemental type, wind or fire. You can swap between them and you wont take any damage from elemental attacks of yours type. Some enemies are like this and wont take damage from you if you're the wrong type as well. Controls aren't perfect, sometimes it's hard to do what you want too... but overall it's mostly pretty good, if simplistic compared to many others by the end. It's still an interesting aproach to a metroidvania and I did like it as an interesting variation, but with the overall story lacking so, setting being meh... and short and buggy ish game time I just don't think it was worth the cost I payed for it. If it was like five to ten then it'd be more ok.
Honestly I had somewhat high hopes since I've liked this story/setting from the past, was thinking a metroidvania of it could be awesome... but again if you want story... you'll get basically nothing new or interesting here. One single main concept is all it has that is easy to predict and while something I like seeing explored... not nearly enough on it's own like it was done to really make me think the game was enjoyable or interesting lore or story wise while playing, or very memorable afterwards. That one mechanic is all that feels memorable after beating it now...
So ya, not terrible, buy on super sales maybe, but don't expect way too much. A slight thumbs down here.

116975245.review:
This game was actually in my wish list for quite some time, just never got around to picking it up. As someone who loves the Genera I found quite a bit about this game I really liked, but that isn't without some criticism. 

The comparison to Castlevania especially is very direct. It takes a lot of inspiration from that game and it might be a little too derivative of that game. The formula works quite well and the mechanics of the game are very good, but you'll never get as good of an experience out of this game as you would from Castlevania Symphony of the Night. This isn't to say the game is bad, its not, just that it very much lives in the shadow of another game and does too little different to stand out.

Another set of criticism I have is with the bosses. Quite a few of the bosses in this game are repeat bosses with new skins and maybe one or two new abilities so as you grow in skill at the game as well as levels with stronger equipment the game becomes much much easier as their patterns aren't much different. There really isn't any boss in the game that'll really stick out except maybe the last boss.

Last major criticism I have is with some of the sound direction. Now, I'm extremely sensitive to sounds around me. The "MAX LEVEL!" that played honestly was a bit overwhelming for me and there was just a lot of other noise pollution in the game. Music is a person taste thing but I didn't personally care for it. It was alright but nothing that was defining as Castlevania, Metroid or even as memorable as Ender Lilies for me.

I know I've been somewhat critical of the game up until this point, but now I get to talk about what I loved about the game.

The art direction was really good. The areas were distinct, the enemies all looked quite interesting and some of the unique capture animations such as with the mimic or when a boss grabs you or binds you was quite nice to see since they are unique sprites. The visual clues on your outfit was also really great to see with a blue cape or a green cape depending on which element you are attuned to at the time was helpful. The team really put a lot of effort into how the character looks and all the skills and it shows.

The gameplay is really fun. The wind and fire elemental swapping was very enjoyable and using that for puzzle solving and optimizing against bosses is a delight to use. The power sometimes can be a bit too strong at times trivializing some bosses in combination with magic. No boss was overwhelmingly difficult but they could provide a decent challenge for sure as well as testing your pattern recognition and reflexes with this elemental swapping skill as later bosses would use both. The two elements also has unique abilities which where required for puzzle solving and progression like blowing up barrels or hovering, so its a bit of a shame it wasn't used a bit more in unique ways since most the time it was just a means to pass a barrier.

The story was nice. It kept me engaged just enough to keep me interest even though I've never watched the anime its based off of. It takes place after the anime so it does have some spoilers for sure and it does go in expecting you to have at least some knowledge of the anime. This isn't too much of an issue since Deedlit's story is very relatable and easy to follow.

Now the question of do I recommend this game? Yes, even with the criticisms I have they're fairly light. If you can't get enough Castlevania than I absolutely would recommend trying this one out. Its a good game and not too expensive either.

116878556.review:
The game plays largely like a standard Metroidvania, with 2D platforming and stat management being of primary importance. You leap from place to place killing enemies, solving puzzles, and progressing the story. Along the way, you’ll obtain various weapons, some dropped by enemies and others obtained from allies and altars. You’ll also encounter magical spirits like Sylphs, Salamanders, and Will O’ Wisps, all of which augment Deedlit’s skillset. Sylph, for example, allows Deedlit to jump higher, float over water, and otherwise become light-of-body. Meanwhile, Salamander grants you the power to blow up explosives and walk through fiery hazards. In some cases, you’ll even need to switch between several spirits in order to pass through obstacles, such as intertwining elemental chains that demand you swap wind for fire on the fly.

Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth captures the spirit of 1990s-era, side-scrolling action, while tweaking the formula just enough to feel unique. The game's linearity and map design is a bit disappointing, as is the lack of unlockable content, but Wonder Labyrinth has solid gameplay and gorgeous visuals that are well worth checking out if you’re a genre fan.

116409070.review:
[b]Recommended at full price  [/b]

[b] Closest comparison: [/b] Castlevania SotN mixed with Ikaruga

[b] Duration/Replayability/Content: [/b] Around 5 hours to get 100% of the map, it also hides some hidden challenges (like gambling or a shooting gallery) that can increase it´s playtime a bit more, and it also has a boss rush mode unlocked after the first playtrough 

[b] So... What is this?: [/b] This is one of the most charming, interesting and well designed metroidvanias that I´ve ever played, adapting ikaruga´s  classic light/dark mechanic to an elemental fire/wind system. Story wise is kind of a direct sequel to the anime, so it is recommended that you are at least familiar with the source material, but it´s not really mandatory since the story is secondary to the gameplay at all times.

[b] Best features: [/b]
+ Cool Wind/Fire elemental system, some enemies are vulnerable or resistant to one element but the same goes for you, and you can switch your active element on the fly 
+ Great metroidvania map with a lot of secrets, backtracking and so on
+ Some great bossfights
+ A delight for fans of the anime, full of references and characters while giving a little continuation to the original story
+ Fluid combat with spells and an interesting "elemental level" (which is different from character level), the more you attack bosses or kill enemies while you are on an element, the other one slowly "levels up", when it reaches lvl 3 your attacks do more damage and your health constantly regenerates, BUT if you get hit the your levels drops instantly, it rewards good players and encourages aggression and constant element switching), 

[u] Feedback [/u]:
- A little short and limited replayability, some added modifiers on ng+ would´ve gone a long way since the basic gameplay loop is already extremely fun, kind of a nitpick tho
- The story is in a weird place, since on one hand it adds very little to the overall experience of the show (probably because it doesn´t want to alienate newcomers), so fans might feel like it´s a bit disappointing (subjective tho, I liked it very much), but on the other hand the little story there is does kind of rely on your previous knowledge about the source material (since a lot of characters show up and their importance will likely be entirely missed by newcomers), so maybe they should´ve added a compendium or something like that to at least try to introduce these old characters to new players

[b] Overall thoughts: [/b] I love the metroidvania games these developer makes, their design is really interesting and this one is not an exception, I was extremely excited to try this one out and it didn´t disapoint me at all, so of course I recommend it.

116170912.review:
This game is like the definition of a 6.5/10 Metroidvania.  There's nothing bad about the experience, but it has nothing innovative whatsoever.  It's modeling itself heavily off Symphony of the Night and plays very similar, but lacking the scale.

First off - this game also has nothing whatsoever to do with Record of Lodoss War.  It's like the devs made a generic dungeon game and then decided to paper the IP over top of it.  The story is super short and exists in a vacuum.  But I haven't seen Lodoss War in a long time, and it's pretty nice seeing the characters again.

Gameplay, just take the base Symphony of the Night experience.  You start with little, you beat bosses, you find new weapons, you level up a bit, you get better traversal skills, you unlock doors, you go to new areas, you beat more bosses, repeat.  You got your primary weapon which changes a bit how it attacks depending on what you equip, you got your bow which can shoot from a distance but costs a bit of MP with each shot, and you got your magic spell which does decent damage but costs a lot of MP.  

The only interesting wrinkle the game adds is that you shift between two element modes, fire and wind.  When you're in wind mode, you're immune to wind damage and deal wind damage with your weapon attacks, and vice versa with fire.  Some enemies are immune to fire so you have to attack with wind.  Some enemies attack with fire so you can ignore attacks by being in fire mode, and so on.  When you're in one mode and hit an enemy, you fill a gauge of power for the other mode, and when it's at level 3, your attacks do more damage in that mode and you passively regen HP.  But conversely, if you get hit you lose power in the gauge of the mode you're currently in.  So unless the enemy is weak to specifically fire or wind you kind of dance between the two modes keeping their gauges topped off.  There's a moderate amount of environmental puzzles where you have to switch between the two modes (which you do instantly with just a button press) to get passed obstacles.  

The real problem is this mechanic should have been the focus of the game but it's underutilized.  Most bosses only have one or two attacks using the mechanic.  Each mode is supposed to have an environmental traversal power - wind lets you hover a bit off the ground which helps traverse spike pit floors, and fire is supposed to allow you to blow up barrels.  Yet the fire specialty is used about three times the entire game, right after you get it, and then never again!  They should have been building on their only signature mechanic but it's like they forgot about it.

The game is insanely short too.  Where in a normal metroidvania you'd get a whole new zone to explore with your new traversal ability you just unlocked, in this game you get to the next boss within minutes.  The lack of build up leads to mental exhaustion, because the bosses are pretty fun but hitting them one after another lessens the enjoyment.  I took only 4 hours to completely clear the game.

Let it not be said that the game isn't fun - it's fun, but it's just so fleeting.

A nice 5 hour experience for anyone wanting to play Castlevania: Symphony of the Night but with an Ikaruga twist. 

The story is minimal but nice for anyone who is a fan of the anime it's based off of, being The Record of Lodoss War. The difficulty wasn't intense, especially if you're the type to explore every room possible to get that 100% map completion. Gameplay is nice and smooth, feeling the most similar to SOTN out of the metroidvania games out there. The game uses a system similar to Ikaruga, in which you switch between fire and wind elements to power up/negate damage of the corresponding type. It's not the main focus of the game however, but a tool included in your arsenal so it doesn't feel overbearing. The map is divided to six areas and you get the signature metroidvania backtracking to unlock new things, though there weren't as many as I would've liked and they are all optional.

The game's most amazing feature is the sprite art. While certain enemies are "very inspired" from SOTN, the game boasts some incredible animation. They followed SOTN's aesthetic and made a game that delivers on the unique details of flowing movement.

It's the Castlevania game I wanted for years, just wish it was longer and had some more rewards for backtracking.

114531467.review:
PREFACE
This is the first time I've felt compelled to leave a review. There will be spoilers. This is also my first Metroidvania. Overall I enjoyed the game and my introduction to the genre, but the execution of certain elements bring down the experience. I recommend this game with caveats - probs not worth the $20 price tag considering how short and unpolished it is, but if you're bored and it's on sale, it's not a bad way to pass 10 hours.

STORY
This is a sequel to the events of the Record of Lodoss War's two animes, but I don't think you need to understand the original story's content. The story gives away that it's been 100 years since the titular character Deedlit adventured with the rest of her classic fantasy posse. And the title is of course a reference to Alice in Wonderland. So it's pretty easy to surmise that she's in a dream world of sorts. Due to that, what little dialogue the paperthin story has is pretty much deliberately obscure philosophizing, as all of the characters she runs into aren't actually themselves, but mouth holes for the voice of the author. It tries to be really deep when it's basically just another 5 stages of grief narrative.

CORE MECHANIC
I quite frankly liked the gameplay early on. The movement and combat centers around fire and air elemental spirits, which you can toggle between. Both allow you to regenerate MP from attacks of that element, though you do type specific damage, and enemies have particular resistances. Air lets you levitate while fire... well, I guess it later gets a better slide attack with invincibility frames, but that doesn't really feel meaningful. Both elements have energy bars that fill up to level 3 from successful attacks using the other element. Taking damage in an elemental form reduces the level, and at level 3 you get HP regen. So switching between forms is highly incentivized, and one is rewarded for their versatility and skill at dodging attacks with near immortality. Would probably make this a fun game to speedrun, if it wasn't for...

EXPLORATION
A lot of other reviews mention how linear the map design is. And yeah, there are few pathways that are objectively unnecessary to explore. Although this is my first Metroidvania, it was pretty obvious to me which powerups I could anticipate based on the artificial exploration limits in maps. Which is unfortunate. Early on the exploration was soft-gated by puzzles that were all elemental spirit or bow related, which were at least interesting. Later portions of the map were hard-gated by power-ups or color coded doors that open across the map with a switch. The fast travel and saves made backtracking through earlier sections easy, especially due to the...

RPG MECHANICS
I genuinely feel like the levels and stats bring down the experience of this game towards the end. Early on all the enemies and bosses are perfectly balanced for the kit that you have. But once you get to the "4th stage," it spirals out of control. Other reviews that mention the late game difficulty spike are universally because they are more seasoned Metroidvania players who weren't trying to 100% the game. I actually tried to 100% the game, and because of that I was rewarded with being hilariously overleveled. When I had unlocked enough of the key abilities that made it worthwhile to backtrack (as well as discovered that certain parts of the wall are breakable and lead to new pathways), the enemies from earlier map regions became a chore to spam through. All that backtracking rewarded me with more gold than I knew what to do with, so I loaded up on health pots and other consumeables. Going forward those made me horribly overpowered, even against bosses. This is made extremely clear by the odd choice to have a boss rush as the miniboss to the final boss - the old bosses hadn't scaled with my level and most of them died within 10 seconds of spamming the attack button. 

A similar thing more or less happened with the game's equipment. There's a main weapon as well as a bow, with many variants for sale that only differed in 1 of 3 ways: attack speed, damage, and utility. Items with added utility, like multishot or homing bows, are literally so much better than the single shot, slightly tweaked speed/damage bows that even if something did 10 more damage per shot it wouldn't be an effective trade-off to never having to deal with the non-satisfying aim mechanic. For the main weapon, the clear advantage was in the two thrown weapons, the boomerang and the shuriken - they had the best range for their attack speed, but also the ability to hit the enemy as it returns to you. Every single other weapon the game tries to throw at you becomes pretty meaningless. I would've much preferred if they simply made the bow modular (penetrating, homing, multishot, lifesteal, etc) as power ups to be earned through exploration, rather than trying to scale player stats with enemy encounters.

OTHER GRIPES
- There's an archery training area, which on top of the arrow ricochet puzzles would make you think the bow is necessary. But in boss fights, actually aiming the bow is completely unnecessary, you just spam. While some boss maps have the metal walls needed to ricochet arrows, this is never actually necessary. It should have been if one is going to justify an archery training area/minigame.
- The best bosses are the humanoid ones. The small hitbox encourages aiming, and the fact that they can move as quickly as you makes it seem like a real fight. The dragons or the final boss are all so big that they just become spam magnets.
- Very surprised at the lack of enemies recognizable from the Lodoss War anime. Instead there's a grab-bag of generic fantasy creatures, most of which have movesets so slow and predictable that late-game they die before having a chance to attack.
- While the core mechanic revolves around fire and wind elementals, there are actually a good number of other elemental types in the game, which are poorly fleshed out. Dark and Light are the obvious other pair, which is the reason why everyone mentions the Will o' Wisp (Light) spell (most enemies of note are Dark). The introduction of elemental weaponry simply waters down the need to master the fire/wind core mechanic, so I don't really understand why they were included.
- Speaking of Will o' Wisp, the most broken spell in the game is actually Invisibility, which leaves behind an afterimage for the enemy to attack. Neither attacking nor taking damage while you are invisible breaks it, and even bosses are fooled by it. And it costs barely more than Will o' Wisp.

First off, there need to be more Americanized Lodoss War games based on the anime, which is the first anime that I ever purchased years ago.  Secondly, if you're going to clone the look and feel of Castlevania SotN, make sure you do it right. Put your hands together, and you get a great little love letter to both.

Sure, the game is short, but it's beautiful and still enjoyable to play.  It's got a slightly gimmicky fire/wind system, but it's no different than the light/dark systems that some games utilize.  I'm not sure about replayability (still haven't finished as of writing this review), but I saw there's an unlockable boss rush mode at least. It's rare to just jump right back into a metroidvania immediately after unlocking all its secrets anyway.  And speaking of that, this is a great game to jump into the metroidvania genre if you never dared since it's lacking all the complex stuff most games these days throw at you to learn.

Long story short (too late), it's a no-brainer to try this game if you love simple metroidvanias AND the Lodoss War anime.  If you love either of those, pick it up on a sale when it's under $10.

111359917.review:
[b]GET THIS ON SALE![/b]

Don't get me wrong, the game is not bad, actually it feels pretty nice. I feel like Luna Nights from the same dev was a bit more bang for your buck when it comes to an individual Metroidvania game since more aspects of the combat were pretty unique and standalone. 

If you have the money, but neither Luna Nights or Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth, I would heavily suggest you get Luna Nights instead. It's a little cheaper, but far more unique when it come to approaching the Metroidvania genre while tackling it with a weakened version of Touhou's character that you play as. I don't really know anything about Touhou I just know she can stop time and likes knives.
https://store.steampowered.com/app/851100/Touhou_Luna_Nights/

Now onto the actual review.

I've played plenty of Castlevania, and barely any Metroid. Most of what I know about Metroid is from outside sources like YouTube or just word of mouth from friends and watching friends play. This feels like a simplified Castlevania: Symphony of the Night.

The story is pretty dog dukey. I didn't care about it much at all, I didn't skip or anything on my first playthrough but I did get tired of the story really quickly. It seemed flabby and emotionless, a lot of characters come off dumber than I think they should've and a lot of talks between characters are highlighted as very important by the "director" but it all seems like low level gibberish that a teen made for some sorta edgy Japanese short-story that they wrote for their literary class trying to sound like they're "in the know" with poetic speak, but didn't even hit the dart board.

Gameplay is nice. It's very fun and I very rarely had moments where I felt like the game screwed me over, or threw things at me that I couldn't react to.

I said I very rarely had moments though, which means I had moments and I'll try to explain.

One thing that's really annoying is trying to slide after an attack. Even though you're "physically" done with an attack and could cancel into something else if they game allowed you, you simply can't. You have to wait until the [b]ENTIRE ANIMATION[/b] is done before you can slide, which isn't a good thing in a fast paced metroidvania where being ready to dodge tight stuff is very important.

Stun locking is a very real threat in this game and it's way too punishing whenever it happens. A lot of the times, if you don't go out of your way for HP upgrades from secrets and just general progression, most stuns will pit you near death or just outright kill you. I don't really see the purpose of stuns in this game and I genuinely don't think this game would suffer that much if you were to hypothetically remove them.

The Will-o-Wisp spell is overpowered. It deals considerable damage, and restores chunks of your gauge very quickly for basically no effort. Speaking of no effort, they heat seek, and It also freezes the screen (every one of the spells do this though) which can give you a breather to plan your next move which makes evading things really easy. They have no risk to them. The only downside is MP cost which is a measely 15 MP, and most fights will outright give you the ability to just pretend you're in a manawell. At the halfway mark you get a sword that just gives you MP on each attack, and a bow that gives you HP on each attack.

For example, shining star boss you can pretty much just sit in the lava and spam will-o-wisp in fire spirit with no downside. If you get a bow that uses a specific element, or none at all, you can also use these same manawells to just spam on the boss for free. I don't think they really thought too hard about the abusability of elemental immunity when they gave you element specific/non-elemental weapons, but I digress, there's many times you can be very egregious with it's usage.

The damage or effects of the other spells don't really make much a difference. They're way too expensive in mana cost to be used regularly, and the few times where I could use them for a burst, I'd just use Will-o-Wisp for more advantages. I literally never used Invisibility or that dark bat spell once beyond when I immediately got the spells. They are extremely underwhelming.

The wind slide is so useless. No iframes and weak travel. The flame slade has iframes and very good travel, while also doing decent damage that you can weave into a bow shot or melee. I can only assume that this was done to give each spirit their own mobility gimmick, because once you get the double jump extension the ability to hover never becomes needed at all. Plus flame spirit gives bonus damage to everything that doesn't guard against flame, so there's that.

Map detail is really nice. I hear a complaint about map sense being off, but I don't really care about that stuff and don't entirely see how it affects the gameplay. When it comes to the layout, I feel like teleports and save stations can sometimes be put at really awkward spots which make them very inconvenient for the majority of stages.

Music is really good. Same with art in general.

I genuinely enjoyed my time with this game but [b]20 bucks[/b] for [b]4 hours[/b] of playtime and [b]no extra content[/b] beyond boss rush (not even a hard mode or a remix) is [i]ridiculous[/i]. I really hope they patch in some extra content as free dlc eventually. If they add some more content that expands the playtime to about the same for Luna Nights, it's an easy sell for me.

108832346.review:
Very solid, definitely recommended on sale. It's not the game I was hoping for and there are a few reservations, but if you enjoy the genre, there's plenty of fun to have with this.

Here are my thoughts:

+ Excellent game feel. Controls are extremely smooth.
+ Most of the bosses are really great, Karla and Narse are probably the two highlights.
+ The element switching mechanic is an awesome idea (could have been incorporated a bit more deeply into the game, though).
+ Fantastic art and a lot of great monster designs. Deedlit also animates beautifully and it's just a joy to see her jumping and dashing around.

= Story is just there. Not a big deal to me, this will depend on what you're looking for.
= Music isn't bad but isn't that memorable.

- Too linear. There isn't a lot of interesting backtracking and the map feels a bit too compact. It's not really an exploration game, it's an action game with Metroidvania elements.
- Too easy. This is probably the biggest problem, there's just no real sense of challenge. There are a couple of difficulty bottlenecks with some annoying strong enemies but nothing major. This is a snack, not a full meal.
- Most of the new weapons you acquire don't feel meaningful or interesting.

108787374.review:
A good game heavily in the style of Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, but not superior to SotN.  There are a lot of things that I felt missing, like armor and accessories. The music is full of bangers, and I've put the OST on my wishlist for (hopefully) a future sale.

From the anime series that was basically an AD&D campaign (and all the better for it) comes a side-story starring the elf Deedlit. Mysterious circumstances bring her to a megadungeon alone, ever unsettling as fragments of her past come forth without warning. What has happened, and why is this old-school gish here? Only for you to find out.

The tale plays like an Igavania game boiled down to its essentials, but with its own style. Various weapons are at Deedlit's disposal, and secret spirit magic spells can grant her advantages with the elemental rock-paper-scissors of enemy weaknesses. However, two elements are integral to her -- fire and wind, manifest as familiars who let her "absorb" their elements. Understanding which of these two spirits to have out when will be integral to survival -- both to regain MP for spells, and to regenerate HP when a spirit is at full strength.

Mastering this game relies on being skillful with melee weapons, using your bow to fight from afar and solve mechanical puzzles, casting spells and understanding what magic to use when. You know, as any elf is wont to do. Traversing the environs is treacherous and boss fights are brutal, forcing you to think on your feet and use all at your disposal. 

Deedlit's max HP and MP are relatively static, and returning to shops for consumables isn't reliable. Luckily, restarting from save points is quick, and boss rooms are preceded by a means to power up your familiars to be at full strength beforehand. Expect to replay most boss fights at least once to master their attack patterns. And as with any Igavania, backtracking with new traversal skills (and unlocking certain colored gates in the labyrinth) will serve you well.

The translation isn't perfect, but it's still legible and feels like old-school JRPGs you'd grown up with. You know the ones. As someone who has only seen a few episodes of the Lodoss War anime, the big reveals caught me off-guard but proved satisfying by the end nevertheless. If you're an outsider to the series, the game does well enough to present its story without holding your hard. I'm sure Lodoss War fans will adore the shoutouts that flew over my head much more.

If you're looking for a short-and-sweet, challenging Metroidvania that innovates on the genre's design, you've come to the right table. The DM may not go easy on you, but the brave will see their skills reward them and enjoy the wonders within this labyrinth.

108659387.review:
Do you like Castlevania: Symphony of the Night? Then you know what you're in for and would like this (with one major asterisk).

This game is in desperate need of separate music and sound effects volume sliders. Music and sound effects are tied to the same *one* slider. This is a problem because, everywhere you go, the music is blaringly loud and energetic. It gets extremely grating. When I was on the verge of a headache, I'd mute the sound just to get a reprieve. Further, it's hilarious that they're selling the soundtrack separately because, in addition to being uniformly bombastic, I can't recall a single tune. Utterly bland and generic. Forgettable. Indistinct. Meanwhile, Symphony of the Night's soundtrack I'm still humming 20+ years on.

Is that an unfair comparison? Probably, but having suffered through 6.5 hours of that soundtrack, I'm not exactly feeling charitable. Patch a slider in, guys. You're not Nintendo and this isn't the 90s. Games have settings these days.

Also, it's rather short with very little inherent replay value. I've been playing a lot of metroivdanias lately and as far as replayability goes, this one's at the lower end of the spectrum. Finishing the game only unlocks a boss rush... which blows my mind because the next-to-last boss of the game is a boss rush, so... what's the point? There are no alternate playable characters. No alternate play styles. Either play it again or... don't. I probably won't.

So why am I recommending this while sounding so negative? Like I said at the beginning, it's very comparable to Symphony of the Night (soundtrack aside): solid gameplay, movement, and combat. It feels good to play. It looks wonderful. It's absolutely worth playing... but buy it on sale... at least until they fix the sound options. $20 is a bit steep for a short, one-play game that might cause headaches.

Fantastic metroidvania with a great visual style, great music, and very satisfying sound effects. It feels very much like a tribute to Symphony of the Night, but it also has so many unique mechanics that are very much its own that it doesn't just feel like it's ridding the coattails of SotN, it's giving a respectable bow to the classic while moving forward with its own agenda.

One of the specific things that feels so great about the game is some of the unique gameplay mechanics and controls. It's such a mechanically satisfying game to play. If you're used to playing hard games you will absolutely destroy this game and one shot most bosses, but somehow the game feels very satisfying. It's on the easier side of games that expect mechanical prowess, but not to the point of not having fun.

The writing was very anime and cliche, but to the point of being kind of campy and fun. I'm not familiar with it and I don't watch or appreciate anime in general, so this would normally be where a game like this loses points with me. In this case the dialogue was short enough that I wasn't bothered by it and it was something we had fun with and chuckled about with chat. You'll be able to appreciate the basic plot though even not knowing the characters and background and again it doesn't take away from the experience and is more or less the same amount of dialogue you'd have in SotN itself.

The map is smaller and there are tons of fast travel points. I don't mind this because there are still a few good gauntlet hallways and these days I really just don't want a game to be wasting my time and this game did not.

I'd give it an 8/10 overall and would say it's highly worth the price on steam, even without a sale.

108175562.review:
After the 2 hour mark, they stopped caring because they knew no one could refund it. The first sign is the archery minigame that's the hardest thing in the game by an incredibly wide margin & is required for 100% weapon completion (and therefore two achievements) but requires none of the skills involved in the rest of the game.

After that, the signs quickly pile up. Long hallways that repeat the same enemy pattern. Long hallways full of the same enemy. Enemies who just sit there & let you kill them. Straight lines of enemies you can just jump/float over/slide through. Bosses who just sit there & let you kill them. A mandatory boss rush that's filled mostly with bosses you'll kill in several seconds because you're over leveled now but also includes the two bosses you just beat, one of whom is a slight variation of another boss you've beaten twice.

It even fails at the basics of metroidvania design because most of the backtracking you'll do is to unlock earlier doors that require keys you suddenly start getting really quickly right before the end of the game or breakable walls in obscure spots or tall shafts you needed the double jump to get through. Then there's the room you can only access by jumping on a certain spot 50 times. Literally 50 times!

Worst of all, the map is designed to make you go through some of the most pointless filler hallways countless times to really maximize the artificial lengthening. The bosses are either braindead easy or are given ridiculous stats just to make you find the cheese that turns the fight into a joke.

There's a lot of cheese. There are moves that make you invincible, enemy attacks that potentially heal you, weapons that heal you, & there's even a spell that's not hidden that makes you invisible while draining your MP so slowly that it lasts the whole fight in most cases while the boss attacks a decoy & you just stab it in the back the whole time. Made worse by the fact that because they can't see you, you're free to stand around absorbing the elements they liberally fire at you so you can fully heal repeatedly throughout the fight, restoring your MP in the process so you stay invisible.

It's plain to see that even a lot of the people who say the game is good don't really like it because their excuse for the bad optional content (in a genre about completionism) is "Don't play it.", their excuse for the OP moves (almost all of the moves) is "Don't use 'em.", & their response to people who don't like the game in general is "Don't play it."

The writing is terrible too. The game constantly acts like its characters are speaking in deep riddles even though it's constantly screaming its twist at you so there's nothing to look forward to because you know how the game is gonna end almost immediately after you start playing it. It's pretty much in the title of the game.

Due to circumstances that admittedly make sense, everyone is behaving out of character all the time by talking like robots & due to reasons that don't make sense, no one just says what they mean. As a result, you don't know anything about any of the characters if you haven't watched the show so it's impossible to care about anything.

This game is good for a little over 2 hours as a way of coasting off of bias caused by buyer's remorse to get good reviews from people who backed it, people who liked it at first, people who like Symphony of the Night, people who like Luna Nights, & people who like the show. Luna Nights is tons better despite being made by the same people. They knew how to make something good but they phoned it in this time.

108069236.review:
Decent metroidvania game but lacking in content, game modes and is easy to completely breeze through in <5 hours if you're used to this kind of game. There are no difficulty modes and after beating the game you unlock a boss rush time attack mode.

The graphics and music are excellent and control is solid. Has pretty fun boss fights and a polarity mechanic ala ikaruga/outland that functions well. There are some very basic puzzles sprinkled throughout using only a couple gameplay mechanics. These environmental puzzles never surprised me and kind of felt like a chore instead of something engaging.

As a weak point the environments and level design feel a bit soulless/predictable and the world map doesn't convey a feeling of a cohesive whole. Progression is extremely linear & obvious (kind of like Metroid Dread, except more so). You generally proceed to the next set of color-coded doors that you unlocked, with one or two exceptions. 
These things make me question why this needed to be a metroidvania instead of a straightforward stage-based game like rondo of blood with more focused level design. The game even refers to large areas as levels so maybe the direction was different at some point during development. On top of that the stores around the map have mostly useless weapons by the time you have money for them. Money & health/mana upgrades dont feel significant.

The game has a nice amount of control and graphics options for the user. The menus and general UI are really smooth.

I'm not familiar with the Lodoss series but I got the impression this game doesn't really add much to the story / world. It's a tiny side story where perhaps only the opening and ending have any significance.

Lightly recommended if the game is on sale or you have interest in the Lodoss series. The game is a decent if super straight-forward castlevania SOTN clone with excellent presentation. Just don't expect it to have a lot of content, a real sense of exploration or be a challenging action game.
I wouldn't recommend this game at base price. There is a lot of competition in the genre and at this price point you could most likely get another game with more fleshed out level design & content. Similarly for games with more rewarding action, exploration or story experiences. 

What's here is pretty good but nothing stands out apart from the clean presentation. The level design and lack of difficulty modes is a main sticking point for me. I'm all for short games if they're tightly designed and encourage replaying.
The movement mechanics are so typical that I don't feel incentivized to do a challenge/speed run through the game after getting a hang of its mechanics, it'd be like any classic metroidvania since SOTN except probably even less going on in movement. The boss rush mode that's implemented does make sense but it's a small bonus.

107561922.review:
This game is a very obvious homage to SOTN. Which is fantastic, because that is one of my favorite games. I found it to be fun immediately, albeit a bit easy. The animations are amazingly smooth, the pixel art is phenomenal. The music is great. The game is fairly straight forward, kill stuff, level, unlock doors, beat bosses. Most enemies can be killed before they attack you, but a few rooms later in the game pose a challenge. The arrow puzzles were simple yet a nice diversion to getting some items.

I wasn't even sure who the dev was for this game, I just bought it because it looked like SOTN. But, as soon as I saw the Team Ladybug logo, I knew I would probably be playing a game similar to Touhou Luna Nights. It definitely has a similar feel. A lot of similar gimmicks are in the game, though they are gimmicks I enjoyed. I liked swapping between wind and fire states, how that changed game play and what I could absorb.

Some gripes. Pressing hover, bow, and the stationary button all at the same time to aim in air is very impractical. This is a great feature, but it is not functional. It's a design choice, but I would have expected pressing the bow button in air to make you stationary. It would have been far more practical and enjoyable IMO. However, the bow is mostly useless in the game, at least the way I played.

I watched the anime in preparation for this, and I can say, it is much better than the anime lol. You need only watch the first anime to understand the relationships of the characters, but really you don't need to at all because there is a very limited story. The second one you definitely don't need to watch, as there is only one small reference to a character from the second one, and I guess one from the manga as well, but I didn't read them.

The game took me around six hours to beat with 100% of the map. Asking price is steep for the amount of content. I did not bother to get all of the achievements, but I would imagine this adds a few hours of gameplay. That being said, this is a high quality product and may be worth full price to some. Definitely pick it up if it's on sale though.

I feel i need to address a little bit on the difficulty curve of the game, some reviews of this game mentioned a steep difficulty change towards the end? I don't find that to be true at all. The pacing of this game is pretty normal for these types of games, I never felt like the difficulty suddenly just spikes up unnaturally. It can get challenging, but not unfair because you have all these items, weapons and abilities to use and help you out. I mean its not even close to a Souls-like difficulty if that's what you're asking.

Legend:
+++ BULLSEYE!
++- Neat!
+-- Mmmm ... okay!
--- Yiikes!
+-+ Mix Bag (Sometimes is ok Sometimes is not)
+-  Not a Big Deal. (Neutral)

Basically I feel like this game hits all the +++ Bullseye points from Graphics to Mechanics. However, I do have a little gripe on the stun mechanics in this game though, and yeah the enemies can stun YOU so you have a down time there, this means either you quickly alternate between left and right to break yourself from stun or use an item. Just wanted to mention this so people would know that it's a thing in this game, but it's Not a Big Deal +- 

Total Score

Like I said before if you already like Metroidvania games, add this into your Library XD

What about the RPG elements? Leveling was fine, weapon selection wasn't too diverse but it did offer meaningful choice in some ways. There are no accessories(rings/talismans) or armor of any type. Sure it's fun in Castlevania to get some new whatever but.. it doesn't really change gameplay and thus nothing here is lost by it's omission.

Something impressive to me, the boss fights are difficult without being a slog against something with too much hp or too much lethality.

106630498.review: So much about this game is awesome, and I really wish I could recommend it, as it is a true love letter to Castlevania SOTN fans along with Lodoss fans. Deedlit moves and controls very well, just like Alucard, with fluid animations and loads of spells and maneuvers. However, the difficult really ramps up towards the end of the game, and like Touhou Luna Nights (Team Ladybug's other Metroidvania type game), the last bosses are absurdly difficult. I'm an older gamer, and I just don't have the patience anymore to slog through overly drawn out boss battles that require you to learn many MANY patterns that change on the fly. I don't mind dying and retrying once, twice, 10 times even. But eventually I just had to stop because I don't have the patience. It is frustrating as hell and it's not fun anymore to have to redo a boss battle over and over and over again. These types of old school 16 bit era difficult ramp ups just aren't fun anymore. I had the patience to deal with them when I was young, but anything that makes me want to smash my controller just isn't OK in my book anymore. For some of you hardcore gamers out there, the final bosses will be a walk in the park. You live and breathe pattern recognition and fast reflexes. Us OGs on the other hand don't like pulling out our hair, so sadly, like Luna Nights, I can't recommend this one. So much of it is great, but shame on Team Ladybug for making the end game sadistically hard.

106627783.review: If you love Symphony of the Night, you will love this game. It feels more refined both aesthetically, visually, and even in gameplay. I can't stress enough how well the controls feel and the visuals are inspiring. It also comes with a delicious cup of nostalgia if you enjoyed Record of Lodoss War.

106598101.review:
Note: I do not know the source material well.

I just finished collecting everything. If you want a ~8-10 hour metroidvania this is your game. It isn't difficult, but the layout is well planned, the elemental mechanics are fun, and the movement is smooth. The music and art are fantastic. This game plays it safe with the story, so people wanting deep Lodoss lore or an award winning story, this isn't your game. But if you are okay with a minimalistic story, this can work. This game won't convince metroidvania haters to like the genre, but it is a solid addition to the library for those who can always do more.

105770337.review:
It's short, but it's quality.  Graphics are great, controls are good (I had to use Joy2Key to get the D-pad usable, and had to change which button was cancel so she wouldn't cast a spell when exiting a menu, but after that I had no problems), gameplay is good.  

It has some interesting mechanics, like how you can switch which element you're using and absorb energy from that element (like Ikaruga), although there were only two elements you could switch between so there were a lot of magic attacks you couldn't absorb (honestly I think it's better that way).  

The story is meh, but I don't really play games for story.  It's cool if a game has a good story, but that's not what I'm there for.  If I really want a good story I'll watch a movie or a show.  For a game I'm just interested in the gameplay.

If you're looking for the next Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, this ain't it.  If you're just looking for a good metroidvania to spend 6 hours having fun on, this is it.  I swear some of the negative reviews were from people looking for something that would change their lives, and angry that it didn't.

Pros:
- The difficulty is just about right, if not a bit easy;
- Amazing visuals in all layers, objects and mobs/NPCs, really charming and pleasing. A really well made pixel art!

- A good arsenal with some variety
- Boss rush mode and NG+ (but without additional content)

Cons
- Short game, you'll beat it in 8h or less
- Apparently they already did a final update, so there will hardly/not be any DLCs, meaning that the game will stay short
- Expensive OST
- Kind of expensive considering the playtime you'll likely get (from 6 to 12h mostly, seeing other reviews)
- Relatively short map, with not so much of backtracing and revisiting

I'd give it an 7.5, problem being mostly the lengh of playtime, lack of more content and the price. Still, I recommend it if you like pixel art and metroidvania

104765791.review:
Record of Lodoss War: Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth: R3mothered is the latest pile by Team Ladybug, better known for the incredible Touhou: Luna Nights. Like its predecessor, Record of Lodoss War: Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth is a m*troidv*nia with lovely 2D sprite work and a killer soundtrack. Yet there's something missing from Record of Lodoss War: Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth that made Luna Nights so great.

Whereas Luna Nights had several gimmicks like bullet hell boss patterns, freeze time (that can be used to build up projectiles) and grazing bullets for MP, Record of Lodoss War: Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth has an Ikaruga-like polarity mechanic. And a bow. The polarity gimmick is implemented well enough - wind spirit takes no damage from blue projectiles and fire spirit takes no damage from red projectiles - but they made a really odd choice. Your cape is blue with the wind spirit equipped, which is fair enough, but when you equip the fire spirit your cape turns... green? I have no idea what they were going for there. During the more chaotic boss fights it's confusing to read visually, and while I got used to it eventually, it's just a really insane and counterintuitive design choice. Oh well. The polarity mechanic is fine but Luna Nights got a surprising amount of mileage out of its bullet time gimmick, while Record of Lodoss War: Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth slightly... predictable. It does everything you expect from polarity, but not much else.

I should mention there's also a sublevel system that reminded me of Cave Story. If you kill an enemy with wind spirit equipped you get red cubes, and vice versa. Each spirit can be leveled up to three with these cubes. Instead of powering you up, they slowly heal your health at level 3. To that effect Record of Lodoss War: Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth feels easier than Luna Nights. I don't necessarily mind this, but it does cause a certain lack of urgency in boss battles. I wouldn't get rid of the mechanic entirely as I do think it's interesting, but it would probably benefit from a nerf. Namely, every single time you hit a boss you get points for your sublevel. Maybe dial that back a little.

You get a bow as a secondary projectile weapon, but it's also used in some light puzzle solving. This is actually one of my favorite parts of Record of Lodoss War: Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth. At first you're shooting arrows at gears to life gate doors, but it slowly gets more complex as the game progresses, requiring some additional platforming and planning. There was one puzzle in particular I thought was really clever, but I won't spoil it if you do end up playing Record of Lodoss War: Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth. There are also multiple spells to acquire throughout the game, but I always stuck to the default homing missile spell, so whatever.

As mentioned before, the difficulty leans a bit on the easy side. You'll probably die a dozen or so times to boss fights, but on the whole you can manage to take them down if you spam magic and arrows enough while occasionally getting close enough to sneak in some proper attacks. Regardless, the boss fights are usually quite enjoyable. They don't throw anything particularly unique at you but learning their patterns and deftly switching polarities is a fun time overall. The penultimate encounter is just a boss rush, which is annoying because the first five or so phases are easy enough to just tank out their attacks and spam them. The final boss fight felt like something I've fought in a thousand other games, so that's a bit anti-climactic. Still, fun times overall.

Record of Lodoss War: Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth is fairly short - I beat the game with 97% of the map uncovered just shy of seven hours. I had a mostly fun time with it but couldn't help but feel it was a bit lacking in inspiration. As such it's a solid m*tro*dv*nia but falls short of the higher echelons. Still, definitely recommended if you're into this sort of game.

Do you like Metroidvanias?  Do you like high fantasy, or Record of Lodoss War in particular?  Then get. this. goddamn. game.  It's not the longest game ever at around 6 to 7 hours depending on how long you take to beat all the bosses, but almost everything about it is perfectly executed.  The controls are perfect, the gameplay gimmicks feel well designed, every death feels fair, the bosses are hard but really enjoyable to figure out, the animation is fantastic...

If I have one significant complaint, it's that the music is the weakest part of the game.  It's passable, but it's not great.  But hey, if that's the worst thing I can say about DiWL, that says a lot.

I really hope this creator returns to the project and puts out a big DLC.  They already have so much work done, and all I really want from DiWL is to have an Inverted Castle SotN style second half.  But as it is, I'm very satisfied and feel like I've gotten to revisit the lore and characters from one of my favorite stories.

104006238.review:
This really hit the sweet spot for me when it comes to Metroidvanias. I love the genre, but it works best in tight packages that take less than 10 hours on the initial playthrough. The game and/or collecting aspect of the game has to be super engaging for me to enjoy it for a longer time frame (e.g. Bloodstained, Aria of Sorrow, Metroid series).

As for Wonder Labyrinth, it never overstayed its welcome. The gameplay is tight and satisfying. There's just enough tweaks along the way to keep it interesting. The boss fights are well-crafted and are never too challenging as to drag too long. Yet mastering each boss feels rewarding. Overall, This is definitely worth the money, and I could see myself coming back to it to play a higher difficulty and/or beat it in a faster time.

103874236.review:
Warning:  If you're photosensitive, stay away.  There are a number of flashing cutscenes and transition effects that cannot be turned off or disabled.  At the end is a series of flashes that are painful to watch even without being photosensitive.

Another very solid Metroidvania-lite from Team Ladybug, who made the wonderful Touhou Luna Nights a few years ago.  Like their previous game, this is a "lite" form of the genre, where you have the game broken up into stages (while still being interconnected) and it is much more linear than some of the other examples of the genre.  Each stage after the first contains one major progression ability, two bosses, and a scattering of other upgrades, spells, and weapons lying around.

Movement and combat feel amazing, it is super fluid and satisfying to move around.  The different abilities mesh well, and can be used for both platforming and combat segments.  There is a lot of enemy variety in each stage, and bosses for the most part are well designed and distinctive.  A few of the late mid-game bosses feel a bit "samey", but the quality of the others greatly outweights it.  There is a late game boss rush which is intense and extremely fun.

Like Touhou Luna Nights, there is a bit of bullet hell inspiration in the boss fights.  This time, the inspiration is the game Ikaruga.  Shortly into the game, you'll gain the ability to switch between wind and fire attunements.  While in fire attunement, fire attacks will regenerate your MP instead of doing damage.  Likewise for wind.  Switching attunements is a key method of progression and surviving boss fights, with one of the chapter 2 bosses being the peak of this mechanic.

The artwork works well, the sprites are beautifully done and well animated, and aside from the flashing, the visual effects are good.  There are a lot of sounds reused from Luna Nights, though most of them work well here.  The "level 3" sound clip makes me feel like "it's on!" and is very satisfying even if a bit repetitive.  Music is good, but not quite as memorable as Luna Night's soundtrack.

Strongly recommended to anyone who likes the more "vania" side of Metroidvania, and don't mind the slightly more linear structure.

This game absolutely slaps. Trust the reviews, if you like Metroidvanias you will love this game. This game is better than all the DS and GBA Castlevanias, better than Bloodstained, and better than contemporaries like Lost Ruins. If you played Touhou Luna Nights (the previous game that this developer made), the game is very similar in design and feel, but is different enough gameplay-wise that it is a unique experience.

Presentation is beautiful (both graphics and music), combat is fast and engaging, and backtracking is minimal thanks to simple game design and ample teleportation rooms. I finished the game in 6 hours and was left wanting more because I was having fun the whole time. 

I don't really have anything bad to say about the game at all, except that knockback is kinda wonky and lasts forever. The game is also a bit on the easy side and has no difficulty options, but challenge modes are available once the game has been beaten. 

Also the game is based on a pretty obscure (in the west at least) IP, so I had no idea who any of the characters were or how I was supposed to feel about them. The story isn't really the focal point of the game though so I'm willing to overlook it.

This game is a must-own if you like Metroidvanias.

102795715.review: 10/10 the best successor to Symphony of the Night to date. Add in the fact that it's based on a great anime, and it makes you barely miss the Castlevania aspects. Symphony of the Night is an eternal classic and we all hope Konami releases it on Steam soon with high-res remastered original PS1 sound and the levels from the Saturn version added in, but Wonder Labyrinth will tide you over.  It scratches the itch even better than the GBA and DS games, which I would highly recommend as well. The biggest imperfection here is that you can't turn off the music without turning off all sounds, and I'd like to play the SotN soundtrack in the background, however, it's not too big a deal as Wonder Labyrinth has a great soundtrack, just not as good as SotN, but so few games/movies do. Other than that, there are really only very minor imperfections, overall the developers did an amazing job advancing what SotN and its sequels for the GBA did so well. The only thing I could really ask of the game is more of itself, but I'd rather have it be solid from start to finish than have it padded with a bunch of fluff like so many so-called "AAA" games do these days. It's just that Wonder Labyrinth is so fun to play I want more of it to explore and experience. Even though the game is a bit short, it has massive replayability and speedrunning potential. Wonder Labyrinth is worth every penny, and there is more great art and imagination in it than a dozen $60 modern "AAA" games. Gaming perfection.

102568993.review:
Pros:
+Gorgeous animations and stage design.
+Awesome music.
+Fluid and addicting Metroidvania gameplay with a hint of Ikaruga.
+It's about time we got another Lodoss War game!

Cons:
-WAY. TOO. SHORT.
-A bit on the easy side.

Record of Lodoss War is a Dungeons and Dragons inspired sword-and-sorcery series of novels that was adapted into a manga, a fantastic OVA series, as well a follow-up series and movie. As far as games, the last Record of Lodoss War game I can remember was the Dreamcast game that came out in 2000, and it was decent at best. Now, 21 years later a small, independent developer working alongside series creator Ryo Mizuno gave us Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth.

And I loved every minute of it.

The best way I can describe this game is if Record of Lodoss War had a baby with Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, but was having an affair with Ikaruga on the side. I had an absolute blast from beginning to end with this game and could not put it down. The silky-smooth animations, addicting Metroidvania/Ikaruga hybrid gameplay, and the wonderful soundtrack had me engaged throughout the entire experience. Even the story was superbly presented, and all of the original Lodoss War cast made appearances.

If there are any negatives about the game is that it is CRIMINALLY short. I beat the game getting 100% of the Labyrinth in 4 and a half hours. Also, the difficulty is on the easy side, with really the only challenge being in the boss battles which is where the Ikaruga spirit-switching gameplay really tests your reflexes.

I absolutely LOVED Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth and did not want it to end. Aside from the length, this is one of the best Metroidvania games ever made. Record of Lodoss War deserves more attention in the world of video games, and hopefully this game is enough of a success to get us a sequel or more titles in the universe. For the price this game is a steal, and I highly recommend picking it up if you are a fan of Metroidvania games, the Record of Lodoss War universe, or just adventure games in general.
