Graphics / Animation: Good.
Sound:  Some sound good, could have been better.
Bosses: Dark Souls levels of 'git-gud'
Music: Awesome! Its like a nice blend of Castlevania and Mischief makers.
Game Duration: Fair, but it could have been alot longer, perhaps add a second section to explore. The bow, other than used for puzzle solving, ends up underused since magic  takes good care of the enemies.
Story: The story ends up being severely lacking and doesn't go very deep in detail, however as you progress through the game, bits and pieces are revealed. There are two moments where the plot is twisted around unexpectedly.  The cut-scenes could have been better since its just minor movement and text, but despite its lacking, it does a fair job explaining the story.
I'd give this game a 7/10. I hope to see a sequel that further improves what you guys made, or better yet a sequel going into detail about Deed, her friends, and her world.

95204341.review:
If you have played any Team Ladybug/Krobon Station game before, you pretty much know what you are getting into. In other words, Record of Lodoss War: Deelit in Wonder Labyrinth is a fantastic one of those metroidvanias. Deedlit's sprite even looks like Alucard from Castlevania: Symphony of the Night. At times, it is quite easy though, as it is very easy to get healed. Still fun as hell though. 5/5

Pros:
 + Pixel. Art. If seeing the game in action does not make you say things like: "This isn't pixel art, this is wizardry!" or "It looks so pretty that I pooped my pants!", then congratulations! You have brain damage!
 + The map design. It is a bit more linear than typical metroidvanias. But at the same time there are meaningful secrets that are cleverly hidden. Getting stuck or lost is hard.
 + Boss and enemy design. There is very little repetition and most battles are very well designed.
 + Soundtrack is so good that listening to it should be mandatory in schools. Children need to know what the definition of the word 'cool' is.

Cons:
 - The plot was there just as an excuse to fight monsters and bad guys. As someone who was not familiar with Record of Lodoss War, I still do not really know what is special about it.
 - It is sometimes hard to see what is going on with all the explosive spectacle and wondrous beauty going on the screen. What a tough life.

94636818.review:
Solid little Metrodvania, if a bit short.

*The Pros*:

- Very nice sprite work. The characters and enemies move fluidly, animations pop nicely. Weapons looks cool.

- The background visuals can be nice and some of the Dragon bosses are a real treat.

- Soundtrack is great. Clearly inspired by SOTN, but that's ok.

- Neat little conceit using an Ikaruga-like elemental system to absorb enemy attacks. The idea is solid and could be fleshed out a bit more. Easily breaks the game in ways, however.

- Spells are cool, nicely animated and feel good. They end up being a bit overpowered later in the game however.

*Cons*:

- Map is rather small, but that's not implicitly a bad thing. However, the level design leaves a bit to be desired. Nothing feels terribly inspired. The arrow puzzles seem promising at first, but they don't really make them super elaborate. The world does not seem very cohesive like it would in a better Metroidvania. There aren't enough secrets and breakable walls.

- Missed opportunity to bank on the source material. What's there is pretty thin.

- Weapon selection is nice, but ultimately pointless. You switch up to the next strongest weapon constantly, there are artificial constraints put on some weapons like the Chakra, to keep them from proc'ing too often (i.e. making them interesting). The movesets are really limited; no street-fighter style special moves in sight unique to each weapon or innate ones Deedlit might have.

- The million different kinds of bows seem largely useless.

- The abilities you gain are very mundane. Very little creativity to be found.

- The inventory system is just plain bad. There's no reason consumable items should share the same slot as magic. Scrolling through the list on the fly feels really off and trying to use items immediately in the heat of battle often results in going make to the ability selection menu.

*Consensus*:

Definitely worth giving it a spin. Despite impressions to the contrary, I think the positives largely outweigh the negatives.

As a proof of concept, it really makes me excited to see what this team will be capable of with a bit more money and time.

7.5/10

94594678.review:
Record of Lodoss War: Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth is a metroidvania based on the ancient anime and novels of the same name. You may be wondering whether you need to be familiar with the source materials to enjoy this, and the answer is not really. You'll have absolutely no clue who anyone is or what on earth they're talking about, but it's a metroidvania – these aren’t really games that benefit from an in depth plot and you can mostly just skip past it. Don't be tempted to read the novels or watch the anime - even when I watched it over 20 years ago it was painfully generic, and the novels were literally some guy's D&D campaign with the serial numbers filed off. 

In terms of how it plays, we're basically looking at Symphony of the Night, again. The main twist in the formula is an ikaruga style colour switch between wind and fire - being in one element will allow you to absorb attacks of the same type, and changing on the fly is required to survive the game's many boss fights. If you're familiar with Touhou Lunar Nights this is very similar, though Deedlit never reaches the utter bullet hell chaos of that game. However, the boss fights are still rather messy affairs that I sometimes beat basically by accident by mashing the attack button and spamming magic while a thousand projectiles filled the screen.

Despite the chaotic boss fights Deedlit in Wonder labyrinth is a pretty sterling example of the genre being extremely pretty, well designed and paced. It is a rather short game, taking me around 6 hours to 100% while only having to consult a guide once for a particular item (the only developer troll in the game, needing the player to jump on a particular floor panel 50 times – why?). This means that the map is compact, pace is very brisk and there’s no time to get bored. While I wouldn’t put it up there with the absolute best in the genre, if you fancy something pretty and fun that you can complete in a couple of evenings, I’d say it’s hard to go too far wrong with Deedlit in Wonder labyrinth.

94523282.review:
I was really looking forward to this game. I really liked Tohou Luna Nights and I was hoping I would enjoy this game as much as Tohou Luna Nights, if not more. Unfortunately, this is definitely a tier below Touhou Luna Nights. It's still a good game though.

In RoLW, you have a melee attack, a magic attack, and a ranged attack. The melee attack is standard in any Metroidvania game, and the type of attack depends on the weapon you have equipped. The magic attack freezes time when you cast it and the attack covers a large area (sometimes outright homing in on enemies). It also does a lot of damage. Obviously, to balance it, it costs MP. The ranged attack is unique in that you can freely aim it. This comes into play in "puzzles" where you have to shoot your arrows in a way that causes them to ricochet exactly as you need in order to hit a trigger. In battle, this allows the ranged attack to be flexible as you can hit enemies above and below you. Of course, you can also just rapid fire the ranged attack without aiming and you'll hit whatever is straight in front of you. Of course, the ranged attack also costs MP in order to keep it balanced.

While the above attacks are more or less standard in most Metroidvania games, what's unique about RoLW is that you also have a spirit gauge. You can switch between a wind spirit and a fire spirit instantaneously whenever you want. Attacks in wind mode causes enemies to drop fire orbs and attacks in fire mode cause enemies to drop wind orbs. Collecting enough orbs increases the spirit gauge, up to level 3. A higher spirit gauge means higher damage. Taking damage reduces the spirit gauge by 1. Having a spirit equipped will cause all your attacks (except magic) to deal that spirit's type as damage. In addition, any enemy attack that matches the spirit that you have equipped will be completely negated. 

What's cool about this system is the risk reward element of it. You see, an enemy that uses fire attacks is likely weak to wind damage. That means that you can either play it safe and attack the enemy in fire mode, or you can attack in wind mode and be skillful enough to switch to fire when it attacks, and then switch back to wind. It should also be noted that some enemy attacks have no element or are an element other than wind/fire (e.g. light, dark, earth, water, etc…). This requires you to really learn enemy patterns and what type of elements they attack with, since getting hit not only damages you, but it also reduces your spirit gauge which you then painstakingly have to refill. I like this system as it rewards flawless gameplay and punishes mistakes without relying on annoying 1 hit kill mechanics.

The game does a great job of making everything really flashy. The game already looks great in my opinion, with an art style that I particularly like. However, the developers go the extra mile with all types of additional effects. Getting to level 3 spirit gauge has a very audible sound cue and the gauge flashes at level 3. The double jump and high jump have a cool animation to them. Hell the game overall is beautifully animated. The game overall looks really good in both its art and animation, which makes the game really fun to experience.

Now, let's move onto the negatives:
	• The game is too short: You can beat this game in like 4 hours……… that's too short. I am all for quality over quantity, but there needs to be a balance here. 
	• The progression system isn't exciting: I feel this is a byproduct of the game being too short. While you can find HP and MP ups and new melee, ranged, and magic weapons, it doesn't feel very exciting. This is because you get a new weapon like every 10 minutes. So who cares if you got a weapon that deals more damage? You know you're going to get another one really quickly. It's not like there's any synergy between items, so there's no item that you're ever specifically looking for. 
	• The game is too easy: This game is way too easy, and what's sad is that it could've been so easily fixed. You see, when your spirit gauge reaches 3, you regenerate health passively………. This was a really bad idea. This combined with the fact that you can gain spirit by attacking bosses at range (through either your arrows or your magic) means if you ever get low on health, you can simply run away from a boss and kite them and wait until you recover all your health before going back into melee range. There were so many bosses that I had no business beating because I got hit like at least 10 times, but I beat them on the 1st try because the HP regen is way too generous. What's sad is that this could've easily been fixed by simply NOT having your HP regen at spirit gauge level 3.

There's a story, but I can tell you're not going to appreciate it if you're not a fan of the related light novel/anime. This is because there's absolutely no character development done. You play as Deedlit who wakes up in a mysterious area, and she needs to escape. Various characters are introduced throughout the game, but they're introduced as if I am supposed to know who they are. Like "EMPEROR BELD!!!!" Who? Hell, I don't even really know who Deedlist is. The fundamental story revolves around the love that Deedlit has around this "Parn" guy, which is apparently behind this entire world. The problem is that this "love" is not shown in the game at all. I am simply supposed to accept that Deedlit and Parn love each other. Welp, this is a problem because I don't accept it (because I haven't seen any of it) and so any of the emotional moments fall completely flat.

Overall, while I had fun with this game, I was disappointed with how short and easy it was. I would love to play this game if a Hard mode is released where they get rid of the HP regen so that I can at least appreciate the bosses more.

94399989.review:
Record of Lodoss War: Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth is one of the worst professionally designed metroidvania I've played for some time, though metroidvania should really be used as "metroidvania". It's a game based on an old Japanese fantasy novel series created for an RPG styled on D&D and mostly known to the western audience through the anime and manga that adapted its story. As obscure as the franchise is these days the game does a not particularly good job of conveying its backstory in an appropriate manner to newer audiences. Mostly you get the gist of what is going on in the game but you're hard-pressed to ever care about Deedlit or the rest of her crew or why you're there in the first place.

This, though, isn't the biggest issue with the game, it's ultimately minor compared to the others. I'm not a big fan of "It-was-all-a-dream" stories or even stories where I don't care too much about the characters if the gameplay is solid then I can easily forget the plot. But it's an indication of just how wrong-headed this game is designed from start to finish. Before I start with my main issues I just have to mention the positives, which are the soundtrack which is really nice, the visual which are beautiful pixel art graphics, and in general, the engine this game is running on that reminds you of Symphony of the Night or similar games and usually handles really well.

When you start out you don't realize this but the level design is really terrible. Every area is really just a couple of rather uniform, non-descript corridors until you reach the next boss, something that is repeated ad nauseam until you reach the end of the game. You meet a couple of cool-looking enemies along the way but soon everything will just feel the same. Yes, the graphics are quite nice to look at but still, every area looks really so generic and it would be difficult to express for each area what its theme and unique aspects are except what you see on the most surface level. The Castlevania metroidvania after which this is fashioned occasionally suffered from this too but from Symphony of the Night through Circle of the Moon and until Order of Ecclesia, each and every one of them had many areas with unique and distinct features that I remember the games and their levels even years after.

This leads to the second problem, which is just how forgettable the overall level structure is. This is the same problem with the levels on the macro level. Most metroidvania create a world that feels like a real place with lots and lots of memorable areas be it SR388 or Dracula's everchanging castle or Hallownest. The maps of these places themselves are something fun to explore and remember. Record of Lodoss War doesn't have that, the overall shape of its world is just a random blob with lots of small corridors thoughtlessly clustered together.

It doesn't stop there though. Since the game is basically a barely hidden boss-rush where you survive a few corridors until the next one, it should have at least well-designed bosses, right. Wrong. Every boss fight is a puzzle, two glass cannons trading shots until you figured out what you have to do to win. A good boss fight is one where you can use your skill to evade boss attacks, find the right pattern and attack yourself. Bosses here move so extremely fast that you can't do this. It leads to most boss fights feeling extremely gimmicky where you have to figure out how to beat them but executing that isn't satisfying and becomes tiresome after some time.

Something that isn't just restricted to boss fights but becomes really annoying there is the stun effect that can hit you and leave you unable to do anything for a couple of seconds. Often the seconds you need to survive. There's hard and then there's unfair and the stun effect feels mostly like a punishing, unfair mechanic that downgrades the whole experience of fighting those bosses, who already aren't well designed. It's like adding insult to injury and makes me want to strangle whoever designer on the team thought this was a good idea in the first place and everybody else who hasn't yet patched this terrible thing out.

The rest is minor, the whole system adapted from bullet-hell shmups with the absorption of blue or orange bullets is neat but ultimately becomes just as tiresome as some of the other aspects of the game. Same with the gears that you have to hit with arrows to move. The game has a lot of compelling ideas on the surface that in practice are flogged to death so that you don't want to see them anymore but they really pale in comparison to the other flaws of the game.

One thing to add is that this is tagged and usually talked about as a metroidvania and it honestly barely functions as one. Yes, it has a large, interconnected castle to explore and you get a couple of new upgrades to get past some obstacles but backtracking in the game is relatively minor. The only reason to ever go back to earlier areas is for some weapons that you don't need anyway and a few minor bonuses. It's technically a metroidvania while disregarding the spirit of metroidvania where exploration is king and one of the most compelling activities you can do in-game. This game has almost zero exploration and almost zero other reasons to play it. Just play any of the myriad better metroidvania out there before you try this.

94312743.review:
100% map, level 99, all items (except for that nutty bow), and all powers and upgrades.

Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth is a stylish game that's both fun and unique, introducing mechanics into the genre that I'll surely look for in future metroidvania games. The gameplay is smooth, and it feels just as good to fight as it does to move as it does to explore. Upgrades focusing on improving your mobility, which makes the play feel more fluid and lends a concrete sense of progress. While playing I found myself pausing frequently to run, jump, dash, and generally move, as doing so was rewarding and fun.

For fans of the Record of Lodoss War series you'll be excited to see the attention to detail given to the game, such as Deedlit's gliding, the gateway between worlds ("Fom alanis katoru!"), and the weapons that can be discovered throughout the labyrinth. The story of this game builds off the books/anime, but has a personal emphasis on Deedlit's character, giving us an opportunity to witness a pivotal moment of her life that gives us enough time to appreciate what is going on without suffocating the player in cutscenes, dialogue, etc.

Bosses themselves offer a fresh experience, nothing is stale, and while the fights themselves were on the easy side, each battle was one that I enjoyed, and looked forward to facing. Quality and uniqueness over difficulty was the route chosen, and I greatly appreciated this choice. 

Music and art were top notch, too. The music did a phenomenal job of setting the tone while the art of each stage, of each enemy, and of your character had me pausing to enjoy what I was playing frequently. The after-effects on Deedlit's motion, the crisp animations from battles, and the communication of information through art and color was excellent, and left me satisfied once the game was complete.

Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth is a fantastic game, and I will definitely be back to play it again in the future.

94222419.review:
Most boss fights can be trivialized (OP invisibility), and cheesing common mobs becomes the safest approach. Many rooms are filled with mobs in either repetitive or cramped fashion. Enemies and projectiles will often kick you outside of a room, which resets the entire room. The invincibility time after getting hit does not prevent you from being bullied to the point where you can't move anymore. The smallest dagger you obtain near the end hits harder than any two-handed sword you found earlier -- but you still need 3-10 hits per mob. Some tough paths lead to a merchant or a locked door (later "shortcut") instead of an actual game objective or reward. The story telling is obscure at best, you'd better know the novel already. 
There are also cool mechanics, the pixel art is nice, I liked the soundtrack... but the end feels so badly rushed. Nowhere near as good as Touhou Luna Nights in my opinion; I was expecting more from the early access version.

93884768.review:
This is a typical post-metroid game precisely in the igavania sub-genre. It’s very concise, though, the runtime is not that long and there are no three or more surprise twist world swaps doubling or tripling the game size. There are no premature endings and the game doesn’t ask you to find a walkthrough just to see how to get half of the content hidden behind a moon logic secret.

The gameplay is perfectly fine, but there are a lot of things present only as token mechanics. Ledge-dropping introduced on the second screen is never used again. The store is useless, the best things it sells are medkits and energy drinks. None of these weapons can compete with basic things you will find essentially right outside the store. There are very few locations and almost all of them are in inconvenient places, so you will rarely see the shopkeeper anyway. Also the prices of shop-weapons are so high you can’t even grind enemies at any reasonable pace. So, basically, the store is only for medkits if you are not very good at the game. I ever went shopping for them only for a couple of specifically spammy bosses, including the final one. The archery is pointless. Without a proper mouse aim, you can’t properly hit anything that is not directly in front of you. You can enter the aim mode, but it’s so bad and inconvenient you should forget about shooting on the move or trying to catch a moving target. The damage is so pathetic it’s not worth it. But the bow is still used pretty often for the puzzles. Mostly it’s okay but any bow-puzzle involving movement is rather irritating. The spent ammo is directly subtracted from your mana and you can run out of it by trying to solve a crucial moving puzzle. The archery mini-game highlights all that is bad with not having a proper mouse aim. (But thankfully it runs on pure maths.) This very same semi-6-directional semi-aim makes most melee weapons very situational, so in general, i only used the swords with half-circle swing arcs. Hitting flyers with the diagonal directional weapons’ strikes that make you walk is really hard. And there are a lot of flyers. On top of it the official Microsoft gamepad is quite bad at diagonals. Also, the attack direction is sticky. If you are striking to the right you can’t just turn around and start striking to the left. You have to perform a full stop and let the elf chill. The necessity rarely arises, but when it does it’s irritating.

The game heavily relies on magic. Once you learn how to read the resists on enemy life bars, it’s much easier to just spam something effective instead of trying to catch the pesky parasites with your low-damage sword. I wiped the floor with the boss rush room. Yet if someone didn’t master the elements, that can be quite challenging. But generally, if you stumble upon a boss being cancer you can bring 10 life potions with you. The GUI for healing is a part of the crooked spell-wheel which is cancer, but with 500 additional HP even the really tough spots are manageable. Though, you might have to grind pennies a lot if you can’t master any boss at the beginning of the game. Starting with the fourth stage even common rooms start to be assembled in a really challenging way and generic enemies start to spam attacks filling half of the screen with projectiles. Later stages are quite challenging even with the max-out HP bar. The last area has only one non-boss save-point, and it’s very far from the previous one. Still, it’s doable due to the colour-coding mechanic. Making half of the enemies immune to your real-time strikes is generally not that good of an idea. Especially when mixing both types in one fight. But in this game, the right colour makes you as well immune to some attacks, and if you max out the blue or the orange spirit it will start to regenerate your health. So by playing slowly, keeping one colour as sacrificial and the other one as emergency healing between fights you can break through end-game corridors filled with dragons and dinosaurs. Shadow stalkers are still cancer and a waste of time, though. And the levelling system where you don’t make any decisions is utterly superfluous. Though, if you are absolutely bad at the game you can grind easy-to-kill enemies for weeks to hit the level-cap of 99 and have more raw damage for the part you are stuck on.

The animations are quite good, but the faux pixel-art is irritating. It’s a mix of pixel-built elements with just low-res jarring traditional jpegs and unfitting visual effects of different resolution. It’s like those old PS1 non-3D graphics which are not here nor there. You don’t have to have stupid low-res graphics to have a good game. Bloodstained is a great game without making you feel like a caveman. And the eye and fonts from the menu and cut-scenes are the worst. The music is really screwed up too. It sounds like it was speed-up 30% for some reason. I really thought it’s something wrong on my end. Even the sounds of the protagonist are borked. She sounds like a dude trying to pitch up his voice in post.

Story-wise she is journeying in some metaphysical purgatory or something, trying to escape her cycles of guilt. The writing is abrupt and cryptic. Somehow the guy is dead and she has to learn to forgive herself. But the last thing i saw is them both lovebirds riding into the sunset.
[b]И тут котёнок проснулся.[/b]
It doesn’t matter, the plot is redundant in this game, just as the whole setting. You can reskin it to any other IP and it will be the same game. There are no breakthrough innovative mechanics, it’s just a solid game in itself even despite the flaws. And it’s the best game of the year because this is the first game released this year that is worth anything. As for me, it is worth the full price.

It was a lot of fun and I really enjoyed the chakram weapons and using invisibility to cheese through human bosses. 

Definitely worth picking up if you want a solid metroidvania with really good gameplay mechanics.

93737409.review:
Positives:
- No palette swapped enemies
- Beautiful sprite work
- Unique battle features to the battle system (if you're familiar with bullet hell shooters that should clue you in)
- No padding; 100% content
- There's an archery minigame I'm not seeing get any attention that's a nice little breakup. Won't distract you for too long unless you're a competionist but still good.
- A nice amount of challenge; not disheartening 

Neutral
- Pretty linear game despite being a "metroidvainia". You'll be rewarded for doing so, with more powerful weapons and spells, but you won't need to rethread old grounds once you "complete" an area. There won't be some "thing" easily missed on the first playthrough that will unlock an upside down castle or the "true" ending.  Some will appreciate this while others may feel it's a staple of the genre. 
- There's an optional spell you can get halfway through that let's you cheese a lot of the enemies and character sized bosses. There's also a sword that can supplement it making it even more breaking. They're nowhere near as bad as Alucard shield, but it's just a peeve of mine and I realize it's a personal issue and not necessarily a flaw. 


Negatives:
- The shop is underutilized (though I could argue the same for SOTN) and unless you do zero exploration the weapons you'd buy will be a short lived upgrade.
- With the lack of need for money, the gambling game feels a bit wasted. If you're the completionist type that needs every item this is a godsend; otherwise skip it. 

Overall:
The length of the game as others have mentioned doesn't really feel like a detriment, as what's there feels pretty fulfilling. If anything, it leaves me hopeful that there will be a sequel where they expand on the ideas they have here. In the end, I feel like it's money well spent.

93680759.review: I recommend this game if and only if it is on sale. The game has amazing sprite work, good artistic design on the areas, and serviceable combat. It did feel rewarding to go back and explore old areas which is critical for a good metroidvania. All in all, I did enjoy my experience with the game. However, I simply cannot recommend that someone pay twenty dollars for a game that only occupies them for less than four hours before the story is finished. That is not me trying to speed through the game as quickly as possible. Four hours was my run time while also trying to 100% the map. This is a good metroidvania, but there are far more economical ones out there like Bloodstained or Hollow Knight. I am leaving a positive score on this game because I believe that it was certainly crafted well and I wish to encourage developers who actually put love and artistry into their games, but keep in mind that you are getting very little content for what you are paying.

93660457.review:
---Negatives---
- Shop is useless. Didn't spend a single cent the entire game. Weapons better than the ones at the store are easily found through natural progression, and I would imagine potions are useless seeing as Level 3 heals you anyway, 
- Some enemy placement is cheap, such as flying enemies (that aren't even spirits) that can just pass through walls and hover outside the map and shoot projectiles at you, 
- Map layout is uninspired, linear, and lacks mystery. No emphasis on exploration or backtracking which is a core element of a game with the tag "Metroidvania", otherwise it's just a platformer, 
- Short. Started at lunch and finished before dinner,  
- Forgettable music. Just background noise, 
- No puzzles which are, again, a core element to Metroidvanias, 
- Adding achievements after release makes it force a second playthrough. Cheap replayability, 
- Lacks any excitement or danger, leaving it feel like a hollow experience after the credits roll, 
- It's 2021. Metroidvanias have evolved to include things like map markers. Why hasn't this? 

---Positives---
- Art and character designs are great, 
- Smooth and precise controls, 
- Eyegasm to a fellow animator, 
- Element-swapping mechanic was a good idea (even if it was their only original one) 

---Summary---
Eh. The gameplay and handling are there, but it's not really "fun" per se. Switch your brain off and kill a few hours, but it lacks any excitement or danger which leaves you feeling empty after the credits. The developer stuck to everything traditional without leaving their own mark on the genre, making it quite generic content-wise. They just went through the motions which basically makes it feel like they just followed a recipe without experimenting, which is a shame because it looks good. Despite so many negative points, it's worth a playthrough once just to appreciate the quality of animation.

93449173.review:
Record of Lodoss War: Wonder Labyrinth is by far one of my top games of the year, but not without it's faults.  I love so much about this game- and fun fact, Masahiro Sakurai has even played it and loves it!

[h1] Story & About (Spoiler Free)[/h1]

In Wonder Labyrinth, you play as an elf girl who wakes up in a 'labyrinth' who's goal is to simply, just escape.  Upon further exploration, you find friends and enemies from your past, both of which are there to help and hurt you.  The game doesn't seem to be as ambitious or fleshed out as SOTN, Hollowknight, Metroid Dread, or other Metroidvanias in it's catagory, but its still a must play nonetheless.

The game takes HUGE inspiration from Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, going as far as to have Deedlit (the main character) replicate the exact running animation of Alucard from SOTN.  The graphics are also almost an exact recreation.  Swords, leveling, map design, boss fights, and even the UI are glorious recreation of SOTN.. right down to the same BACK DASH of Alucard.  The game seems to be an intentional TRIBUTE to SOTN and not a knockoff.  The graphics/pixel art are beautiful. 

I haven't watched the anime or read the manga but that didn't dampen my play-through at all.  I'll admit, I didn't know or care about the characters upon first seeing them, but toward the end I felt connected to each one as if I've been a fan from day one.  I do have an interest in checking out the manga/anime after this play-through.

You do not need to know the source material to enjoy this game.

[h1] Small Nit Picks [/h1]

Small complaints I did have with the game is that you as a character, are grossly overpowered.  You're an elf girl who has access to a Sword and Bow, but you can also Fly, use magic, become invincible, slide, Double Jump (and even extend your Double Jump), and regenerate health- and you gain all of these powers within the first 5 minutes of the game... and a handful of weapons in which seems like the first 3 rooms.  You also meet the shopkeeper in the first 5 minutes of the game, which was hours in SOTN when compared to it. 

The bosses also seem to be too easy as well, as just spamming the sword attack seems to win the fight majority of the time.  Further through the game, you even obtain a magic spell called, "SHADE", which allows you to become invincible for about 5 seconds.. all of which you can still attack.  Using this spell I was able to beat bosses without a challenge.   I also wish the map was more fleshed out with more exploring similar to that of SOTN.  Far too many times the game seemed to finish a boss fight.. only to give me the exact weapon I need to enter another boss fight 3 rooms later.  The game is a metroidvania, but at times it seems VERY linear with no places to get lost or explore.  The game tends to give you exactly what you need when you need it.

There are small gimmicks such as switching from your attacks from WIND to FIRE and some enemies/bosses being immune to one or the other, but majority of the time I just used this 'elemental switch' to regenerate health' in the heat of battle.


[h1] Music [/h1]

The music in Wonder Labyrinth surprised me.  A few times I had to pause and turn up the music, as it immersed me with the story and characters.  Here's a track below that plays after you run through the labyrinth in desperate search of someone in one of the later levels.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XY9t-finmRU

For an anime I knew nothing about and characters I could of cared less about.  Record of Lodoss War Wonder Labyrinth, is a 8.5/10 for me.  I will be checking out the anime and manga on this one.  And I definitely will be playing it again

93372143.review:
This is a solid metroidvania. The art is great, the sound design is nice, and the gameplay is fun. I do feel that to get anything out of the story the player needs to have some external knowledge of  the source material of Record of Lodoss War. A common complaint I heard about this game is its length. While true, it is on the shorter side, I'm okay with that. I got about 6-7 hours of gameplay as I searched the map for hidden stuff. (It will say 8 on my review because I left the game idle at times). 

For a game on sale at 15.99, I think that's fine. The game can also be really easy with the magic you can get and usage of health items. I, personally, did not use any health or magic regeneration items once just to challenge myself, and I did make the game more exciting for me (it also didn't feel unfair or much of a handicap to not have resupply items). The way you get health back is quite generous which makes health items unnecessary to me. However, if you do use regeneration items, the game becomes too easy. 

Overall, this is an 8/10 for me. I bought it at a sale and I happily recommend it  to those who are curious to do so  if the short run time is a concern. If the game feels too easy, you are not ruining it for yourself if you do not use regeneration items, in my opinion, that makes it more fun.

93139630.review: A very good metroidvania with great mechanics, level design, enemies and large boss battles. It also has a surprising number of characters, nice pixel art and a good soundtrack to. The map is large and each new area offers a new challenge. I found myself changing weapons and abilities often to combat different enemies and bosses. The bow puzzles are also a nice addition. It also has it's own elemental system, although you mainly switch between a wind state and a fire state. In the fire state you can absorb fire attacks which restore mana and keep you safe. 93136021.review:
Pros:
- It's Record of Lodoss War
- Great Audio
- Solid movement and combat
- Gorgeous environments and VFX

Cons
- The UI. I cannot comprehend how the UI somehow regressed from Touhou Luna Nights. It's like their UI/UX designer just does. not. care. about a decent experience.
- Controller layout, again UI/UX. Why would I ever make A attack and B jump, it's like you saw BotW controls and thought, "I can make that even less convenient." 
- Air/Fire swap. You can either float or be effective. Boss fights eventually get this Ikaruga swap action, but it's so hard to differentiate between which power you are currently using when a lot is happening on the screen. E.X. The Air/Fire Spirit boss fight.
- Also why does Air/Fire have "Levels"? Other than to hit stack to 3 so you can get health regen. If the level lowers you need to switch elements and kill enemies to gain back levels for the opposite elements, which becomes real obnoxious when you just need to float but the monster is immune to air, so you are forced to switch elements... it just becomes tedious fairly quick. 


The story here is very niche to Lodoss War fans, I'm a little rusty on lore and I found it impossible to follow along, and therefore care. 

I would recommend this for 10$ or less, it's an decent, level based metroidvania if you are hungry for the genre.

93089149.review:
This is overall another solid metroidvania from team ladybug.

I know nothing about Record of Lodoss War; only really hearing about it in passing and unfortunately unlike Touhou Luna Nights, team ladybugs previous game this feels a fair bit more reliant on knowledge of the series to get full enjoyment of this. Thankfully the game itself is fun enough that not knowing won't ruin the experience.

 [h1]The Good[/h1]

Once more team ladybug knocks it out of the park with the sprite work, even when tackling what is a considerably different and more conventional style compared to the chibier style used in Synchronicity and Luna Nights. The visuals express everything rather clearly to the player with no overly ambiguous gameplay elements that hit you out of nowhere. The controls are tight and responsive which helps the platforming and general navigation of the game feel incredibly enjoyable. Enemy variety is rather large with a lack of many repeating enemy types making each zone feel fresh. The Ikaruga style switching elements is used well in both the combat and general exploration introducing some very interesting combat and platforming challenges. The equipment system [strike]Ripped straight from SOTN[/strike] introduces some light customizability changing the way you play with every new weapon. The element system makes the game a bit less of a just mash the attack button the whole game to kill everything as you may need to switch per enemy to get damage off or enhance your damage. The magic adds into this introducing more elements to play around with and exploit. The level design is a big step up from luna nights with a lot more interesting exploration and navigation and a bit more of that classic metroidvania old area revisiting for new things previously locked off. 

[h1]The Bad[/h1]

Game is an absolute joke difficulty wise which was rather disappointing coming off of the challenging but rewarding luna nights. Every single boss can be very easily brute forced just by running up to them and mashing the attack button or taking pot shots with the bow from across the stage in complete safety. A lot of puzzles can be easily exploited either by just taking hits to skip it with iframes in the the damage based ones or standing directly in the door to shoot the gear without rebounds in the bow ones. Speaking of the bow puzzles while interesting they are often times frustrating as some require very specific positioning and shots to get which is just annoying. 

[h1]The Meh[/h1]
Music was pretty standard across the board. While far from bad I can't say I recall any of the tracks after playing and it mostly just fell into the background. The story is obviously very reliant on knowledge of record of lodoss war. While you are given a very short intro (hero kill bad guy, girl love hero) no information is given on any of these other characters or even the main character besides that she loves the hero. The bonus 100% map ending is especially confusing as it seems to maybe tie into a newer series but my unfamiliarity leaves me thinking what as opposed to surprise. The element levelling system is rather underbaked. It is interesting in concept and encouraging not eating hits to keep it up is nice but it is far too easy to keep up where it counts in bosses and losing it is barely a punishment considering how quickly you can get it back. The mini games are largely ehhhhhhhhh; just kind of existing to either get a mid tier bow or get way too much money that you will never need. Speaking of the shop; it's fine. Adds little besides making an easy game easier. 

On the whole this is another really solid release from team ladybug who is quickly becoming one of my favorite developers. While I prefer touhou luna nights on the whole this game was still very solid and a step up in a lot of other areas compared to that game, primarily level design.

Good stuff 8/10

93063103.review:
Team Ladybug knows what they are doing with the basics of a Metroidvania-like game.  This and Touhou compliment each other quite well, and both are great representations of their collective ability.

Lodoss War's big gameplay hook is the IKARUGA-style polarity switch, which is mostly used for combat and just a little bit of platforming.  It gets implemented quite well in boss fights, and I would say it's the game's biggest draw.

One hangup I have with the overall design of TLB's Metroidvania games is the map being so lumped together.  It's just a big block of a map and the areas aren't really defined by any sort of thought-out layout.  I wish the areas had been spaced out more instead of being fit together like a giant Tetris piece.

Graphically, the game is a stunner.  The 2D pixel art here is wonderful and is eye-catching.  It's all a love letter to Symphony of the Night, if anything, but it's done very well.  

Musically, maybe two tracks from the game stand out, which is a bit of a disappointment.  Nothing bad, but nothing phenomenal.

The game will take seasoned action game fans about 5-7 hours to finish, which might seem brief, but I'd say the game benefits from not overstaying it's welcome.

I like the Ikaruga style mechanics of switching between Wind and Fire to protect against Wind and Fire attacks respectively. 92758751.review:
Leveling in this game doesn't mean shit. By grinding from level 25 to 85 in one area I increased my damage from 140 to 200, which sounds like a bit at least, but doesn't change the fact that I'd still need exactly 2 hits to kill the exact enemy I was grinding the entire time. Defense increase feels like more, but the insane amount of knockback which enemies inflict will make you feel like even more of a loser than just straight up getting one-shot. There's also nothing to make the grind interesting. You just find the mathematically most optimal (xp per second) room to reenter repeatedly and off you go. The big payoff of doing this though never comes.

Combat is basic. You mostly just switch between defending while being unable to deal damage and dealing damage while being unable to defend. There are other constellations of elemental damage and such but they don't really have much impact.

Story and Characters are thrown in your face without connecting any dots. I know that Lodoss is an ancient intellectual property but having such rough telling of plot points and character relations just makes me feel unwelcome.

The game really has its art going for it. Some things are kinda straight out of Symphony of the Night, but that's just good taste so I ain't complaining.

Overall feels kinda bad to give it a thumbs down, but the retro goggles can't only give.

92743755.review:
[quote][h1]Full review (including score): https://youtu.be/wKkgH67rx08
Summarized review below![/h1][/quote]
It’s not often that we get a new game based on a somewhat obscure 1990 anime and novel series, but here we are with exactly that in 2021.

[h2]Story:[/h2]
For those unfamiliar, Record of Lodoss War is a fantasy novel series that ran during the late 80s and early 90s. This game takes place after the original series and is a prequel to a new novel series written by the original author – set a full 100 years later. Despite that though, the game is designed to be welcoming to newcomers – and I myself fall into that category. However, if you’re going to be playing it for the story – there isn’t really much there in the first place. This is a much more gameplay-focused title and the story is mostly just random bits of dialogue before and after boss fights, just enough to provide the foundation to hold it all together.

[h2]Gameplay:[/h2]
Here you have a metroidvania with nice combat, cool abilities and upgrades, a bunch of different enemies and bosses, and a decent sense of exploration too. It’s divided into six stages, but takes place on one map that opens up as you gain access to new abilities. It is not the biggest map, but exploring it does yield some nice bonuses and as this is a metroidvania, there is some backtracking. The game does not go overboard with it though and there are teleporters that can get your around the map.

The overall gameplay avoids that feeling of repetition because you’re always entering some new area and encountering new enemies. Although it may only take 3-6 hours to beat, the experience is very well-paced and I never felt bored with it.

[h2]Combat:[/h2]
Combat has a bit of a unique spin to it as well. It’s divided into two “elements” that you can swap between at any time. Depending on the enemy type, one element may do more damage and it can also have an effect on movement. The two elements also have their own distinct level that grows as you defeat enemies with it and shrinks when you get hit. Having one at level 3 allows you to heal over time while using the other, so the game encourages you to swap between the two to maintain a decent HP pool.

It is a very cool system and makes the combat more than just another metroidvania hack and slash. That’s not to say that the core combat is bad though – it’s actually pretty nice. There’s ample combat feedback and you can aim your melee weapons in any direction. Experimentation is encouraged and you will find a variety of these different weapon types as you explore.

[h2]Graphics, Music, & Performance:[/h2]
The graphics are also good. It’s composed of some really detailed pixel art – the perfect fit for this type of gameplay and very reminiscent of Castlevania. The music is fine too, but I honestly can’t say I remember any of it now that I’ve cleared the game – so not something that left an impact on me. Performance-wise, the game is solid. I had no technical issues of any kind and my only complaint there is that the game is locked to 60 fps.

[h2]Overall:[/h2]
Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth is a short, yet fun metroidvania that emphasizes what makes the genre great. Polished combat, some nice exploration, a bunch of different enemy types and boss fights – it’s an easy recommendation for fans of that genre.

Follow my [b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/3215371]Steam Curator Page[/url][/b] for more reviews + videos!

92658485.review:
Maybe I went in with bad expectations, but this is surprisingly linear for a Metroidvania. A lot of times back tracking to explore feels like a chore, and you don't really get enough movement capabilities to help things move along.

Bosses seem to be easy enough, most went down just from spamming magic attacks. Although you do have to watch out for barely-visible attacks that could knock you around (and, in a couple of cases, stun lock you until dead).

Assuming that this is part of a series of works (and not just bad storytelling) I have no idea what's going on. It seems like I'm supposed to recognize a lot of characters that show up but never get introduced, which just makes the entire story feel really uninteresting unless you know what's going on.

The game has a couple good ideas, like the spirit swapping. When in Wind you get Fire energy (and vice-versa). Energy can raise your spirit level up to 3, which auto-heals you when at max. But if you get hit, it drops a level. This ends up being interesting enough, since when you get hit it now becomes a game of avoiding the *second* hit until you can get the other level raised.

Beyond that, I just kept waiting for the game to shake something up and give me a new experience, but it never happened. Every powerup was wholly predictable (ledge too high? Guess I wait for the Double Jump. Water? Guess I wait for water breathing) where so many other games surprised me with new tools to overcome obstacles.

92575101.review:
[h1]"Light and darkness are equals and where one exists, so too must the other."[/h1]

My exposure to Record of Lodoss War is limited. I have no reliable access to the books in my country, neither is the OVA or anime available for purchase. I discovered the series through a friend upon sharing to him an amv which made use of Kiseki no Umi, the opening song for Record of Lodoss War: Chronicles of the Heroic Knight.

Needless to say, once I discovered this game during a brief sale, I [i]had[/i] to play it. And so I did.

[b]About this game:[/b]
Record of Lodoss War - Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth, is a sequel to the initial series of novels and a prequel to Diadem of the Covenant, a sequel series of novels which follows Deedlit a hundred years following the original fable. It is a Metroidvania, which is one of my favorite genres following my exposure to a certain Castlevania game you may or may not be aware of.

The game follows Deedlit as she traverses a deadly new world where things are not quite as they seem. Old enemies return to hinder her journey, while old friends aid her on her way. As she slowly uncovers the hidden truths of the Labyrinth, she must face the reality she denies if she is ever to escape.

[b]My Experience:[/b]
Throughout my eight hour run, I had an absolute blast. The weapon variety, although small, was nonetheless enjoyable, the arrow puzzles did their job, enemy variety is [b]fantastic[/b] and the level design was alright. I loved the work that went into the sprites and animations, although some sprites were not as impressive as others [strike](Shooting Star chief among them)[/strike].

(Previously I mentioned that Shooting Star's sprite was unimpressive. While I feel it isn't as great as Narse, I don't think it's as unimpressive as I initially said it was.)

Navigating the map was fun and discovering little secrets here and there was a treat. However, I doubt I explored everything, certainly the main areas and spaces where I'd find an upgrade or two, but I feel I missed quite a bit, especially when I was nearing the final boss. Total tunnel vision on my part.

A lot of the bosses frustrated me. Let me be clear here, I beat the game with a keyboard with the magic/attack keys rebound to arrows and movement/ducking to WASD. My biggest issue with the bosses, is that not all of them have a noticeable opening. Pirotess is especially difficult in her second boss battle, not once during it did I feel like I could take advantage of her. Beside's Nihilim, I had the most trouble with her. Other than that, the boss battles are fun, challenging and rewarding, very pattern heavy.

Knowing the patters really does help and I did my best to notice them when I could, and strike when I found it. Enemies having weaknesses to certain spells or the type of spirit you attack with was a neat touch of D&D sweetness which just goes to show that even a Metroidvania can hearken back to Lodoss' roots. I thought that was a very good touch.

What got me most, was the length. I back tracked a lot, because I love exploration, so my hours are quite possibly inflated relative to the games actual length. It's shorter than I was expecting, which isn't unwelcome.

I also quite enjoyed the difficulty, challenging when it has to be, but decidedly forgiving. Sure, I felt overwhelmed in places but it's not like the odds were insurmountable.

The ending itself was very nice. Despite my lack of proper exposure, I am at least partially familiar with Deedlit's story and place within the series and it was enough to make me emotionally invested.

[b]Negatives[/b]
Once again, I didn't like how [i]some[/i] boss battles felt really cheap, or lacked a noticeable opening. A lot of the times I was spamming will'o the wisp, especially during the second Pirotess boss battle which I found incredibly tough. She's always on the move and immobilizing Deedlit and doesn't really pause long enough to take a hit.

MP stays roughly the game throughout a play through while health gets boosted quite a few times. Throughout my entire play through, I'd only leveled up my MP bar [b]once[/b]. The fact the shop keeper (Ghim) did not offer any upgrades for it was especially hurtful.

Speaking of Ghim, he's the shop keep. Now, he doesn't offer much. Better weapons as you progress and healing items are the best he's going to give you. I think the devs totally missed out on having him sell cool extra items like a talisman that will regenerate your MP faster, or collect more gold loot, or even a onetime use revive for when you fall during the second phase of a boss battle. He offers [i]nothing[/i] but the essentials but even then, that's a minor complaint.

A major complaint I have, however, is that the end of the final boss battle should come with an epilepsy warning. Flashing white lights as Deedlit's adventure is shown in green tinted stills is going to get somebody hurt.

A final issue to address, is that V-sync doesn't always work like it's supposed to. It happens on and off and becomes noticeable fairly easily.

[b]Closing thoughts:[/b]
I wish that Record of Lodoss War was easier to access in my country. For what it's worth, knowing what I know about Lodoss and its characters at least allowed me to follow along and even remember certain characters who I've known only through images on the internet (the wiki is an incomplete mess).

Playing as Deedlit is awesome, I've come to really like her and sympathize with her. I can see myself starting a fresh save and playing through again when the mood strikes me.

If you're new to the Lodoss War series and you're thinking this game would be a good start, I would reconsider. The game doesn't explain much about the events of the first series, nor does it go into detail about the book characters enough to be invested in them without prior knowledge of them and their story within the universe. However, the game can easily be played just as well without the context.

Classic Lodoss fans may enjoy what the game has to offer.

I know I certainly enjoyed what I got.

Might I add that the cover art is [b]stunning![/b]

Completion date: 25/5/2021.

92564827.review:
It would seem I fall into the category of having some previous experience (and attachment, if I'm to be honest) with the Lodoss franchise from... way too many years ago. While that in itself is not a pre-requisite, it definitely helps to elevate the experience, as the game pretty much carries the same feel across.

As a Metroidvania, it's a little on the light side, with a relatively short completion time, and lack of gameplay settings or extra modes. On the other hand, what you do get is pretty condensed and solid. A well crafted game with level design that hits the mark, fluid gameplay, beautiful audio-visuals, wide enemy variety and some fun, unique mechanics.

The English localisation does have some obvious dents to it, but we've all seen old-school arcade games from Japan with far worse, right?

I definitely recommend, IF you're aware of what you're getting into.
- If you're looking for the next genre-defining hit that every game is going to copy for 20 years, you'll most likely end up disappointed.
- If you're going for an enjoyable weekend afternoon romp with characters and a setting you know or outright cherish, this should be right up your alley.
- If you just like pretty games, it might be relevant to your interests.

Depending on your tastes, you can consider waiting for a sale. I don't regret the 13 quid I paid for it, at all.

92513972.review:
[i]Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth[/i] is a decent Lodoss-themed action platformer. At its core, the game gets everything right: movement feels nice, combat is well-balanced with interesting elemental mechanics, and the boss encounters offer bit of (moderate) challenge. The old-fashioned pixel graphics are quite nice, with good animation work on the lead character and decent diversity in the environments and antagonists. Even the story is an intriguing take on the Lodoss universe, with many references to the series and a fulfilling conclusion.

The main issue is that the whole thing seems to lack scope and ambition. Despite the "metroidvania" tag, the game is essentially linear in nature, rather short (5-7 hours) and generally on the easier side, with few secrets and virtually no side activites or sublplots. As such, it doesn't feel overpriced but sure leaves you wanting more, and makes you wonder what the studio could do on a higher budget. I'd love to see a more ambitious sequel in the future.

92495737.review:
Team Ladybug please make more, I'm begging you, I will give you all of my money.

Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth is a metroidvania inspired by Symphone of the Night, and just like their previous game, Luna Nights (which you should totally play btw it's a masterpiece), features tightly intertwined gameplay mechanics that seamlessly compliment each other. The gameplay itself is incredibly fun, movement is fluid, the difficulty progression is just right, only at one point in the game did I get mad at a room. The pixel art is top notch, the game is beautiful.

The only downside I can possibly think of is the fact that the game is 6-7 hours long if you wanna 100% the map, or less if you just rush through the game, but that doesn't mean that the areas are lackluster or that the game is empty. Instead of doing what most other metroidvanias do, as in, stretching the map out and having a lot of backtracking, this game concentrates all of the fun stuff into 6 compact levels.

Overall
Story: 8/10

Music and Atmosphere: 11/10 The music is just immaculate

This game is pretty good! If you enjoyed Touhou: Luna Nights, I would recommend this for sure, however the design of the map is noticeably less enjoyable than Luna Nights. On top of that, while the platforming is snappy and responsive, the combat doesn't do a good job of implementing it in the same way Luna Nights did. The boss battles are more about having the right weapon/magic whereas Touhou was more about balancing precision platforming with dealing damage (which I definitely enjoyed). Luna Nights is a bit more of a challenging and intense experience compared to this, which is a bit slower and more relaxed most of the time.

This game has a few great ideas, namely the "puzzles" (they're not logic puzzles whatsoever) that you do with the bow! I though they were really fun, but unfortunately there's only like 15 times in the whole game you use them and they're all really easy. There was definitely more potential for introducing the bow into combat, since it's relatively useless in boss battles.

As far as the story goes, similar to Luna Nights, it's not particularly deep or gripping, and most of the characters are literally incomprehensible due to the lack of any kind of exposition. Still, the story is pretty minimal, and I found this one a little more endearing than Luna Nights.

If you've played platformers before, you can easily finish this game in about 4 hours with no replayability value or post-game content. It's fun and neat, but I would only recommend picking it up on a sale or if you have money burning a hole in your pocket.

92385937.review:
Wow, Team Ladybug is quickly becoming one of my favorite Metroidvania developers.  Having finished Touhou, I decided to give this a try next. As much as I enjoyed Touhou, they improved upon almost every aspect of game play. The movement is much more fluid and precise.  The sprites are large and amazingly detailed. And I absolutely love the music and sound effects, very retro inspired.  I definitely got SOTN and Bloodstained vibes off this.

As others have said, this game is also on the shorter side like Touhou. However, there is so much content packed into it, you almost don't notice.  Tons of spells, swords, bows, and new abilities to discover. And many bosses - if you're a fan of boss battles in metroidvanias, then Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth will not disappoint. While not as difficult as some of the latter bosses in Touhou, they are still challenging, so be prepared to die a few times before mastering their patterns.

Besides the length of the game, I really can't find much wrong with it, I enjoyed it all around. Although I have never seen the anime it's based upon, I'm sure this would be an additional treat for fans, as there are lots of cameos from different characters. However, the game definitely stands on its own and doesn't require knowledge of the series. Again, kudos to the developers for a job well done!

92382027.review:
An absolute masterpiece of a video game that pays tribute to both one of the greatest games of all time "Castlevania: Symphony of the Night" that created a new genre of games known as "Metroidvenia" and the Japanese equivalent of Dungeons and Dragons (which itself began life as a bunch of japanese friends recorded their DnD campaigns) known as Record of Lodoss War. 

In case you never heard of, or understand what a Metroidvenia is; basically imagine a 2D platformer, now you add RPG elements, you are blasting enemies from screen to screen using various weapons and magic, getting XP and levelling up, and as you explore the map, you obtain abilities that will allow you to backtrack to previous areas to get to areas you could not before, either to obtain more abilities or weapons... or to progress the story. 

This game`s little gimmick, is the use of two elements, fire and ice that you need to constantly switch between, as having the right one turned on will allow you to completely ignore attacks or boost your own. This gimmick was previously by the same developers in the excellent "Shin Megami Tensei Synchronicity Prologue", which was released for free, as it was meant to be more of a joke game to troll fans, but I am pretty sure they started work on this project  when they saw how well received that game was.

The other unique mechanic, is that attacking with each element give you Charge level for the other element, once you reach max, the maxed out element will regenerate your health until you take damage..causing it to level down. Leading to some chaotic boss fights as you are constantly switching between elements, to both avoid damage, and to restore your life. You can buy health potions, but in the first few stages they are not affordable, so its much easier to learn to switch efficiently.

I found this game to be perfectly balanced, it was never too easy but also not too hard, if I ever got stuck in a boss, I either grinded a level or two, switch my weapon, or learned their pattern and eventually defeated them. 

One thing that may be a con for this game... is that as I mentioned, its based on a japanese franchise, so people who are not familiar with it, may be totally be confused about the story or miss out on alot of implications, however this game is mostly about the gameplay for 95% of the time, and the story is not THAT complicated...youll just miss out on a few references. Aside from that one complaint, everything else in the game was great.

Overall I had a blast playing through this game, beat in in a single day (about 8 hours), so the price is a bit high, around 20$ CND at the time of this review, but I am definitely gonna be replaying this game in the future, as I have replayed Symphony of the Night a few times. This game is totally worth a buy, if you feel like having some platformer rpg fun times.

92277564.review:
Genuinely great. It's Symphony of the Night with Ikaruga's main mechanic and in the RoLW world,  starring its best character.
Jam-packed with cool mechanics, but a bit short. Left me wanting for more :)
Completion time: 5hrs, 6 if you're aiming for 100% map completion.

[b]PROS[/b]
[list][*]Godtier pixelart, godtier animations, godtier presentation, even the UI slaps.
[*]Really nice soundtrack with a few memorable tracks.
[*]Super polished.
[*]Very tight gameplay with a low skill floor and high skill ceiling.
[*]Neat bow mechanic, especially the [spoiler]shooting range minigame[/spoiler].
[*]Large bestiary, constantly surprises you with new inventive mechanics and every mob has a lot of charm to it.
[*]The main mechanic, once you've gotten sufficiently used to it, is extremely fun and rewarding to play around.
[*]Deedlit.[/list]

[b]CONS[/b]:
[list][*]Not enough Lodoss. You spend most of your time exploring alone and [spoiler]interactions with the other main RoLW characters is extremely limited[/spoiler]. Although this is somewhat justified by the game's setting.
[*]Deedlit's colorful personality doesn't show much.
[*]A bit of wasted potential for some mechanics: Sliding, backdodging are barely used (zoning mobs and bosses at the edge of your range thanks to your insane aerial mobility makes these almost obsolete in combat), the bow's precision aiming mechanic is never used outside of puzzles and outshined in battle by magic, and the fire/wind spirit's "assist" projectile barely does anything. This is mostly due to the player's kit quickly becoming overloaded with very strong options.
[*]While it is a metroidvania, its level design is extremely linear. Outside of the little secret every now and then, there is always [i]only one location[/i] you can progress towards at any given time. This is a plus if you prefer handholding, but a minus if you're in for the open-ended maps this genre is known for.
[*]Difficulty is a bit weird, it's generally very easy but sometimes throws one-trick-pony difficulty spikes at you. Bosses at first mop the floor with your face with some untelegraphed quick attacks which you then completely handwave on your second try with proper spacing, given you're not cheesing them out by constantly fleeing and spamming on-element spells. Thankfully this is not always the case.
[/list]

Most of these cons are a bit nitpicky for a reason. It's really good and well worth its full price especially if you like the genre, Lodoss and/or the mother of anime elves.
At some point I thought I got softlocked and you might too so keep one thing in mind: In the section where you get Heritage, after the room with the undead king mobs, you must stay on top of each apparition for a few seconds to make them disappear.
Oh and just in case you're wondering, to access that one unexplored room below that one vertical corridor in the Stage 1 zone for 100% map completion, [spoiler]jump 50 times on the ground right above that room.[/spoiler] You're welcome!

92266345.review:
It's alright, but nothing spectacular.

The game has some really good pixel art and the music is great too, though some of the tracks kinda don't fit the environments in my opinion, like for example the track for Stage 4, even though it's my most favorite from the game. Gameplay is pretty tight and feels quite good, it just took some time to get used to, like dodging being a backstep instead of a free dash in any direction, or attacking while flying etc. The bosses are fun and have good patterns, but are very forgiving, it's not unusual to tank some damage on your first try before you learn the attacks and still win. And that's probably about it.

As for the things I found weak it would be the high amount of weapons, which are mostly crap and not very unique, which is a shame as various weapon types have different attack animations like a front slash/stab, overhead swing or a short range throw, but ultimately it doesn't matter what you use unless it's some early game weapon with bad stats. There is also a shop in the game, but I never really felt like I needed to buy or sell anything, except maybe some healing potions for rare bad situations. The weapons being sold are mostly crap or overpriced and you'll still find equivalents out in the open that are just as strong, if not better.
There are also a bunch of elements monsters are weak or resistant to, but you'll mostly deal air or fire damage based on the spirit you are currently using, with the rest being tied only to a single spell or a unique weapon that ignores the element of the spirit and uses its own. So it's kind of a wasted opportunity.
Also some bosses are made out of paper and can be easily cheesed by just keeping your distance and spamming bow or even casting a spell a few times, which is really a shame.
As for the level design, it's very simple, the rooms are basically just rectangles with some platforms in similar layouts, there are no secrets and the progression through the map is very linear for a metroidvania. Some of the traversal abilities aren't utilized enough too, for example the slide, you have to use it only like three times.

The game was still enjoyable, but short. I just wish there were more difficulties or something more like a secret boss or extra stage. It's also very similar to Luna Nights in strengths/weaknesses and feel, so if you liked that game, you'll like this one too.

92251026.review:
Good game, but it helps to know the source material. I don't, so my feelings are on the gameplay.
It's not quite as good as a Castlevania game, like SOTN, or Bloodstained. It lacks somewhat in depth. 
It's very light on the inventory, you only choose weapons, Melee and Bow, there's no armor or defensive trinkets to equip. 
You can buy new weapons from a merchant, but he's more supplemental as often you'll find stronger weapons(or pathetically weak ones) sitting in rooms behind a locked door, an archery puzzle, or need an item to reach. 
The bosses are probably a little easy, most were beaten on my first try. The first spell you get in the game is very strong and useful on almost every enemy, activating a spell will pause everything while its animation plays to give a bit of a breather to assess your situation. 
Your defensive options are a bit less than what SOTN has however, by default you have a Backstep, then you are given two elemental spirits of Wind and Fire that you can switch on the fly that protects you from and absorbs their respective element to gain MP and leveling them to their max cap of lvl. 3 gives you a generous HP regeneration. Wind allows you to hover and later Fire gets invincibility frames on the slide. Getting hit will level your Spirit down however, but it's easy enough, even during a boss fight, to get it back up to lvl 3.
Spirit management is key, keep them at lvl 3 to heal. There is no armor in this game.

Offensively your Melee and Bow attacks take the respective element and later increase base attack power when equipped, some enemies will be weak to one of the elements, some neutral, others outright immune, you'll be swapping Spirits alot, they are your lifeline to making progress.

All of this is really nitpicks. My only grievances is not understanding the source material and the minimaps position, I wish there was an option to move it, resize it, maybe change the zoom on it.

To conclude: It's worth a playthrough, replayability seems low as there isn't achievements yet.

92221725.review:
Team Leadybug is continuing to innovate metroidvanias in a way that is refreshing, but that I don't click with.

Wonder Labyrinth has more compelling storytelling and stronger rpg elements than Luna Nights, and like Luna Nights its boss fights are standouts that require technical skill and feel extremely fun to master.

In Labyrinth, the major mechanical gimmick is that you can switch polarity between air and fire, allowing you to absorb attacks of the corresponding element. This turns big fights into Ikaruga, which is dope.

However, like Luna Nights, I bounced off of the exploration pretty hard. Your life total is really low, and while you have some i-frames after getting hit, you also have recovery frames after getting hit, so it's not impossible for combinations of enemies to juggle you. The low life total also means you go from healthy to dead in only a couple misplays, and there's pretty decent distances between save statues, so you may find yourself repeating a lot of progress.

There's no armor equips and no defense stat, so it's play good and play consistently or die. And I can do the first one, but never the second one.

Overall, I'd recommend this, but with the caveat that if what you like about metroidvanias is specifically the rpg elements, this still doesn't really scratch that itch.

If you like platforming action games that require a little bit of thinking, that let you style your way through fights, and that are probably pretty fun to speedrun, I'd suggest picking this up.

92173900.review: As a huge fan of Metroidvania(or as I prefer, Metroid-likes) this game interested me, despite my ignorance on the franchise of Record of Lodoss War in general. I was familiar with Team Ladybug from Luna Nights, and the change in art style caught my particular attention, so onto my wishlist it went. When a friend bought it for me I jumped right in, eager for more Metroidvania games. It started as one would expect from an RPG based Metroidvania games, side-scrolling, exploring, leveling, changing weapons, but the game's core mechanics came to light soon enough. The sylphs, while they could have definitely been expanded for more variety and use, were really intuitive and fun to use, often acting with Ikaruga effects that blend very seamlessly with the gameplay. The controls are nice and tight, movement is very fluid, and combat allows for much more variety in attack angles than a lot of Metroidvania games and is very welcome. The story was told and characters were introduced in such a way that, as someone who is only familiar with the series in a passing way, didn't get too bogged down in lore from the series to the point that I got confused or lost. It's a great game, if a little on the short side, but the mechanics are solid, the visuals are great, and there is a pretty solid soundtrack too. If you're a Metroid-like fan, I highly recommend it, even if you don't know much about Record of Lodoss War.

92064965.review:
I greatly enjoyed this game, but I guess that's not surprising given my love of both Symphony of the Night and Record of Lodoss War manga/anime.  Even without that nostalgia, however, I still feel like this short but sweet game stands on its own.

My biggest knock against it is linearity.  While they are interconnected into one map, the game has bespoke "stages."  Each area is completed in order, and I didn't really feel like I was exploring a cohesive environment. You can backtrack to other areas once you get abilities/unlocks for weapons, spells and some upgrades, but it's all optional.  You can basically complete the game quickly going from stage to stage.  Some people complain about backtracking and exploring, but for me it is a hallmark of the genre.

That's really my only gripe with Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth.  The pixel art is lovely.  The soundtrack is really freaking good.  I didn't find the length disappointing.  I think it lasts just long enough to not overstay its welcome.  Being able to complete a game in a few sittings these days is a boon to me.  I got full map completion in about 8 hours. The quality of play for those 8 hours was consistently good, so I felt good about my $20 spent.  I really like this trend of short metroidvanias like this, Carrion, Momodora: Reverie Under the Moonlight, Timespinner, and Dandara.

92020064.review:
I just finished my first playthrough, with 100% map completed. Feels fairly short. It's a good game, but I wish I waited for a sale.

So I haven't seen the anime that this is based on, and they don't explain anything about who anyone is or what their relationships are. The game just assumes you already know. By the time I finished the game I still don't really know who these people are. The....explanation......for what is going, I accurately guessed within the first few minutes. Which is a bummer, because it made me care about what was going on, basically not at all. Oh well, who needs a story in a metroidvania game.

So you basically play as a gender swapped Alucard, from SOTL, but instead of having vampire magic, you get elemental magic.  Many of Deedlit's moves and controls are exactly the same. There are a few new mechanics; you get a bow and have two elemental familiars. The bow isn't a super big deal, you can aim up and down, but I mostly just used it to hit switches and open doors.

The familiars are a big deal. The air elemental lets you hover, feather fall, add wind damage to your attacks, and makes you immune to wind damage. The fire elemental adds fire damage and makes you immune to fire damage. It's nice to be immune to lava or a dragon's fire breath. They add more damage the more hits you get without taking damage (basically a combo system) and give health regeneration when full. This is how you'll get most of your healing, and you lose 1/3 of you combo bar when hit. Also using fire charges up the air elemental and using wind charges up the fire elemental. The total gameplay effect is that you'll want to switch elementals a LOT, to add the right damage, regenerate health, or block elemental damage. Sometimes twice in a single jump or every second or two. It's a neat change, but it's really easy to lose track in the heat of combat, take a few hits, get stunned then get killed. In most boss fights you'll either totally dominate them and never get hit more than twice, or you'll get hit a third time, stun locked and killed while you just stand there watching. Feels pretty cheap, but not awful.

The map is set up in exactly the same way as SOTL, including where they like to hide items. Metroidvania veterans will easily spot the breakable walls and see where on the map that secret rooms are most likely to be found.
