91965619.review: this game was so simple, i destroyed it one sitting not having to look up anything, this game truly had potential i believe, lovely graphics any metroidvania fan would love, i dont like comparing one thing to another, but Symphony of the night completely decimates this game in every aspect and was made like 20 years prior, the game will have you wanting to beat it but its only about 3-5 hours long, no fun things to collect and a low item pool, no real sense of adventure the map was small and every room is packed with monsters, traveling from one room to another that you just cleared and then having to go back to the same room and every monster respawn and having to kill them is where the majority of the game time goes, no real fun puzzles to boggle your mind, very straight forward simple game, theres news of a boss rush mode, but lets be honest how long will that last before it gets boring? i wouldnt recommend it as a fun game to play, it didnt scratch my itch for metroidvania games so i will continue the search

91925682.review:
Nothing much to add of what have been said. Great graphics, simple but working story, and some weird game design decisions. Overall I recommend it if you like Metroidvanias.

A couple of possible improvement which shouldn't be too expensive and improve the game further :
- Hard/+ modes. In this kind of game it's mandatory. Just tweaking some numbers in damages and health should be enough to allow player to tune the game experience.
- Nerf the boomerang and the chakram. I ruined half of the game abusing the first and rushed the final boss with the second. In most Metroidvanias games ranged weapons are often largely lower in raw damage than their melee counterpart. Those two weapon are doing way too much for their convenient usage.
- Remove both, erh, meat? From the [spoiler]Shooting Star[/spoiler] arena. It makes the fight impossible to fail as whenever you're a bit low, you just have to go to the side and beat your m.... well you got it. I doubt removing them well make the fight that harder as this boss pattern is fairly easy to learn.
- Add either a mp cost or a maximum duration between two landing to the hovering ability. It makes a certain number of monsters plus a fair bunch of boss attacks absolutely unthreatening.

Some others improvements but might be harder to implement :
- Some monsters attacks hitbox should be tweaked, noticeably the minotaurs. When they use the jump-slash attack you can litterally pass through the axe unharmed.
- Some monsters pattern make them particularly weak in some situation, noticeably the crocodiles
- A fair bunch of your attack pass through walls, while most enemies can't. Now imagine that with the Boomerang and Hover. Yeah I'm flying and killing all flying enemies from below, wall or not.
- I never figured out what poison does. If a threatening mechanic can't be figured out, it's not threatening enough.
- Some songs are just... too darn 00's techno for such a fantasy game.

Again I mostly appreciated it, but I felt like underlining what could make it great.

91822102.review:
[i]Record of Lodoss War-Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth-[/i] is a wonderful game with a long title. Fans of the "Igavania" [i]Castlevania[/i] entries, especially [i]Symphony of the Night[/i], will find some real similarities in Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth.

The game stars Deedlit from the old-school anime/manga/light novel [i]Record of Lodoss War[/i]. I watched this OVA over ten years ago, so I didn't remember a lot of it. That's okay because the story here isn't too concentrated until the end. You can easily get by with no knowledge of the source material.

In [i]Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth[/i] you will traverse a labyrinth of mysterious rooms and corridors laden with enemies and traps. Unlike the gothic, sci-fi, or Arabian Nights-themed aesthetics of other similar games, [i]Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth[/i] uses classic [i]Dungeons & Dragons[/i] creatures in a dark fantasy world. Combat is really fun, and Deedlit has a small array of powers that can be combined to get some amazing effects. By switching between air and fire spirits, she can absorb MP from enemy spells and even regenerate health, along with being able to hover and use spells, melee weapons, and bows. I was so impressed with the game in minutes after starting.

Musick, sound effects, and graphics are top-notch. The musick replicates [i]Symphony of the Night[/i] in some areas (mostly the intro), and I am fine with that. The musick goes from rock epics to more ambient fare. Sound effects sound crisp and forceful. The audio really made the game feel alive, and so did the graphics. From the moment I saw Deedlit's cape flitting about, backgrounds slightly rotating to adjust to the player's movement, and the animations of the various enemies of the game, I was blown away. This is really good stuff.

I can't recommend [i]Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth[/i] enough. It's not super long, but the hours I spent playing it have been a real highlight. I'm excited for new features that have been promised soon (boss rush), and I will have to finish exploring the labyrinth to get the last few percentage points to 100%.

This sits comfortably in the group of middling metroidvanias such as The Mummy: Demastered, Chasm, Timespinner, and Alwa's Legacy.

The game itself is... ok, and there's a love and attention to detail in the character art and backgrounds (mostly) but this attitude doesn't seem to apply to world-design, enemies, and gameplay - all of which being fairly standard and boring. 

Team Ladybug's map design (and obsession with long hallways and keeping their maps as compact as possible for whatever reason) has gotten so stale that I was able to accurately predict where save rooms and secrets were just by seeing certain room layouts or looking for gaps in the map. Considering this is their third metroidvania now, I would expect to see some improvement in map-design by now (or some new ideas altogether) but they seem perfectly fine with recycling ideas and assets instead and taking absolutely no risks whatsoever.

If you've already played the good metroidvanias, then there's really nothing here for you. If you're new to the genre and want something basic but with at least a bit more personality, play Luna Nights instead.

91336825.review:
There are bad games, there are good games, and then there are games that are total wonders. This one has "Wonder" in its title, and it deserves it. 

Ladybug yet again basically made a fanfiction game using an official license and yet did something so lore appropriate than the tragically bad sequel trilogy of Star Wars that it makes me wonder why anyone dares to call them canon. Why did I waste a couple sentences hating those movies? Because they are terrible, I am still offended by them, and because I can find better writers off the side of the road than the morons involved with writing that tripe, as often is proven by labors of love like this game. Previously they made Lunar Nights taking place in Touhou, and now they have this amazing game taking place in Record of the Lodoss War.

So, how faithful is it? Well, if you ever watched Lodoss War, you know it is something that is extremely niche for a reason. Stiff voicework, classic music as a soundtrack, and looks like it was made on the budget of two shoe strings and a ball of yarn. So, who the heck cares, go watch Rune Sodlier instead.

As for this game's gameplay? Well, good bend like a reed in the wind combat action and worth the effort. A little less impressive than Luna Nights, but dang this group impresses me. I did not like the element shift mechanics because it altered how you moved in the environment, but apparently there is some game called Ikaruga or such that has a similar mechanic.... now that I think about it, this game borrows a shmup mechanic for a metroidvania game, while their previous game was a metroidvania game based on a shmup franchise. There is now way to not think about the mindset of this company while I review this game, is there? Well, better than pointing out how bad Star Wars Episode 8 is.

Music? Not all that good. Passable. When they made Luna Nights, they were able to borrow from that franchise's amazing OST list, but Lodoss War had nothing of quality in its music, so this game gets less quality music than the other title. It is 1:24 as I type this sentence. I am barely awake, allow me to vent about random stuff as I review this good game.

Was I disappointed by anything in this game? No Rune Soldier cameos or references were found on my playthrough. That is all. That is my only complaint, because both of Lodoss and Rune Soldier are in the same anime continuity or whatever.

Story: Corn and Orange out of Banana and Apple.
It good. I won't spoil anything, but knowing what I do, I expected the ending I got before I even had purchased the game. Some of the trailers kinda made me realize right away what I was getting into.

91332378.review:
This game has the stupidest title I've ever seen.

The story is almost completely incomprehensible. Deep down, it's just a tale about learning to let go as part of the grieving process after losing someone you love. But they hide it under layers and layers of useless information about a war in the "kingdom of Lodoss" and by  introducing like 10-15 characters that the main character supposedly knew during this war. It's like jumping into the Lord of the Rings at chapter 18 of The Two Towers. Horribly, awfully written and the charm of the final moments of the game are ruined because of it.

The bosses in this game aren't just equally awful, they're even worse than the story. If you're actually fighting the bosses, you're an idiot. All you have to do is find the spell that is a boss' weakness, then spam it over and over while dodging. If you run  out of MP, every boss has at least one attack that you can stand in to "drain" MP out of. Just dodge and spam, and cheese every single boss. The only point of weapons is getting around the map.

BUT

It is a perfectly serviceable Metroidvania. It has an interesting gimmick, though it doesn't feel like that is ever really used to its full potential. You can switch between an air element and fire on-the-go, which give different benefits such as floating or being invulnerable to fire. Standing in pockets of the same element you are using "drains" MP, but hitting an opposite element hurts. There are a few situations where this is used to the best, where you have to switch back and forth between them to get through puzzle-like rooms, or while falling like a platformer, or while fighting enemies. Overall, it feels underutilized, but it's still a cool idea.

The music is AMAZING. The art and animation is BEAUTIFUL. It's almost like the budget went entirely to the soundtrack  and art design. If you like metroidvanias, it's almost worth it just for both, since really good pixel art is kinda rare nowadays with indie games.

The moment-to-moment gameplay is decent, and great to look at  and listen to. The story and the bosses are trash. Overall, I'd give it a 6.5/10. I recommend to anyone who likes metroidvanias and has a little cash to spend, but keep in mind that it's pretty short. I got through in ~5.6 hours with 99% map completion, probably only missing one or maybe two tiles. It's far from perfect, but I'd love to see this iterated on and  improved in a future title.

91332012.review: 4/5: tl;dr a little too easy but fun nonetheless. a fun little excursion into an amazing fantasy world :). this game could benefit from a more fleshed out world but it does well with what it offers. the combat ranges from easy to intermediate, and the core mechanic of switching spirits make combat charming and makes the bosses so fun to learn the patterns of (though) most have a gimmick or flaw to exploit. it can be beat it in about 10 hours (and i had nearly 96% map completion so it's not that hard to find the secrets just by fighting unfortunately). this game could benefit from a hard mode and having more secrets and puzzles.

A nice, very playable Metroidvania - good for casual play. Very pretty pixel art throughout and not so complex in its powers/challenges, so easy to grab a short session in the evening after work while still making good progress. Was able to complete it at a reasonable pace without any major obstacles (except trying for S-Rank on the Archery Training - pointless frustration for completionists only - elemental and other bows are more useful than the reward).

In-Genre:
I probably prefer Hollow Knight as a Metroidvania (literally my favourite in the whole genre), but it's a very all-encompassing game that both needs and deserves a lot of attention, whether it be for the challenging bosses/areas, worry of losing your accumulated Geo, deep exploration or breathtaking art. All great points if you consistently have the chunks of time to take advantage of it, but I found Deedlit much easier to pick up and play. Some bosses would need a Retry, but many could be adapted to and cleared on the first attempt, without any restoration items. Elemental attributes are a big deal mid- to late-game, so once you amass a decent armoury of Spirits/Bows you can usually exploit most enemies' weakness to make short work of them, including bosses.

Story & Final Thoughts:
I hear that Touhou Luna Nights is probably their trickier game, and on the strength of this, would be happy to pick it up for my next dip into the genre. I had no prior familiarity with Lodoss, but still was readily drawn to the characters and interested in seeing how their story played out. If you want a charming Metroidvania that doesn't ask too much but gives a lot in return, this is a good one. If you only want a Metroidvania that tests your legacy skill in the genre, this might be too light (or just good for a speedrun).

91292662.review:
========
Summary:
========
Another great title by team Ladybug which features again a metroidvania gameplay just like Luna Nights.
There are a lot of different weapons and powers to use and the experience is fairly short yet satisfying (I finished the game in 7 hours despite many deaths).
The soundtrack as always is very good, the animations, sound effects are also great and the bosses are all challenging and have intresting patterns and design.  
========
Difficulty:
========
Enemy wise, the game is surprisingly fair until the very last chapter which features some really tough enemies (more on that later).
On the platforming side, it's pretty fair with a few difficult sections but overall most of it is manageable and you probably won't die too often due to the level design.

Gameplay wise however, the game will take some getting used to as the main character is able to switch between two elements (Wind and Fire) which allows you to absorb the same type damage but also affect which type of damage you inflict.
And since most enemies will have different vulnerabilities to elements, it is strongly recommended that you look at what their weaknesses are (displayed at the bottom right of the screen) otherwise the game will be SIGNIFICANTLY harder (trying to kill a fire monster with fire for instance).
These elements are represented with two gauges at the middle of the screen with 3 different levels.
The higher the element's level, the higher the damage you inflict.
And if the gauge is at level 3 you automatically regenerate health.
You will however lose levels if you get hit.
The game also has a very low amount of invulnerability frames or Iframes (a period after being hurt during which you cannot get hit) which means you WILL get severely punished later on in rooms that have multiple enemies that can make you fall on top of another enemy making you take damage twice with no way to avoid it sometimes leading to your death.
========
Bosses:
========
Probably this game's strongest point, the bosses are fairly difficult to deal with and will pose a fair challenge to the player the first time they fight them. 
Some will still remain a challenge even after multiple fights due to their number of different patterns and how fast some of them are. 
========
Unlockables:
========
Most of the hidden powers/weapons are found by destroying secret walls and are pretty obvious to find if you look at your map.
You will sometimes have to explore a fair bit to find switches or keys to progress but there aren't many instances of that.
While most of them are on your path, some require a bit of looking around by using your collected items or powers.
You'll also be able to purchase some gear and items from a merchant with in game gold collected from beating monsters or selling unused weapons.
Weapons have different swing speed and reach which allows you to play however you like.
========
Length:
========
As mentioned earlier, the game should roughly last 7 or more hours depending on how you fare against the bosses and enemies.
========
Extra Content:
========
While I couldn't find it, there's apparently a boss rush mode but the game features no New Game + from what I saw.
This may change with future updates as the game just got released.
========
100%-ing the game and achievements:
========
As of now there are no Achievements in the game and you can't exactly track what Items you got from which level like in Luna Nights which makes it difficult to know if you've 100% the game or not but it isn't necessary to get all the items/powers to beat the game.

91195614.review:
At best, it's OK. I'd been sitting on it since it came out in EA ages ago, waiting for it to be finished. The overall core is fine, nothing outstanding, but the enemy+room+combat design all put together leave something to be desired - with some improvement in any of those areas I think it would have been much better.

Basically, standard 2D platforming castlevania-esque combat. If you touch an enemy, you get knocked back and lose a bunch of health, if an enemy attack hits you, you get knocked back and lose a bunch of health, if you get hit I think 3 times in a moderate time span you get straight up stunned. Because the knock backs are so huge and hit recovery is so long there were times when I went from full health to dead against normal enemies where I literally couldn't react. Adding more frustration to this, the hitboxes of enemies are not super clear, and some enemies have attacks that basically require you to just retreat across the screen to avoid because they overlap with other enemies' attacks so broadly. It's also far too difficult to tell which spirit you are using on the fly when looking at your character, which you need to constantly because you need to be moving pretty much all the time (and thus, dodging). There's an easy marker at the top of your screen, the opposite of where you are, but it really needed to be more present on Deedlit herself.

Maybe as compensation for the general difficulty of actually using weapons on enemies, magic and bow attacks are quite strong, but capped by mana, but mana is easy to recover - sometimes, and against some enemies. You can go several rooms in a row with no easy mana recovery options or just room after room of basically infinite mana. Spamming magic or arrows is relatively effective against some of the more annoying enemies if you sit there and change your spell constantly. Some enemies are also just mega tanky, require jumping to interact with because they hover offscreen, and you quickly learn you're best off just trying to get past them or knocked back past them.

It technically fulfills the requirements of calling it a metroidvania but the exploration is pretty limited, there's usually 1 room in each stage that requires an upgrade you get later (or unlocking a door you can later), otherwise just breakable walls hide things. There is very little reason to backtrack as I think all the upgrades you'd want are available as you progress naturally.

The boss fights are pretty good, except for the last two boss fights, which I don't want to spoil but it does the whole "fail a phase? Here, waste your time on everything easy all over again!" except it's even more egregious how pointless it is due to some specifics of them. It literally felt like padding, in a pretty short game, for no reason. Some of the worst lack of checkpoint design I've seen in a game.

I was aware of Record of Lodoss ages ago but never watched it, I do know it brings in a lot of characters from it to have a few lines of dialogue here and there, but it is not really a story game.

Overall, just OK. I would put it pretty far down my list of metroidvanias. It tries to emulate Symphony of the Night in various ways but not in enough of them to bring it up a notch. The enemy design and level design is just pretty bad and the combat does that no favors. Maybe a 6 out of 10 from me.

91170245.review:
While I know very little about Metroidvanias as this is the first one I've played since Metroid Fusion (which I dropped, but I'll pick it back up soon), I definitely know a few things about Record of Lodoss War - so I'll be looking at this thing as "just" a metroidvania first, then as a Lodoss War story. 

As a simple Metroidvania, I can say it felt good. You get plenty of mobility, weapons feel good to swing and there's a decent number of them. Not a million, but enough for you to care. 
"Spirit Switching", i.e. the Ikaruga color-switching mechanic is also pretty fun: it makes you invulnerable to attacks of the same element as your active one, changes the properties of some of your moves (jump becomes a freeform glide with Wind mode, slide becomes an i-frame'd Cannon Drill with Fire mode) and raises your total damage based on the current power level of each mode (caps at 3, you always lose 1 on hit regardless of HP, also like a shmup). 
My only real gripes with gameplay are the lack of a "turn" button when you have your bow out and the fact that spells and items are in the same equip slot. You can only equip a spell or an item at a time, bound to the same button. You'll get used to it, but they could both make moment-to-moment slightly better if adjusted.

In a way, it feels just like watching the 1990 OVA: a short, easy-watching, lavishly-produced experience with plenty of memorable moments, but also minor details that could have been done better. Speaking of the OVA, by the way...

/// DO *NOT* PLAY THIS AS YOUR ENTRY POINT INTO RECORD LODOSS WAR ///

This whole thing is basically a curtain call for the original book cycle, which is about 7 volumes long. They were also never translated in english, so that makes the 1990 OVA your only option (aside from Wikipedia), and lemme tell you: you will not understand a single thing of anything that is happening without it. Or rather you will, but some moments won't hit the way they were designed to because you'll be going "who the fuck is this" every 2 seconds. So basically, watch the OVA before even thinking of booting the game up. It's a nice watch anyway, so don't worry about it.

Also, EXTREMELY important detail: in the original DnD campaign that would serve for the basis for the novels, Deedlit was played by the author, Ryo Mizuno himself. Try to keep this in mind as you get to the ending. 

If you're already into Lodoss War though, what awaits you here is both a lovingly crafted tribute and a bittersweet sendoff to the tale of Parn, Deedlit and the Accursed Island - and more importantly, to Ryo Mizuno's tale. To the good times long past, and to the uncertainty of the future. 

Godspeed, Lady Deedlit.

90918197.review:
[h1]A solid metroidvania, but easy and short[/h1]

As the title flat out states, this is a classic 2d metroidvania, and an enjoyable one at that. The presentation is very nice, with great animations for the pixel art, and a good soundtrack to go with it. The gameplay is also well-done, with just a handful of issues here and there. The game is not as responsive as it could be when it comes to shooting arrows and then sliding to avoid damage, or switching between the two spirits you have to use the different moves/properties they have, for example. You get nice (if a bit simple) mobility upgrades as you progress, and your movement speed hits a sweet spot from the start, turning the exploration of the map into an enjoyable affair. You get a decent array of spells, although some are much more practical than others. The weapon selection is perhaps a bit too limited, however, if not in number, at least in functionality, with too many similar melee options.

As mentioned before, the game is extremely easy, and I think I got everything there was to find in 6 hours. Then again, this isn't a 60 dollars release, and the easy difficulty at least doesn't hinder the pacing of the completion. If you are a fan of the genre, definitely give it a go, and it might even be a good entry point for newcomers, assuming these flaws aren't discouraging.

90911016.review: A short but sweet metroidvania based on the character Deedlit from the Record of Lodoss War series. I'd recommend you watch the anime or read the manga to learn more about the characters, The pixel art is quite nice. My only gripes are that the map didn't feel completely fleshed out. I'm glad the game didn't drag on but I'm a bit unsatisfied with the amount of exploration I was allowed to do. I think I found about 85 to 90% of all the items but there didn't seem to be a way to tell. If there's a bestiary and item collection log in game, I missed it. Overall not a bad game for the price, but I can't really recommend a full price purchase if you compare it to other metroidvanias available on steam.

90884296.review:
There is no game that I love more than Symphony of the Night. Off the top of my head it's one of the hardest games for me to explain why I even like it so much. There's so much for me to talk about from the characters, the gameplay, the music! Man the music in that game is something I can never get enough of it. Lost Painting is probably one of my favorite video game songs ever.

Due to sotn though I have a very particular taste in metroidvania games. I remember being recommended some Metroid games and when I gave them a shot I wasn’t really interested. Through that I learned I’m more of a fan of fantasy settings and the use of swords and whatnot. Being in Space with some space guns is just not the most interesting thing to me personally. 

That’s what eventually led me to Team LadyBug. These dudes are great at making metroidvanias out of whatever property given to them. I found them initially though Touhou Luna Nights. This game managed to get me to still play it although it did not even have weapon variety like in Sotn.

Although it lacked things that usually would pull me in I still played this game to 99% completion. Yeah 99% because just like in Bullet hell games these bosses are HARD! And I just could beat that final boss but great game nonetheless. This game was enough to make me believe that Team Ladybug can make the types of Metroidvania games I’m looking for.

That Led me to this game in which I was more of what I was interested in. 

While I didn't know anything about Record of Lodoss War I still played this game and I found it fairly interesting. I’m not going to go into detail because there ain’t much to tell and honestly I feel experiencing this game without knowing the story is the way to go here even if it isn’t something all too deep.

As a metroidvania this game is great especially for someone who prefers more of an Igavania I had such a fantastic time with this game. Something you quickly notice about this game is that its movement is great and when attacking depending on what you’re using. 


There’s 3 different types of primary weapons in the game. One-handed weapons, two-handed, and throwables. One handed weapons are your standard type deal that allows you to attack in 8 directions. Two-handed weapons cannot swing in as many directions but they always attack with a giant overhead swing that makes them overall very useful especially if a two-handed weapon is the strongest you have. 

Lastly as I said throwables which there were only two of that I could find. They’re your basic boomerang style weapons that are neat but not all too useful and in terms of swinging. That’s the general breakdown of the weapons but there are still different types of weapons but they’re only visual. 

Something else in this game is Bows and Arrows as your secondary weapon. Bows serve as your long ranged weapon that sports different qualities depending on the bow that you have. It could range from shooting multiple arrows to having homing arrows. They’re especially helpful during later game boss fights since they can get chaotic especially when you’re upclose where you’re more likely to get hit.

Bows are also used in some puzzles to open doors or spin various gears. 

Another thing this game has is magic. While its not used in the same sense that it is in Sotn, it's still something you can find and equip throughout the game.

Magic is unlocked by finding it throughout the game. They’re all equippable like items that you scroll through. Some are clearly more useful than others, especially the wind and fire magic as there are enemies that clearly take damage to one or the other.

Overall as a metroidvania style game I enjoyed it a lot and I can thoroughly recommend it. Although the start of it feels a bit slow to me personally once you start getting into the actual meat of the area you traverse through you really start to feel it all come together as a very fun game that will really push you. 

The boss fights in this game is possibly one of its best qualities as it takes influence a bit from what Team LadyBug did in Luna Nights by making the bosses have some bullet hell influence on occasion which as I said earlier paired up with some weapons like your bow makes the fights all the more interesting. 

There were some problems I had with the game though for example maybe I was just expected to grind but the end game areas felt a tad too difficult as I felt very weak in comparison to most of the enemies there but the bosses felt fine and pretty balance in my opinion but I also could’ve just cheesed them by using the bow. 

Speaking of bosses one thing this game had that I did not like is that for the final boss you have to beat the boss beforehand again if you die due to no save in between and I wish there was a checkpoint there. You do end up learning how to quickly beat the boss easily rather fast so it's not the BIGGEST of deals but it's still annoying. 

My final issue with this game which is a similar problem I have with Sotn is that there is no new game plus meaning that once you beat this game unless you haven’t played it in a while there really isn’t much of a reason to come back.

Overall this is a very fun game that I recommend a lot as aside from Bloodstained which was literally made by Igarashi this is the first metroidvania in a while that really hooked me in and I wish it released on more platforms because currently as of this video its only on PC but considering its minimum requirements I don’t think it’ll be too much of an issue for even those of you rocking a craptop.

Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth really surprised me with its quality and is a fantastic game for the price of simply 20 bucks which is honestly the perfect price for the game. Great combat, fantastic music and sprites, and just absolutely fun as hell boss fights that I would love to fight again. 

In Conclusion…. 

Buy this fucking game.

(If you read this whole thing then yes I posted a whole youtube script I wrote on this game with a few minor tweaks)

I really enjoyed this game, but I cannot in good faith give it a blanket recommendation. As a long time fan of both the anime series Lodoss War and the metroidvania genre, I was the target audience of Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth, and I was ultimately disappointed by it.

The graphics are great, featuring large, beautifully made sprites with a lot of frames of fluid animation. The music is evocative and driving; nothing that will stick in your mind, but keeping you in the moment. The controls handle well and are properly customizable. The story was confusing to a point, but ultimately resolved well, and was probably simple enough that even those who aren’t fans of the anime could enjoy it (I think my confusion was mostly trying to place it in the existing Lodoss story).

Switching between the fire and wind spirit, the primary mechanic in the game, was probably its strongest attribute, and I would have loved to see it expanded. Much like Ikaruga, the idea is that your fire spirit absorbs fire attacks, but also causes you to attack with fire, so you have to keep switching to balance your offense and defense based on the enemies and obstacles around you. The aspects that utilized this mechanic well were definitely my favorite parts of the game, and I wish they had been expanded on.

The metroidvania elements are where it starts to come up short. The map is very small, made worse by the extremely compact layout. The large sprites and mostly unremarkable hallways make a lot of the screens go by quickly as well. The design changes between the six stages weren’t terribly remarkable, and the last stage was basically a set piece for the story with two boss fights, with no meat to it: no enemies, no obstacles, no puzzles.

The rest of the game is similarly lacking in “diverse” and “memorable.” The enemy sprites are great, drawn straight out of the anime/manga, but the roster isn’t especially robust, even less so when you take palette swaps and other small changes into account. The main collectibles in the game are weapons and spells that don’t make the game play that differently, so going back to find a secret room often left me with an underpowered weapon or a spell I might cast once or twice.

The main premise of a metroidvania is the idea of gating off areas to encourage exploration and backtracking. Most of the areas of this game were gated off with colored doors or keys. The few powers that were present included the omni-present double-jump and water-breathing, along with a slide that felt like it could have been a core mechanic. The way that the game handled its super jump was probably my favorite feature, especially combined with the air spirit’s levitation ability.

In the end, I feel like this game would have benefited from more focus being put on the platforming, rather than releasing a short, watered down Symphony of the Night. I would have loved to see more flavor and length to each stage, more creative uses of the core mechanics, and more challenging jumps, puzzles, and bosses. I enjoyed the game while I was playing it, but I wish there was more of it, both in terms of length and depth.

90789319.review:
Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth is a fun Metroidvania title with very clear pros and cons. It is a game that some are destined to love but everyone else will find themselves unimpressed.

The Positives

-The gameplay is simple and fun. There are no complicated weapon/magic/platforming systems, which makes DiW accessible to even non-hardcore players.
-Exploration is enjoyable and works organically in the game. I never felt like I was wasting time not knowing what to do or where to find what I was looking for.
-The spirit system is a clever mechanic with a lot of potential.
-There is a decent variety of enemies, most of them with their own unique set of moves.
-Controls are exactly the way they need to be, movement feels smooth and there were only a handful of times when Deedlit did not immediately do what I wanted her to.
-Visually the game is a joy to watch and it is bound to age amazingly. I cannot imagine a better pixelated version of Lodoss.
-What I said about the visuals is also true for the music. Excellent work.
-I cannot overstate how happy I was to see Record of Lodoss War being brought back to the light. Nostalgia is a absolutely a factor that helped me love this game to an extent that I otherwise may not have. I wish the future will bring us more games from the Lodoss universe and maybe even from other titles of the same era (I'd love a game for Vampire Princess Miyu, Guyver or Arslan).

The Negatives

-DiW is extremely short and there are no extra modes or rewards, so other than enjoying the game again from the start there is no incentive in replaying. I get that this is an indie project but I think it needs a few more additions.
-Even worse, DiW provides next to no challenge. I am far from being a seasoned Metroidvania player but at almost no time did I feel like I had to signifantly up  my game to progress. An easy/hard mode would help spice things up a bit.
-There are many weapons but less than a quarter of them feel distinct in some way.

Overall Deedlit in Wonderlabyrinth is a title made for Metroidvania fans who want a relaxing time and old-school Lodoss/anime fans. Anyone else will probably find it underwhelming. I for one I am happy to have played it and want more.

90779377.review:
Really neat metroidvania that leans way more into the castlevania side for a change. 
Story is understandable even for someone like me, who doesn't know shit about Record of Lodoss War, graphics are very well done with some seriously impressive pixel animations, both for characters/bosses and in the environment as well.
Gameplay is generally good, it's got basic combat with upwards diagonal attacks, an aimable bow attack, different magics to use and the need to switch between two stances will keep you on your toes during fights. 
Although there are some hiccups here and there, like Deedlit jumping instead of dodge-sliding, resulting in unneccessary damage taken, the double jump not working properly on some instances, or enemies flying out of the screen so you can't hit them but they can hit you, the flaws of this game are generally pretty minor.
Also the general difficulty isn't really that high, it kinda rises and falls depending on how much you want to utilize the tools (or rather items), the game gives you; you can cheese pretty much all bosses apart from the last couple few by just spamming attack, magic and potions nonstop.
 I personally hardly used any potions on my playthrough (and i forgot about magic on most bosses lol) save for the last two or three and the game was a decent challenge still, so it's largely up to you. That said there is a maximum of 10 items of each type that you can carry.
It's also not very long, and the replay value goes against zero, with the game being very linear and secrets being few. That doesn't need to neccessarily be a bad thing though, since not finding secrets doesn't hold you back in any significant way and even though the game in a way railroads you through its' zones (aka no sequence breaking), the zones themselves are big enough and always give you multiple paths to explore when you first enter them.

All in all a very beautiful, slightly flawed metroidvania that will scratch your itch just enough and doesn't overstay its' welcome.

90612428.review:
What's cool?

Atmosphere. Art. Weapons. Spells. Characters. Enemies. Everything you can do mechanically as the player.

The highlight of the game for me as the player was the sheer amount of movement and combat potential you have. The first thing you unlock is floating and I thought that was cool. Most games with enemies and spikes would never want you to have something like that.

Bow and spells are of course tied to MP, but the drip regen + ikargua style polarity mechnic MP regen/damage nullification take care of you greatly, meaning you can actually feel more like one of those slick battle characters instead of hack, hack, hack, hack, one spell, hack for rest of battle. Health regen tied to a gauge you lose when you get hit seemed like it wouldn't be good, but they nailed that too. Now you have the incentive to flip between your polarities for health, damage, damage nullification, and magic regen. Gets pretty hectic.


Biggest cons is that most of the game is way too easy. Especially as you level from just clearing the enemies as you move around, you just end up wiping the floor with a lot most regular mobs. The "Large" bosses tend to be way too easy as well. Otherwise towards the end the standard mobs get good and the other bosses are pretty fun.

Ladybug - take this same exact mechanics, art, everything and just expand the levels, enemies, boss fights. The player has such a fantastic arsenal to such slick stuff, but you just don't have the targets for it.

90611605.review:
Record of Lodoss War- Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth is easily one of the best metroidvania games to come out in the last couple of years. 
The game is beautiful to look at, with detailed high quality sprites, the gameplay is challenging, and the music is phenomenal.

Honestly the few gripes I have with the game are more nitpicks than anything. Sometimes it's difficult to tell whether you have the wind or fire ability equipped in the heat of battle. A few bosses are a bit cheap, seeming to do way more damage than they should. It's also a bit on the short side, I've basically 100% the game in terms of map completion, beating the game, and collecting all the available upgrades within 10 hours.

This is a solid 9/10, if you love Metroidvania's, I think this game will be right up your alley.

90591651.review:
Overall, Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth is a fun but slightly disappointing metroidvania that includes a couple of really cool ideas, but doesn’t do nearly enough with them. Sure, the pixel art is to die for and the Ikaruga-esque color swapping mechanics are neat, but the experience is held back by lackluster enemies, stale and uninspired level design, as well as overpowered, easily exploitable mechanics that end up trivializing boss fights. It’s not a bad game, per se (which is why I'm still giving it a thumbs up, albeit a weak one), but I really wish there was more substance to it. More meat on its proverbial bones.

90566706.review:
A good, quick metroidvania with Stellar animation and a Ikaruga colour switching mechanic to become immune to specific attacks.
It accomplishes what it wants to do and finishes up, doesn't waste your time.

The colour switching mechanic also replaces the use of healing items or metroids energy orbs.
Attacking with one colour levels up the other colour, and at max level a colour will heal you over time when active.
However a colour will lose a level each time you are hit, so it rewards careful play instead of damage racing enemies.

There are also magic spells which give you a variety of ways to do damage at range, and mana mainly charges by hitting enemies with your weapons.
So you can close in to hit enemies when you have an opportunity, then when they are attacking you can spend your mana on ranged attacks while you evade. Combat has a nice rhythm.

90476384.review: This is a fairly short metroidvania but is quite enjoyable. There's not too much backtracking/exploration but what makes the game enjoyable is a unique combat system and fun boss fights. The combat system gives you several different magic spells as well as the ability to switch between fire and wind melee attacks. 90475396.review:
This game is a love letter to IGA and metroidvanias, a genre that has seen a plethora of entries, but none quite like this.  Few times have I started one of these style of games up has it really taken me back to the time I played Symphony of The Night at a local video game trader's store before I made the purchase. This was before you had mass market, big box stores of the likes of gamestop and  instant access to reviews and information about the latest and greatest.  Back then you only had trickles of info from EGM or other contemporary videogame publication. 

I have been following this game for quite some time and have been intrigued just solely on the art direction and visual aesthetic. Upon watching trailer after trailer and gameplay previews from early builds I was hooked.  This was going to be a day one buy for me.

The moment I started it up and played it I was transported back in time to that memory of me in that local used game store. This is that kind of game for me and I highly recommend it to anyone, especially if you're the OG and Symphony of The Night was your introduction to the beloved Castlevania series.

90450168.review:
TL;DR: 9/10, short and sweet and worth the money.

I am a fan of this genre, so felt I was bound to like this game too. And yes, I did like this game, a lot.

It's not a long game at all, it's pretty short. It only took me 7 hours to beat the game with 100% map completion. But for the asking price, I think that's very reasonable. The controls are responsive and satisfying and the mechanics are all very well polished.

At times I felt the game had a bit of a problem with enemies piling on damage while I was recovering from the last hit or being stunned, leading to a few deaths. But because of the abundance of save points and versatile attack strategies to counter these enemies, these deaths were never irritating.

The music and visuals are amazing and brings the presentation together with a lot of flair.

If I had some critique it would probably be the following:

The equipment system feels somewhat redundant, especially from the shop, since you will progress the game and find better weapons before you have time to start appreciating the ones you already have. While some weapons have elemental properties that deal more damage to certain enemies, I never found myself relying on this to the extent I had to switch gear. Speaking of elemental attacks...

The expanded elemental system feels entirely pointless. You always have access to Wind and Fire element at the press of a button, and no enemy is resistant to both. If they guard against Wind, hit them with Fire, and vice versa. Therefore the addition of Light, Dark, Water, Wood, and Earth elements added almost nothing to the game whatsoever. Equipping high power gear, relying only on Fire and Wind, and casting the Wisp spell for its homing ability got me through the game just fine from beginning to end.

However, neither of these critiques detract from my enjoyment of the game whatsoever, they just seemed superfluous. It was a fun time beginning to end, and I'm happy I finally got to play it.

90439702.review: This game is incredible. I am a fan of the IP in general, and had high hopes for this game. Happy to say that my expectations were shattered. Thoroughly enjoyed this game. It is fairly short clocking in at about 5-7 hours depending on skill and time spent exploring. The boss fights are significantly more difficult than the regular enemies encountered throughout the game, but that's expected given the heavy Castlevania inspiration. Music is FANTASTIC! Switching between the fire and wind spirits to find enemy weakness is a nice added layer of complexity to keep the game engaging. Finally, the pixel art and animations are absolutely gorgeous. Record of Lodoss War series creator Ryo Mizuno also oversaw the development of this game. Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth might not be for everyone, but it checked all the right boxes for me. 10/10

90399301.review:
Great Metroidvania game. It was an absolute joy from start to finish.
The little story was nicely implemented and it was always great to see all the characters from Lodoss in the game. 
It has beautiful pixelart, good mechanics and diverse bosses to fight.

Deedlit can switch between 2 spirits (Sylph = Wind and Salamander = Fire) changing elemental properties of your attacks and adds immunity to the element of the chosen spirit. The spirits also let you absorb it's appropriate element to regenerate your MP.

There are plenty weapons to discover. Some are even able to change your attack property to another element regardless of the active spirit (e.g. thunder or dark). 
Your weapon options are longswords, daggers, throwing weapons (mid range), spears and 2-handed swords. For long range combat there are only bows.

During the course of the game Deedlit will learn new moves and spells to aid her. The moves typically let you get to parts of the stage that where previously unreachable.

It took me about 8 hours to reach the end. The game left me very satisifed, but it also left me longing for a sequel.

Edit: Thank you for the final update. I will try to get all the achievments soon.

90284031.review: As someone who has been called a "connoisseur of Metroidvania games", a title that makes me want to put my head through a wall, I have to say I quite enjoyed Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth.  I think in terms of style and control this is the closest a game has ever gotten to emulating the legendary Castlevania Symphony of the Night. The game is absolutely gorgeous and brought me similar feelings to when I first booed up SotN back in the late 90s. Deedlit feels lovingly inspired by Alucard's gorgeous animations and the control has been slightly expanded upon on with the introduction of being able to attack in 8 directions, much like in Super Castlevania IV. Despite this, Deedlit feels ever so slightly stiffer than Alucard ever was. Animation canceling through jump attacks is nowhere to be found in the game, which can lead to frustrating situations of feeling like the game isn't responding to your controls. This is most likely to be seen when you’re trying to come down from a jump mid attack and then slide. Deedlit will just proceed to jump back up into whatever you were trying to avoid with glee or even worse, stand perfectly still and get walloped just as hard. There’s also no way to increase your speed in the game as far as I know. Movement enhancing tech, like back dash canceling, shinesparking, or even just a sprint button of some sort, is nowhere to be found. This leads to Deedlit feeling quite slow and makes any form of back-tracking feel more tedious than it should be. The best form of movement is the super jump. I would be lying if I said it wasn’t thrilling to shoot up through the air, it is heavily underutilized and only provides extreme vertical gain. Good for some of the tower rooms, but, not practical for the quick room to room sprinting you may be doing to find that last one percent [spoiler](small hint here, jump a lot)[/spoiler]. Not that the absence of any of this adds much to the game’s difficulty. Every enemy encounter, boss or not, in the game can easily be face-tanked without a second thought due to how easily you can damage race most enemies. Save points are extremely plentiful and are around every corner. Being able to heal by swapping to a tier 3 elemental style feels ridiculous and I never once felt like my life was in danger. I did not die a single time during my play time and any resets came from my own personal challenge, beating all the bosses without taking a single hit. This challenge is something I would recommend if you are to pick Wonder Labyrinth up by the way, otherwise you will blitz through the game from 3 to 6 hours easily. Regardless, while being ultimately less engaging, shorter, stiffer, and easier than SotN in every aspect, this game was still a fun and worthwhile expenditure of my time. I would say its price tag currently is justifiable if you love these style of games, but, you probably already own it if you do. Otherwise, wait for a sale. I don’t think you’ll find yourself disappointed.

90225587.review:
Nothing I can possibly say would begin to describe to how much I enjoyed this game; but I'm going to try anyway.

Let's get comparisons out of the way; Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth is, in summary, similar to playing Team Ladybug's previous side-scrolling maze adventure "Luna Nights," but while simultaneously playing Ikaruga and Momodora: RUTM. The end result is a game that demands skill and strategy from the player while eliminating nearly all reliance on random elements or exploitative tricks.

While some visual similarities with Castlevania: SOTN are apparent, arguably the biggest visual influence is the animated series which provides the source material, Record of Lodoss War. Aside from her basic run cycle, Deedlit's animations and poses are pulled virtually frame-for-frame from the source animation. The same trend can be seen with the game's backgrounds, enemies, and non-player characters.

Now, graded on just the gameplay and visual design, "Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth" would still be a shining example of what small development teams are capable of producing; but it is the story and treatment of expanding the source material that elevates the game to the realm of a masterpiece. I really can't emphasize enough how clever and moving the story ends up by the end, particularly since it could easily have degraded into the trash-tier nonsense typical of most fan projects.

Story spoilers incoming.

[spoiler] Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth explores surprisingly deep themes of resisting change, leaving a legacy of work during your life, and honoring loved ones who have passed away while staying absolutely true to the story and setting of the original work, incorporating elements from the source material. It delves into the pain and sadness Deedlit must have felt outliving all her human friends and loved ones during the centuries which passed since the events of the animated series while still maintaining a hopeful and inspiring overtone, punctuated with an almost chilling final cutscene. [/spoiler] 

If you watched Record of Lodoss War growing up as a child of the 90's, this is a must-play work of art and a challenging but rewarding gameplay experience that is almost certain to make you fall in love with Lodoss War all over again. Stripped of the story elements and for those who aren't familiar with the source anime, the gameplay is *still* powerful enough to carry the title, and it's a great excuse to expose yourself to one of the foundational masterworks of golden-era Japanese Animation.

90161741.review:
Lamento mucho no poder recomendar el juego. 
Para los que nunca hayan jugado un metroivania, es un buen juego como para entrar en el género. Sin embargo a poco que hayas completado algunos de este estilo, Record of Lodoss War aporta muy poco.
Y es una pena tener que decir esto, porque el mismo estudio hizo hace unos años el Tohou Luna Nights que es altamente recomendable, con mecánicas innovadoras para el género, rebosante de personalidad y una banda sonora única. Bueno, todo eso, no lo tiene este  juego muy a mi pesar, porque esperaba mucho de él. 

Eso sería el resumen. Ahora pasaré a desmenuzar cada aspecto del juego a mi opinión. 

- Graficos: sin duda el punto mas alto del juego. Tiene un pixelart hermoso tanto en calidad, como en cantidad de frames de animación. Hace que cada cuadro te haga babear solo con ver a Deeldit caminar. 

- Historia: entiendo que está basado en un anime de antaño, pero no lo he visto. Aún así la historia se sostiene por sí misma y tiene un costado tierno. Es un punto a favor.

- Música: no es mala, pero tampoco destacable. Apenas acompaña, y en algunas zonas es monótona. El Tohou Luna Nights está a años luz en esta cuestión. 

- Jugabilidad: aquí empiezan los problemas. Por empezar el juego te plantea que irás cambiando de modos (viento y fuego), digamos incorporando mecánicas como las del shoot'em up Ikaruga. Al ser un metroivania uno espera que este sistema se vaya complejizando, cambiando a mas tipos de modos y forzándonos a utilizar distintos elementos. Pues no... solo usas esos dos todo el juego. Ademas el personaje prácticamente no cambia jugablemente con un elemento u otro... solamente con viento planeas, y con fuego haces un slide con invulnerabilidad... nada mas en todo el juego. En cuanto a builds es uno de los mayores problemas. Solo tienes 4 tipos de armas mas una: tipos de cuchillos, tipos de estoque, tipos de espada, tipos de espadón, y el bumerang que es único (solo hay uno). El modo de jugar no cambia en absoluto solo son armas mas rápidas o con mas hitbox, y el resto mejoras de estadísticas. Con los arcos pasa lo mismo. Un solo arco cambia un poco la mecánica de disparo y el resto son iguales, pero con mejores estadísticas. En definitiva el personaje cambia poco a lo largo del juego, y es una pena porque con haber utilizado mas elementos, diferenciar mas al personaje según elemento, o que las armas fueran realmente distintas mecánicamente, creo que habría mejorado mucho.

- Diseño de niveles: sin dudas el punto mas flaco del juego. En muchas zonas te encontrarás pudiendo ir a los dos lados de una puerta, sin poder abrir la misma. Esto en un metroidvania me parece inadmisible, porque la mecánica del "puente roto" se siente artificial y completamente arbitraria. En muchas zonas los cuartos simplemente serán un pasillo con enemigos con mucha vida y ya. No se siente que cada cuarto tenga una función mas orgánica o sea distinto de los anteriores. Esto pasaba un poco en el Luna Nights, pero allí los puzzles o las zonas de plataformeo estaban mas inspiradas... aquí comienzan de manera insulsa y terminan de la misma manera, pero con estadísticas mas altas. 

- Dificultad y duración: me ha durado poco mas de 8hs tomándome bastante tiempo para hacer backtracking y explorar. Y a pesar de ser relativamente corto para un metroidvania, me ha parecido largo... pasando la mitad del juego, salvo por la espectacularidad de ciertos bosses ya no esperas mucho del resto del mapeado. La dificultad abusa de las estadísticas para intentar ponerte las cosas mas complicadas y creo que aún así no lo logra... algunos jefes y enemigos simplemente te complican un poco porque te meten un stun de 5 o 6 segundos y el resto simplemente es añadir damage y mas damage. 

Y como si todo esto fuera poco, el juego no tiene logros de Steam... algo que sería anecdótico si todo lo anterior no tirara tan para atrás. 

Una vez mas, lo siento, pero no puedo recomendarle el juego a nadie que haya jugado otro metroidvania antes. Si quieren probar juegos del género que sean poco conocidos, tienen el Tohou Luna Nights que es del mismo estudio, y otros como Valdis Story, Kunai, 3000th Duel, o Minoria. Todos ellos les darán algún punto alto de innovación jugable o de estilo que no encontrarán en Record of Lodos, salvo, el simple hecho de ser exageradamente bonito. 

Un saludo, y si mas adelante actualizan el juego mejorando estas cuestiones, cambiaré mi recomendación.

A quick spoiler free note about the story: if you have seen or read the Record of Lodoss War, you will be fine. TL;DR Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth is a beautiful Castlevania style game that's fun to play. Recommended.

-Movement feels *mostly* tight but certain things like quickly swapping between attacking left and right doesn't work

90088520.review:
Hey!  You got your Ikaruga in my Symphony of the Night!

Record of Lodoss War: Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth is a fun little game, very obviously inspired by Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, but throwing in enough new material to... not be original, but at least not feel stale.

If you're familiar with "Metroidvanias" as a genre, there isn't much to add in terms of the gameplay here.  It's a bit more linear than most, with the whole castle being traversable, but still clearly divided into stages (even with a scene transition preceding each one.)  What sets it apart is Deedlit's spirits.  She can switch between Sylph and Salamander, with some enemies being weaker to one than the other, and Deedlit herself being able to absorb attacks of the element she's currently attuned to.  Absorbing attacks helps to refill MP (which regenerates anyway, but absorption refills it much faster.)

Story-wise, you're likely to get a lot more out of it if you're already familiar with the Record of Lodoss War story and characters.  While it's very clear that the main character is dealing with loss and an inability to accept that loss, you'll feel a lot more for her if you know just who Deedlit, Parn, Ghim, Etoh, Slayn, Woodchuck, and all of the other characters are.

Don't expect the game to take a long time to complete.  My first playthrough, visiting every corner of the map, took me under 8 hours.  But it was an enjoyable experience, and I'd recommend it if you want a more easy-going Metroidvania adventure.

89995266.review:
It puzzles me how this game has such a high review score.

TL;DR: a short mediocre Metroidvania game. It's not necessarily bad, but it is boring to explore and does not really do anything interesting with the formula, nor does it execute it particularly well. Looks great though.

Let's get good things out of the way:
- the game is gorgeous: amazing art, great animations, decent backgrounds
- music is kinda good, but more on that later
- some game mechanics are genuinely good, Ikaruga style of switching element is great
- despite its shortcomings, does not outstay its welcome - it is short enough to stay mildly enjoyable

Now, the reasons why I don't really recommend this game.

The first and most important thing, the thing I love the genre for: sense of wonder and exploration. It is just not present here. The map is uninspired and boring to explore. The variety of layouts is lacking, a lot of similar rooms with the same backgrounds. Exploration is surprisingly unrewarding, there is barely any point to it.

Combat is... It's there, it's present and functional. Most enemies take a lot of time to wind up their attacks, so for the most part you can destroy them before they even do anything. Any damage you take throws you away across half of the screen, staggers galore and after getting hit multiple times, you get staggered for even longer. As a result a single hit can easily result in game over. Some of the attacks are almost impossible to avoid, so it makes sense to make the wind up longer. It doesn't make the game any more exciting though. Bosses are a pleasant exception, but they are few and far between, as you would expect.

Story makes so little sense it seems intentional. It is either very dependent on the player being aware of the setting, characters and lore, or the translation is bad. Most of the time I was as confused as the protagonist. Ending barely gives any answers.

Music just plays on the loop while you explore an area. It's generally not that bad, but gets old eventually. There's too much of it and the variety is lacking.

The game is rather short, but considering all the shortcomings, it's really not a bad thing. It barely outstays its welcome. 3 hours give or take are enough to complete it without obsessing too much about 100% it.

89990050.review:
This is what a current Metroidvania game should look like. 

* Though using the standard toolset for Metroidvanias (i.e. Double Jump, etc), it still adds enough of its own gameplay mechanics, so it always feels like your walking a very well know path, but something feels nicely different. 
* The pixel art style is off the charts, with beautiful animations for friends and foes alike. 
* Backtracking is optional and, praise Cthulhu, kept to a Minimum. You want that weapon that is just slightly better than the one you're using? Okay, take a detour of 4 minutes. 
* The game takes 5 hours to complete 100%. Yes. This is GOOD. Look at your library and weep for all the games you want to play, but don't have the time. 5 hours for a game is awesome.

89921306.review:
Alright, I've gotten up to the start of the 4th area so I think I've seen enough to be certain about my misgivings. This is, like, half of a good game.

The level design in this game is just okay. It's a lot of corridors and shafts without much variation. The only real difference between areas is enemies and visuals. If this game is supposed to be inspired by Symphony of the Night then it didn't really learn that the areas need to be laid out differently, complete with interesting rooms and landmarks here and there. Exploration just isn't terribly interesting or fun in this game.

The music is frankly not great. The tracks are mostly meandering musical noise. Again, not great if you're intentionally evoking comparison to Castlevania. It matters!

Mechanically the game is interesting, with the bow and the Ikaruga-like elemental system. These things are utilized well for the bosses, which are easily the best thing about this game. I can't say the same about most of the rest of the enemies which you can mostly just hack through. Also there are some bow puzzles but they aren't exactly brain teasers.

Honestly I feel like this game would have been better off if it didn't try to be a metroidvania and was just more of a straightforward action game. Which I know is obliterating the entire point of the work, but frankly the metroidvania aspects of this game are its weakest points.

If I could give a game a "meh" that wasn't a Yes or a No, I would for this one.

89830110.review:
RoLW:DiWL manages to simultaneously be a great Metroidvania game, a spiritual successor to Symphony of the Night, and an awesome homage to Lodoss War--all while having an identity of its own.  Switching back and forth between wind and fire elements gives the game an Ikaruga-like mechanic, while the bow offers some simple physics-based puzzles and added combat options.  The weapon loot is all here too; with different stats, animations, and visual designs for each of them.
Above all, great care is given to the animation, background and monster design, and music.  This might be the best Metroidvania I've played that's NOT developed by Koji Igarashi.  And it's $20. Show it some love with a purchase.

89817443.review:
Steam needs a "middle" button.  I mainly bought this because of my experience with Bloodstained.  I have no experience as a kid playing SOTN.  I am aware of the SOTN "genre" but never played a SOTN style game until I backed Bloodstained.

Compared to BS, this game is very short.  We're looking at 4-6 hours of playtime if you power through it, more if you are trying to 100% it.  It feels very much like a "side story" version of a full game.  I personally got this because I am an older millennial that watched anime during the same time this series was prevalent.  Seeing such an old license/franchise being turned into a game was quite a pleasant surprise.

Otherwise this game fits the Metroidvania formula to a tee.  You pick up items along the way to give yourself additional abilities, and weapon and bow upgrades can be found if you search far enough into various nooks and crannies.  If you find yourself unable to make a certain ledge or have a door locked in front of you, you will have to come back at a later time to access it, usually with a newfound ability or some sort of universal Super Mario World-esque "P switch" you'll hit after a boss battle.

Boss battles were kind of a brute-force sorta deal for me, but there's plenty of opportunities to find blind spots and weak points for bosses if you try hard enough.  Gameplay itself is solid.  The Ikaruga-style element switching system is kind of interesting though it's not my cup of tea.  Combat is fairly straightforward.  Triangle for bow, Cross for melee.  There isn't a "combo" or special move system like there is with BS.

The map compared to BS' map is pretty small and straightforward.  Lots of save spots and transport areas.  Fair amount of backtracking to advance the game.  Controls are tight but this game has a lot of "take a hit and fall into something that makes it worse" moments, more so than BS.

The story is kind of straightforward.  It is more or less a very short "OVA" of what happens after the entire anime finishes, I believe.  Won't spoil the ending.

Graphics are beautiful.  Old school painfully crafted 2D sprites and animations.  So many characters were drawn and I was hoping I'd be able to play them in the future.  Speaking of content, that's also one of the weak points of this game.  It lacks a serious amount of content.  There are no extra modes, no gallery, no higher difficulties, no way to "replay" endings.  Also, for it being a Steam game, there are no Steam-related achievements or trading cards or anything that takes advantage of the Steam platform.  This game could've just been released elsewhere.

I really hope they do more of this franchise.  Something based off of Pirotess, for example would be awesome.  This game has excellent foundations for a full-blown game, but it just doesn't have enough "meat" to it to make me heartily recommend it.  It's a solid game, and I'd say $20 for this game is fair, but man I wish there was more to it and something that'll make it worth me replaying it.

That being said, I do hope this is like a precursor for something even bigger.  The Record of Lodoss War franchise has huge potential and if they make the right games off of it a new generation of gamers (along with us older gamers) can enjoy it for years to come.

So is this a recommended?  If you're looking for something to scratch your SOTN itch after you're done with Bloodstained, yes.  If you're a ROLW franchise fan, yes.  However, if you're the type of person who dislikes "short" games, you may want to wait until a sale or additional content comes out.

89753511.review:
A somewhat linear Metroidvania. You progress through "stages" and only ever really go back to unlock hidden areas for optional equipment. A rather short game as well as I beat it under 7 hours and seemingly so has a friend of mine who recommended the game to me.

Where this game shines is the mechanics some new and some old. The game itself handles similar to Castlevania : Symphony of the Night. The game has a castlevania-like backdash, adds more directions with which you can angle your attacks, implements a straightforward magic system where you swap through spells/items, and gives you a bow which can angle up or down from a horizontal starting point. Arrows from you bow take mp and can bounce off of walls.

The most unique mechanic the game has is in the two spirits you aquire early on, a wind and a fire spirit. Switching spirits is mapped to it's own button which is a central mechanic to movement and managing enemy attacks. When you are hit with an attack of the same element you absorb the attack as MP rather than taking damage somewhat like the classic SHMUP Ikaruga. When you defeat an enemy or attack a boss with one spirit equipped the other one gains levels up to a maximum of level 3. These levels increase the damage you do when that spirit is equipped as well as at level 3 you will regenerate health points. If you are hit then you lose a level on the equipped spirit. This system encourages clever management of which spirit you are holding to if you take a hit and when you attack with the other spirit to recover spirit gauge. In addition to this mechanic the wind spirit also has the extra utility of allowing you to fly when it is equipped but you can only fly as high as you would be able to jump. 

I normally wouldn't say much about the plot of the game as that aspect isn't usually too important to my enjoyment of the game but this game takes place in the universe of a Japanese series of Fantasy Novels called "Record of Lodoss War". You don't need to be familiar with this series to understand the plot but it will help you recognize characters as they come up giving you a understanding of the history they share. If you aren't familiar the plot is straightforward enough to follow. Apparently this also is a prequel to the latest novel in the series which if you google the title of in the USA you get pages on this game instead so the game segues into a unrelated story which you probably won't be able to easily get access to.

Overall the game pulls off what it sets out to do fairly well. It's a short yet quality experience which I recommend to fans of somewhat linear style metroidvania games.

89741211.review:
Pros: SOTN etc etc, great game, hope to see more since they have an engine worked out, bit short

Cons: I tend to complain about soundtracks and I won't disappoint here: as with most of its elements, the game's OST aims to capture the grandiose splendor of the SOTN OST and it's frustrating how close it comes without ever getting there. 

The composer manages to capture the big, roomy production of the original, but fails to make the tracks memorable or particularly compelling. This is mostly due to an avoidance or outright omission of melody: rarely does any instrument come out of the woodwork to declare itself, and when it does it meanders about before wandering back into the cacophony. This results in 90% of the OST sounding like undefined boss fight ambiance, even in areas that would benefit from something understated. The Castlevania games are as defined by their soundtracks as they are by their gameplay and storylines, and I was hoping to see that mirrored here. Unfortunately though, this OST consists of ingredients but never comes together to make a meal.

Excellent metroidvania that has a host of very interesting and rewarding gameplay mechanics, providing surprising depth to the combat and exploration, and all of them well grounded within the canon of the setting, and never feeling terribly out of character.

Fairly short game, can be beaten within about 4 hours, even shorter once you know where to go. 89645078.review:
This game isn't a metroidvania.

It surely has some elements of it, but some traits are so poorly designed it just makes the game unfun to play.
I was looking for this game and at its release, I bought the bundle with Touhou Luna Nights.
Let's say I was pretty disappointed, I could hardly have fun with theses games.
I'm sorry this review is going to be stuffed.

[h1]Map Design[/h1]
Your overall path to the end is really linear, and though there may be one or two very little branching paths, that's because one of them is a dead end with nothing yet to do because you were supposed to go left instead of right and get back to the right just after.
Progressing through the game is just: opening the map, searching the marked coloured blocked way you found earlier, going here, you're done. No "striking, memorable and understandable" blocked path like any other game of the genre, it's probably just another coloured door. Completing is the same but on every corner of the map.
Moreover, the fact that you finish the game with 95% map completion really bothers me, I didn't even try too much backtracking, but maybe I'm just used to metroidvanias. Something to note is that breakable walls are a little different, which reduces the "I'm gonna hit every single wall", so that's at least good.
But sadly I'm not done with the levels, I'm briefly going to mention the final area because of its downright evil enemy positions. In their previous game, Touhou Luna Nights, annoyingly long screens were avoidable thanks to the freeze time effect, but in this game, you cannot even "fly above them" because of dragons taking the entire corridor while another shoots you from behind it. Remember the example I gave with going right then left then right? Yeah.

[h1]Boss Fights[/h1]
Bosses are supposed to be a test of skills for the players, does he understand how to play, and does he have the right to continue?
Some of the patterns involving switching elements do elevate that point, but some really don't, let me explain the latter.
Many bosses in this game are fast, REALLY fast, I'm talking 0.2s long anticipation animations, with a pattern that couldn't be guessed. That means that the 3-4 first try you're going to have with a boss, you're going to tank a lot of new patterns you didn't know. And I hope you remembered every one of them, and their order too, because they mostly all respect a strict pattern. Having the bosses have only a single intended way to fight them just make them non-engaging, they become no more than chores.
And to make that point even worse, the last fight before the final one is a Boss Rush... I hope you still have your mental notes on every bosses' patterns!
There are few bosses that aren't really like that, but these ones often have a really obvious and exploitable weak point, involving magic spells or not, making them even less interesting.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
Brief note on this: I don't know how you are supposed to play with the default button mapping, this was an issue on Luna Nights too, I don't know how you are physically able to tap/hold/spam simultaneously or differently two buttons with the same finger to jump/hover and attack. Anyway, it is rebindable so that's good, my main issue in this paragraph is the fact that during an attack animation, the "down + jump" input, the one to slide, makes you jump instead of slide (or it could do nothing too), which is annoying for precise battles.

[h1]Credit where credit's due[/h1]
Artistically speaking, the game is gorgeous, really good visuals and music. I can't really recall any melody, but the soundtrack does its job, and I remember some levels' theme slapping, so I'm good.
Weapons all have different sprites, which is a good thing despite them being tossed when you find a better one.
The story might be good, sadly it's hardly understandable without knowing the original material.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Overall, there isn't much to do. Replaying the game will probably be 95% the same.
I finished the game in 5 hours, I could probably complete the remaining percentage of the map in thirty minutes or so, but I didn't. I don't mind short experiences, but I'm starting to get pissed when this experience is called by every review "a great metroidvania".
If you want a real game of this genre, please play Bloodstained or Hollow Knight.

tl;dr good looks, questionable game, bad metroidvania
