89613987.review:
[h1]Very good game for fans of Igavania style games[/h1]

Record of Lodoss War is a straight up Igavania tribute. If you love those style of games there is a lot to like here and considering the budget price, I would recommend you just buy it. No need for any more info than that really. If you're on the fence I'll try to put into words why this game is good and worth the price but could have been great.

A lot of people compare this game to Castlevania Symphony of the night (SOTN) but I think it's closer to Igas GBA and DS games like the Aria/Dawn games. The map is much smaller in scale than SOTN and the rooms themselves are smaller as well. SOTN really feels like a long journey through many different and varied environments while in this game the environments mostly look and feel the same. It has the standard castle interiors, underground tombs and caves and while they all look good, actually traversing them is mostly the same. The room complexity is also very simple which is why I compared it earlier to the GBA Igavanias. Those games were obviously hindered by the technical limits of their respective platforms. So, I'm sort of surprised that in this much newer game developed on modern platform is so simple in room layout. There are no large outdoor areas here and little in verticality in the rooms compared to SOTN.
The difficulty is also on par with those earlier mentioned games. Normal enemies are never much of a threat but the bosses get progressively harder with more and varied patterns to learn. It never really gets hard though.

There is surprisingly little to explore and the way forward is mostly obvious so the pathfinding aspect of these types of games is not here. There are secret paths and what not but they never really lead to new areas of secret bosses or anything like that. It's almost always just a dead-end small room with an item or upgrade in it. And speaking of items there's a lot of weapons in this game which combined with the small map means you find new weapons every couple of minutes. There were several times where I've just found a new weapon stronger than my last and just started to use it and then after a couple of screens, I found another even stronger weapon. I sort of wished the game gave me some time and space to actually use the new weapons I found.

Now it might seem like I'm overly negative to a small indie-developed title but the market is saturated with Igavania and metroidvania style games so the bar is quite high here. But with that being said let's get on with what Record of Lodoss War does well.

The graphics are wonderful and animation is fluid especially on Deedlith. Lots of different animations for the different weapons and controls are tight and responsive. Controlling this game just feels great and this is an absolute requirement for this type of game I feel. You get movement type unlocks like you would expect and they are great. The double jump you get especially feels great, probably one of the nicest double jump mechanics done in this type of game. Movement speed feels perfect and you get nice evasive options like slide and dodge. Although I wished for an air dodge as well especially towards the end of the game.

As for other mechanics there is a polarity system in this game. Basically, think of games like Ikaruga where your enemies mostly attack in one of two polarities and you can absorb the same polarity. I absolutely love this system and it really saved the game for me as it made normal encounters more varied and boss fights more interesting. BTW another game that is also in this style with a polarity system is Outland. Go play it if you haven't, it’s great.

The music is good with nice variety. Although the different tunes didn't hook me immediately like many of the SOTN tracks they started to grow on me after a couple of run through the areas.

Technically the game is solid; everything works as it should. Controller support was plug’n’play for xinput at least.

So, to sum up I’ll still recommend this game if you are a fan of Iga’s Castlevania games and other type of similar games. It does more rights than wrongs and it’s just lacking in a couple of areas to be truly great. If you like Record of Lodoss War as well it helps you understand some of the things going on but the game is very light on story so I don’t feel like this is a requirement. The game also sort of sets up for a sequel so I really hope that this game is successful enough for that to happen.

A short but sweet, modestly challenging experience. I got 6 hours out of it. 

I wish it was longer. It feels too short. There are some unique mechanics with Deedlit's spirits and her bow, but this feels more introductory than a lasting experience. 

When I finally felt like I had a handle on everything, the game was over. The final encounter was the only one to give me any serious trouble. 

There isn't much alternative exploration and the quest is quite linear. Don't expect the Metroidvania ability to sequence break as there are doors you can only open through progression. There are also abilities that prohibit exploration of areas outside of the newest unlocked "zone." 

You might only return to a previous zone to explore a handful of additional rooms. There are hidden rooms, but they're painfully obvious and don't require much imagination or exploration to find. If there are any truly hidden rooms, I never found any. 

I recommend it as it is a fun experience, but I suggest getting it on a sale. I feel $20 is a bit much for something that doesn't have any replay-ability and can be beaten so quickly.

89580630.review:
[h1]UN BUEN EJEMPLO DE COMO HACER UN METROIDVANIA[/h1]

Siempre he sido fan de Record of Lodoss War, me he leído sus mangas varias veces y he visto el anime y en cuanto descubrí que iban a hacer un juego indie basado en la saga me alegré pero, sabiendo que era Early Access, decidí esperar hasta que saliese. Y bueno, vaya grata sorpresa.

Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth es un metroidvania dividido en 6 áreas (o fases, como indica el juego) en el que avanzaremos eliminando enemigos, sorteando diversas plataformas y combatiendo con desafiantes jefes. Todo esto con la ayuda de dos espíritus, uno de viento y otro de fuego, que nos permitirán explotar las debilidades de nuestros adversarios, así como ayudarnos a atravesar algunas zonas peligrosas. 

Uno de los mayores puntos a favor del juego es su duración. Como podéis observar, podréis terminar el juego en unas 5 horas con un 100% del mapa y es más que suficiente. Sí, ojalá hubiese durado un poco más, pero esta duración hace que el ritmo del juego sea perfecto y enganche hasta el final. Si te gusta el género (en especial juegos como Hollow Knight, Blasphemous o Castlevania: Symphony of the Night) sin duda este Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth te gustará. Y si eres fan de Record of Lodoss War, jugar con uno de los personajes más emblemáticos de la saga, te hará cosquillitas en el corazoncito.

tl;dr Play this if you're absolutely starved for metroidvanias and have already played Luna Nights

Again, I wish there was a "neutral" rating option, because despite being a massive letdown for me, it's still very enjoyable.
I'm gonna focus on gameplay in this review, the controls, artstyle and animations are great, story and music are okay. 

This game borrows ideas and mechanics heavily from Team Ladybugs previous game, "Touhou Luna Nights" and obviously SotN, and yet it's somehow way worse than both of these games. 
Game's too short, the basic enemies and bosses are way too easy- you'll spend 90% of the encounters just mashing the attack button (the attack has only ONE animation for each weapon type, it isn't 1997 anymore) and spamming the skills whenever you can, puzzles are as basic as they get and it still suffers from the same problem Luna Nights had where the devs artificially spike the difficulty by spawning 20 enemies in every room and making you backtrack through it 4 times, because thats fun. 
The enemy moveset and boss patterns are uninspired and so are the skills MC uses, and even though I recognize that the developers may've been limited by the source material it still isn't an excuse.

No achievements as of 1.0 either, or other modes like Luna Nights had. Not nearly enough content for the full price (compared to other steam games of this type), you can easily beat it in about 3h if you don't go looking for all the secret items. 

5/10 - Disappointing

89540321.review:
Team Ladybug's second game (on Steam) after Luna Nights & it's another banger. A metroidvania based on Record of the Lodoss War (which I haven't actually seen but I've only ever heard good things). Like Luna Nights, the game has its own unique gameplay elements & gimmicks on top of the familiar metroidvania design.
 
In Wonder Labyrinth you play as Deedlit the elf & use a variety of weapons & magic, but it departs from the usual formula in the beginning by giving you 2 spirits: fire & wind. These spirits give you immunity to their respective element & the wind spirit also allows you limited flight. Later you acquire a bow & arrow & find you can ricochet arrows off metal surfaces & use them to activate various machines throughout the world. You use these tools to travel through the labyrinth, look for treasure & fight a variety of bosses.
Now metroidvanias can have problems w/ obtuse design & messy pacing that relies on a lot of backtracking. But Wonder Labyrinth doesn't have this problem thanks to world design that provides plenty of ways to get to its various levels & the liberal placement of teleportation gates.

My only complaints are that there are these magic doors sealed by colored magic seals (red, green, yellow, etc.) that are unlocked by pressing a correspondingly colored switch, press the switch & all doors of that color are unlocked throughout the world. Now these locked doors aren't an issue themselves, rather there doesn't seem to be a way to see which ones you have unlocked. Also the enemy placement can be a bit cheap sometimes, but that's an issue in basically every metroidvania. A little annoying, but relatively minor issues.

89474378.review:
Very good spin on classic Castlevania: Symphony of the Night mechanics. If you liked that, you'll like this. At the current writing of this review the game says I'm at 61% map completion; that means I should hit 100% around 6 hours at my current pace. This might mean the game is kind of short.

Deedlit can equip a melee weapon and a bow. There are a few different types of melee weapons, and the majority feel the same to use. All that really changes for most of them is their speed and damage. There are some that are different, like the two-handed swords and a boomerang I found at one point (which was really fun to use). The bows are mostly just upgrades of one another, although some have extra effects such as shooting multiple arrows at once.

There's an element switching mechanic reminiscent of Ikaruga (a shoot 'em up) between Air and Fire, and some enemies are weak/resistant to various elements. You also gain the resistance to whatever element you are currently using, so if, say, an enemy shoots a fireball at you while you have the fire spirit swapped in you will absorb the damage.

A bit more linear than other action adventure games I've played like this, but I'm having tons of fun and I feel like the game was worth what I payed.

Ikaruga bullet-hell color mechanics don't work when the screen is this busy.

Seriously, this is among the best FEELING and LOOKING platformers I've played in a bit and it's completely ruined by red and blue garbage flying everywhere and the 15 different UI elements you need to check to make sure you're on the right color. The thing is, they clearly knew this was important to know, because your color is indicated by the UI, your sprite, and the particle effects, but if anything this just adds to the screen clutter.

I'm going to keep playing it and I'll update the review if things change but this game is a reminder that "bad graphics" can mean more than just style and fidelity.

Edit: Yeah I'm gonna file this game under "unplayable" for me personally right now because looking at the parts with heavy action makes me feel dizzy in a way games, especially 2d ones, almost never do.

89462863.review:
An unfortunate case of style over substance. The beautifully animated pixel art and brilliant soundtrack cannot make up for subpar gameplay which offer very little in terms of fun and engagement. 
Exploration is very barebones, upgrades are too straightforward and combat feels either too easy or too messy with no middle ground. Even the most interesting mechanics, such as the ability to absorb elemental attacks for various benefits, end up being a detriment to the game: case in point, most enemy attacks are designed to cover lots of space (to encourage absorbing them rather than dodging them), but this leads to a cluttered screen where it's difficult to track your own character and impossible to read what the enemy's doing. Having beaten most bosses through sheer muscle memory due to very repetitive patterns (easy to memorize, hard to react to) I can't really speak highly of either the AI or the encounter design.
In short, for me the game couldn't follow the captivating beginning and the promise of a good metroidvania. There's a lot of polish and care for sure, but not in the most essential areas in my opinion.

89457268.review:
I watched the Record of Lodoss War anime and OVA over 15 years ago. I forgot they existed until this game came out. It was a pleasant surprise when it did. I still remember most characters, but I have to admit I'm not an expert on the lore. That said, the story felt somewhat silly and not that deep, but it didn't take anything away from the experience. I just wanted to kill stuff and farm loot. Which brings me to my next point.

I'm not a big fan of the looting system. Very few enemies actually have drops (only 2 to 5 per level). There are no miscellaneous loot to sell or to craft things. Major missed opportunity there. Instead, enemies straight up drop gold. You also can't sort your inventory. 

Deedlit moves very freely and gracefully and it feels good using most weapons in the game. The bows can be very strong, especially with the right element, since your regular weapons are limited to fire and wind. Spells are very underwhelming. They take unnecessary time to cast and are not that powerful 90% of the time. However it's possible to take advantage of the mp drain mechanic and spam spells like there's no tomorrow, in some situations. No familiars as well, however your fire and wind spirits do attack on their own every now and then for neglectable damage.

There are some minor puzzle elements, all of them using the bow. They are not very unique or hard. You don't get access to a lot of mobility abilities. Maybe because the rooms are self-contained and not that big, which would make such abilities not that valuable.

It should take most players 4 to 6 hours to 100% the game. It's not that long and not very hard. Enemy AI is underwhelming, too.

All the bad things aside, I still recommend this game because I'm a huge fan of the genre, but if you want a better, more complete metroidvania experience, then the game I recommend the most is Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night. It is one of the best games of the genre since SOTN. It's more expensive than this, but it lasts for several more hours. Hollow Knight is another great game that you should check out if you haven't already.

89453873.review:
As a huge fan of both Symphony of the Night and the 1990 Record of Lodoss War OVA, I have to admit that I was excited - very excited, to play this game. And yes, it lived up to the hype.

Now to address the elephant in the room: [b]is this as good as SoTN[/b]?
No, BUT it's the closest thing to a true successor to date. And no, it's not just another one of those half-assed "metroidvania" indie clones that get shat out every other day. This is the real deal. This is the good shit.

Initially I was concerned it'd be a clone with no originality, but that isn't true. In this game there are two kinds of elementals that you switch between. Attacks of the same type won't hurt you, and will give you magic to perform spells with. Attacking an enemy of the opposing type will do more damage and is sometime the only way to damage an enemy. This creates a lot of interesting risk and reward scenarios, but the game doesn't make the most of them because it lacks difficulty. There isn't any new game + or optional super-boss, so be expected to blast through the game in under 5 hours.

I'm tempted to prattle on about why this isn't be best metroidvania, but it wouldn't be fair to the developers. SoTN was a full-priced triple-A game; this by comparison is an indie title that I got for $10 (early access sale). It is absolutely worth paying full-price for, even if you've never heard of the anime.

If the developers ever read this, then I want to say to you:

Great job. This is the best game I've played in a long, long time.
よくやった。これは私が長い間プレイした中で最高のゲームです。

I feel like this game was made just for me, as both a big Record of Lodoss War fan, and as someone for whom Symphony of the Night was an extremely formative game. This game is like Metroidvania comfort food, and I'm here to say it's delicious.

I'm not necessarily [i]skilled[/i] at Metroidvania games, so I can't speak to the difficulty being easy/difficult. But Wonder Labyrinth gives me all of the same comfort and vibes that playing SotN did for the first time when I was 13. Combat feels intuitive, but the element dancing mechanic gives some more complexity to the combat system. The puzzle mechanics with arrows and doors are a satisfying change of pace, too. If you're a Lodoss War fan, every time a familiar face shows up as you progress through the game, it feels like a tug at the heartstrings: like you're greeting old friends you haven't seen for about as long since we've been under lockdown and socially distant from real life friends. 

I can't wait to finish it and probably keep playing it for the good vibes that it gives me. If you enjoy the genre, or you're a Lodoss War fan, pick this up!

89392251.review:
Pros: top notch combat and bosses, fluid controls and mild platforming, intuitive map exploration
Cons: short length, story. If you can picture the most obnoxious, obtuse, 100 hour overly long and wordy JRPG story where you just want to button mash through dialogue, this is the complete opposite of that. At the endgame the story picks up, but my sense was there is a lot more story to tell to develop the main and supporting characters, and that would have been welcomed. 

I honestly had zero idea what the hell was going with the story until probably stage 5. I was completely confused what was going on and who the NPCs were throughout EA. Regardless, this is a lovely, yet short game honoring SOTN with really fluid combat mechanics. The bosses were insanely well balanced, which is a rarity these days in metroidvanias. I could not believe how satisfying it was to 1) initially die because my default face-tank strategy didn't work for the boss 2) learn the boss patterns after 2-3 tries, 3) kill the boss after a handful of deaths spent perfecting patterns 4) that the devs don't force you to cycle through pre-combat dialogue again, straight to action. This is not a punishing die 100x and maybe you squeak by once you have muscle memory down. Not brutally punishing with platforming or platforming during boss battles, but rewarding in that you can't tank right through bosses. It's clear the devs approached combat with care and are sophisticated about the difficulty level. 

Hidden/breakable areas are done really well, it rewards the player who attacks all the walls and is paying attention to the map for where there should be additional rooms. I 100%'d the map and finished in approximately 11 hours, and I only had to look up a guide for the jump secret room. I can't remember if I jumped 50x or down attacked numerous times to open it, but if there's a breakable hidden wall, as a rule of thumb, it should open on the first time you specifically attack that wall, or there should be some indication you're on the right track (crumbling, change the tile patterns to show damage). 

Gating areas via color coded switches is done well, however, post EA content in stages 4-6, it's pretty formulaic fast travel and check the gate, and pick up a weapon that isn't as strong as what you currently are running. In this sense, the gating felt a bit linear post EA content, as there were typically 1-2 gates to go back and check. My suggestion would be to house additional areas and content here, not just another bow or chakra to add to my collection of weapons.

Spoiler perhaps, the epilogue is fantastic. Always enjoy when a game ends with a short warm fuzzy epilogue.

The only bug I encountered was due to me trying to find secrets/break the game: in the desert pyramid in the dragon battle room, with a fully upgraded jump I could jump off the map and fall forever until game over when I fell through the map. The only ability gating spot I got stuck / had to reset was prior to getting the fully upgraded jump, I tried to force progressing by pogoing off the ghosts to clear the high jump, and couldn't repeat the pogo again to make it back. 

6/6 dice rolls, would love to play for another 10+ hours if the devs decide to add more content post full release.

89361177.review:
This is the most recent metroivania (excluding the usual shovelware spammed onto steam) to be released (as of March 30 2021) and the penultimate game on my list of singleplayer non-roguelike games to play. This game is made by the same studio that brought the world Touhou Luna nights which is one of the best metroidvanias on steam. This game is good but it does not live up to its predecessor. It is nonetheless a real enjoyment to play and it recommended for all fans of metroidvanias. 

The good:
- The story. If, like me, you're not a fan of anime then nothing is going to make any sense... that is, until  you reach the final boss... at that point the story will hit like a pile of bricks. One of a very small number of metroidvanias that managed to make me cry.
- The animation
- sound effects
- map
- I was able to defeat the final boss, can't say the same about Touhou Luna nights.
- the gameplay.

The bad:
- As with all team ladybug games, the UI sucks. However, as always, you'll get used to it and figure out how things work through trial and error as the game progresses. (hint: While you may only be able to grant fire and wind attributes, your spells have their own separate attributes)
- the music.
- Virtually no improvements over touhou luna nights and pharaoh rebirth besides the design of the save points.
- stun locks used as a way of artificially making the game harder.

89359604.review:
This is yet another pixel art metroidvania from Krobon/Team Ladybug. This developer usually works out a deal with an IP holder and makes a short but bombastic metroidvania with great art and music. So far, they've made [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ExVQ01fQwjk]Shin Megami Tensei: Synchronicity Prologue[/url], [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tjUPcb_MIDw]KonoSuba: The Resurrection of Beldia[/url], [url=store.steampowered.com/app/851100]Touhou Luna Nights[/url] and now this. This game is very similar to Touhou Luna Nights in particular, just with a coat of Record of Lodoss War paint and a different gameplay gimmick ([url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/253750/Ikaruga/]Ikaruga[/url] like polarity switching instead of time stopping), even the UI and many animations are very similar. The progression is likewise largely gated by color coded doors/keys instead of relying on abilities.

Another obvious inspiration is [b]Castlevania: Symphony of the Night[/b]. Many of Deedlit's animations are directly patterned over Alucard, in particular her walk cycle and how she swings swords, and all the cloak stuff. And just like in Castlevania you get a large selection of weapons, such as longswords, greatswords, clubs, spears, daggers, boomerangs etc. And then your second weapon slot is the bow, resulting in a gameplay loop similar to [url=store.steampowered.com/app/428550]Momodora: Reverie Under The Moonlight[/url]. However unlike Momodora your bow shots cannot be charged, you can aim up/down instead and there's also a ricochet mechanic allowing for some simple puzzles. The third and last gear slot is for spells. They aren't terribly interesting and you'll probably end up spamming the very first spell for the whole game, as it has great tracking and a very good damage output to mana usage ratio.

If you've never played Ikaruga, the polarity thing is basically switching between two elements (blue/wind and orange/fire in this case) to guard against projectiles and target enemy weaknesses. Other games that used a similar mechanic are [url=store.steampowered.com/app/305050]Outland[/url] and [url=store.steampowered.com/app/220440]DmC: Devil May Cry[/url], off the top of my head. It adds decent variety, and spells and some bows can override it with other elements if you don't feel like switching all the time.

Now for the bad stuff:
- The game is very short. Only a little over 5 hours if you don't farm enemy drops, and there's no side content whatsoever, no optional quests or secret bosses.
- Very little challenge. Enemies are very passive, 95% of the time you can kill them before they do anything at all. Bosses aren't that well designed either, their patterns are all over the place and they attack with little telegraphing, but you deal so much damage it doesn't really matter.
- The story is largely nonsensical and just an excuse to give spotlight to as many licensed characters as possible. If you're not a hardcore fan of Record of Lodoss War it will make very little sense, as the game doesn't bother introducing anyone.

But even so, I still feel the game is worth playing. It's beautiful, fast paced and very polished. If you want more of Touhou Luna Nights (or just enjoy Krobon's work in general) then this is a no-brainer.

89349118.review:
[b]PSA (since the developer didn't care about)[/b]
[hr][/hr]
[h1]!!! SEVERE PHOTO-SENSITIVITY WARNING !!![/h1]
[b]If you have problems with flickering lights, STEER CLEAR[/b]
[hr][/hr]

[b]TL;DR:[/b] If you already played Touhou Luna Nights, it's more of the same. Competent overall design mixed with the everything you-already-know, just in another setting. If you want something new and fresh, or you don't care about Lodoss lore, just ignore it and you wont miss it.

[h1]the not-TL;DR[/h1]
It's competent, but it lacks anything that might serve well metroidvanias or that can help verily distinguish one from another. It's a good example of "how to do what everyone already does or has done, with minimal innovation and good quality standard". You won't miss the "Got a new key/ability! Time for hours of backtracking opening all those new doors!" that can feel so great (/sarcasm) since you can't judge whether what you might find may actually help you in a short term or if it'll be just a minor bonus or a not-even-neat weapon. Compulsive searching!!! Yay!!1 Goes specially nice with the lack of fast locomotion modes so present in other metroidvanias that actually have some sense on the size of their maps and include less roundabout ways, shortcuts and faster movement mechanics. Only the sparse teleportation rooms to serve you here.

Also, whose idea was to put a huge chunk of meat to serve as special gauge regeneration? Really? At that point we already know that beating people gets special gauge (and MP), but then putting us to repeatedly [b]beat the meat[/b]? Why not just make a different save statue that does both saving and restores everything? Oh, so two chunks of metal-chain-suspended meat can be inside the boss room in case you need to quickly beat the meat mid-fight.. now I get it. Maybe it was a reference I missed on the anime, manga, original novels, and/or other games?

In case you're wondering "why diss the game so much if the review is positive?", it's simple. I played Tohou Luna Nights and liked the design and competence of the devs. When I saw them again with another lore I like, I didn't even think. But I expected more of them. I expected them to learn and improve, not just move laterally. Now the map is bigger, a pain to travel through sometimes, which made back-tracking worse, and nothing else has really changed. Just another competent game. But that's what they promised. And I can't judge them based on a ratio between expectation/delivery, I need to judge based on the ratio between delivery/promise.

What I can do is not look forward to another work from them.

89338472.review:
So glad the full release is out so a proper review can be given.

Some may call this a Sotn clone but Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth is an entirely fantastic Metroidvania on its own. The soundtrack is amazing, the gameplay is smooth, and the skill/ability progression is a blast. Heck, Team Ladybug even added diagonal attacks and thrusts above and below Deedlit respectively, a nice callback to Super Castlevania IV. 

Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth continues to display the charm of the Mogura 2 engine with smooth pixel based  sprites and animations. 

The swapping between the spirits is a neat concept too as it adds fun platforming challenges to the game as well. This works in tandem with the bow causing the player to interact with their environment instead of Crissaegrim-ing their way through every like in Symphony of the Night. 

The game isn't too hard if you've played a Metroidvania before, I beat it without the use of any potions/consumables from the shop in game. 

The newest release has a couple bugs. I'll be going into spoiler territory to skip to the last paragraph if you (the reader) would not like to be spoiled.

In the 4th stage's boss room you can clip out of bounds, and during the memory world flashback in Deed's house reloading the game gives the player their currently equipped weapon, although it still does 5 damage. 

Semi-spoiler, getting high jump allows you to skip some of the sniping sections with the gears as you can hop over them.

The last complaint I really have is the xp grinding. This was nerfed from the previous release and getting to level 99 takes considerably longer, so for any completionists out there you'll be here a while.

Overall Team Ladybug created another fantastic game with engaging gameplay, an atmosphere + soundtrack that draws the player in, and one to remember for the ages. 8/10. This game is well worth the price tag and if you enjoy it, check out Touhou Luna Nights as well.

Great title that any Metroidvania aficionado should not skip. The price is absolutely fair, not the longest game but that reflects the game's length and quite personally I like that it's on the "short" side, the game would hardly ever get to a point where it feels tedious or unpleasantly redundant. (Don't mind my hours played, that's me leaving the game opened)

Think Ikaruga for a Metroidvania, clever concept. One could argue that the game is too easy and I can understand why, in late game once you will most likely master the in-game mechanics, you can become sort of an indestructible bad ass but if not for that, the game definitely has it's moments and the boss fights are different enough that you will not feel like you are fighting the same boss over and over.

89318856.review:
Superficially this looks like a Metroidvania game but its mostly a facade. The game is incredibly linear with only a scant few side passages that gives upgrades or weapons.
Speaking of those weapons and upgrades they are underwhelming to say the least, Weapons feels stale and uninteresting with nothing really unique about any of them. And the upgrades are all purely stat boost to either of your two elements or to max hp/mp. There are no accessories or armor to be found at all nor are there any side quests, There are no pets to gain nor are there any skills to gain or upgrade, while you do have a spell slot it feels tact on.
For a game that wants to be a Metroidvania game it does shockingly few things to qualify. Giving you only 2 item slots to fill, a weapon and a bow. 

The story is also complete nonsense, unless you are already familiar with the setting and all the characters you will be hopelessly lost as they spout philosophical dribble at each other. Its bafflingly poorly made for anyone not already invested in the world. You are introduced to 15ish characters and you will learn nothing about any of them. Not even the main character is well fleshed out or even compelling, often shifting from one emotion to another seemingly at random.

The UI is a mess, being over designed to look fancy instead of practical. Its far to large while not conveying the information you actually need. With half of it going unused outside of boss fights, cluttering the screen needlessly. The inventory screen/map screen is also a mess, not keeping track of important information such as which colored doors you have unlocked. It shows your attack and defense but not how you can improve them. You have levels but what levels does is not clear.

But my biggest complaint by far are the bosses. While stunningly well animated and drawn they are terrible to fight against. They all lack any form of telegraphing, attacks often killing you outright because random debris hits you or an attack can be used in multiple ways giving you limited options to react, further compounded by the lack of telegraphing.

Verdict: 3/10
If you like the interesting upgrades and item scavenging of Symphony of the Night then this isn't it.
This game really should just have been an action platformer instead, and dropped all pretenses of being a Metroidvania game as it doesn't commit to it and instead feels shallow and bland.

89293817.review:
Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth takes inspiration from several games, as can be seen from the sprite work and mechanics. At its core it is what is considered a "metroidvania", and at that formula it succeeds. Exploring available areas (clearing the map) until you find appropriate skills to allow you to continue exploring gated areas is the basic metroidvania mechanic, and this game succeeds at that. Unfortunately, the game utilizes a mechanic from one particular game, Outland, that simply isn't quite functional and is rather annoying - elemental / color matching mechanics.
Early on Deedlit gains access to Sylph (wind, blue) and Salamander (fire, red). A variety of barriers and enemy projectiles (generally bullet hell projectiles) match the colors to a given element. Switching to the element before being struck by a matching color projectile allows you to ignore the damage completely. Unfortunately, this doesn't work out well, because it requires you to simply mash the element switch button constantly in order to damage enemies that guard against your matching element attacks, but can still hurt you if they touch you, despite you matching their element. It's nonsensical. Essentially, they block your attack if you match their element, but they can still hurt you if they touch you. Sorry, you're breaking your own elemental matching rules.
Bosses require you to memorize patterns that swap between the elements. There are unblockable attacks mixed in the attack routines that simply require you to avoid them. Again however most bosses utilize bullet hell projectiles that overlap and require you to constantly switch between the elements. Yawn.
In addition, there are puzzles that require you to calculate geometric angles for shooting arrows against reflective surfaces to cut a rope and open a door, typically granting access to an item. These considerably slow down the pace and grind the game to a halt. Even Bloodstained, that poor SotN copy, showed the full reflective angles for mirrors and the appropriate skill. Deedlit does not, requiring you to spend time figuring your angles. Sorry guys, this grinds the game to a halt and is rather annoying, as the majority of arrow puzzles are solved by floating to a particular height with Sylph and sending an arrow past the initial reflective surfaces. Couple that with clunky bow controls and you'll likely be annoyed rather quickly.
Progression is silly - in 2.3 hours I was dealing 6 points of damage per strike to over 140 with the correct weapon and increased elemental damage, and still requiring 2-3 strikes per enemy to kill them. This is indicative of a short, poorly paced game with no real sense of progression. Within the short time I played I acquired several typical metroidvania progression-unlocking items (floating, sliding, double jumping, ranged attacks). Because of the rapid acquisition I didn't feel like I'd achieved any sort of actual progress. The bosses faced in the interim were rather boring - a dark elf who tosses daggers while ninja jumping around and casting either wind or fire spells, a water serpent that had an easily memorable pattern, and a pair of elementals (wind and fire). The elementals fight, I might add, didn't remove a given elemental once you dealt enough damage to kill it - the 'dead' elemental stuck around and spammed its elemental bullets and attacks but simply couldn't be hurt. It stuck around until the other elemental was killed. I get you want the game to be a challenge, but that's fucking cheap.
Overall, the animation is great (and highly reminiscent of SotN - just look at Deedlit's run and cape animations) and the controls are decent and responsive - as long as you're not using a shitty Xbox 360 / One controller. I switched from a 360 controller to a buffalo SNES pad and was happier with the controls and response time.
Sorry guys, bullet hell mechanics are lazy and boring outside of the appropriate genre. Outland was terrible, and porting these mechanics into Deedlit don't do it any favors.
Not worth $20. Get it at least 50% off.

89291960.review:
Good, but very, very short.

The game plays between a polished up [i]Symphony of the Night[/i] with some stripped elements, a little bit of [i]Ikaruga[/i] and a pinch of modern game design.

The game explores story elements of [i]Record of Lodoss War[/i] something I've never read/seen, but what was here was serviceable as-is. Deedlit, a high elf, awakens in a familiar but strange location. With the game's length, any additional exposition borders on spoiling the game.

The RPG elements, leveling and equipment, are very stripped down to focus on the gameplay, which is very good and rewards skilled gameplay, but can be a little easy. The combat-centric metroidvania game focuses on melee, archery, spells and some movement abilities while occasionally throwing in a few archery puzzles and locked doors. There's not many items or equipment as similar titles, but there's enough variety and versatility in the Deedlit's repertoire that it never really feels like armor and other equipment items are "missing" from the game.

In addition to playing great, it just looks real nice and sounds good, to boot. Boss fights are really interesting, though as previously stated the game's not particularly difficult to a "skilled" player, which is just as easily a "pro" as it is a "con" for some people.

I enjoyed it, but the game's over in about 5 hours or less (~100%, by the way, without a guide). Entertaining, for sure, but there's minimal replayability for a metroidvania, which was a little surprising. If you're new to metroidvanias, though, this is probably a good place to start as a low-stress "trial" into the genre.

Okay so admittedly this is more of a 'First Impressions' sort of thing since I'm only partway through Level 2... but especially for the price point, I have to say: I went in expecting a SotN clone with a Lodoss War paint job slapped on top of it (and being perfectly fine with that), but I'm... almost shocked by how much fun this game actually is. 89289839.review:
Record of Lodoss War: Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth is one of the best surprises I have had in years. A small team of developers ended up creating one of the best "metroidvanias" to come out in recent years that I know of. 

Level design is fantastic, with each area feeling very different from one another and being very intuitive in how you have to navigate them. There is one area in particular that might feel a bit rushed, but even then it's not badly designed. 

Gameplay-wise, the game feels like a mix between Symphony of the Night and Ikaruga, with its own elements thrown in. Combat is fluid, you have access to magic, items, a dedicated button for a bow and weapons of different kinds such as axes, swords, daggers, spears and boomerangs. The elemental spirit mechanic is interesting, with certain attacks and obstacles being completely ineffective against Deedlit depending on which elemental spirit she's equipped with at the time (and you can switch between them with the press of one button) and healing her when they're at max level. 

The music is really good, although the music for a certain area sounds a bit distorted. The sound effects are nice and fit the game, and the ones that are indicatory of certain gameplay elements being used are not annoying at all, feeling subtle most of the time. 

Graphically speaking, the game is very stylish, with some of the best pixel art I have seen in years. The animations are well detailed (Deedlit's running animation is reminiscent of Alucard's in Symphony of the Night, for example) and fluid, which helps the gameplay feel as good as it does.

As for the downsides. Having been released in batches due to early access, some areas are not as well designed as the others. As I said earlier, the music sounds a bit distorted in one or two areas. The game might be a bit too linear and/or short for some.

In conclusion: Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth is a great experience. Would recommend to everyone that's a fan of Team Ladybug's previous works, fans of "Metroidvanias" or people who tend to like stuff published by Playism.

89288496.review: Let me recommend this with some caveats. If you're wondering whether to play this or Touhou Luna Nights, play that one if you haven't already or don't want to play both, but if you played that one all the way through and liked it at all, definitely at least try this game. The control scheme is the same, attack rather than jump is mapped to the confirm button, so it takes some getting used to and delivers a kind of "floaty" feel. The design choices I've run into so far are mostly quite good with a major exception. One hit from anything automatically takes you down an entire level, even if you're killing the local bosses well before they can finish a single loop of their attack pattern. That's the worst design choice in the game, but it still doesn't give me a lot of confidence that Team Ladybug's next project will top this one either, nor that Gensokyo Night Festival will top Touhou Luna Nights when it's finally done.

89287775.review:
I've had this game for several months now in Early Access, but I'm just writing this review now as the full game has been released and I have beaten it.

So one of the first I'll note is that a lot of the appeal comes from nostalgia, partly by being a metroidvania game in the style of Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, and partly by being based on the classic anime series Record of Lodoss War. To be honest I probably wouldn't have bought it if I wasn't already a Lodoss fan. That's not to say that the game doesn't stand on its own, but you might enjoy it more if you are familiar with the source material.

As for the game itself it has a nice mixture of combat and puzzle solving. While combat against most enemies is pretty straight forward, sometimes it helps to take a specific approach to some foes. The various weapons give combat some variety, as different weapons will have different speeds, reaches, and damage values, making it useful to put some thought into which weapon you should use in a given area. Also the spirit system adds another level to combat and it is really necessary to master as the game progresses, at feat that fortunately isn't that hard. Paying attention to the elemental weaknesses of certain foes is also a must for the skilled player.

Beyond the gameplay I have no complaints. The graphics are gorgeous and the music is haunting. The story, such as it is, fits into the Lodoss canon in way that makes sense as well as having some emotional impact (although as I said before, this may only apply if you are familiar with the Lodoss stories).

If I had one complaint about this game it is, as others have said, rather short. I was able to beat it in about 17.5 hours, and part of that was due to having to fight several bosses two or three times in order to beat, as well as spending some time grinding. A skilled player might be able to beat it in half that time. That said I do feel it is worth the default $20 price and is a good game to play over a weekend.

I personally would say this game is worth giving 10/10 and I highly recommend it.

89286986.review:
As a Metroidvania fanatic, having played Castlevania: Symphony of the Night for countless hours, and previously played Team Ladybug's Touhou Luna Nights - I confidently say that this is a very solid game overall.

The gameplay sets a nice example of having simplistic controls in similar fashion to previous Castlevania games mixed with a polarity system that offers the player a nice amount of depth that they can dive into that can reward the player if played correctly. The player is also introduced with a decent amount of movement options to mess around with as they explore each area.

The spritework is incredible, and the music is pretty neat.

I only recently found out that this game is based on a manga/anime from the late 80s/early 90s to which I have not read or seen, therefore, I have no points to make note of for the story and dialogue.

The only points of criticism that I have for the game are:
- The game is rather short. Each area is quite condensed within the map, making this game a short, but sweet experience.
- Spells can make boss fights trivial. I personally found most of the boss fights rather easy by spamming low-mana cost Spells such as Will-O-Wisp.

If this game is set to get future updates, I would like to see the addition of a Hard Mode and New Game + Mode.

If you're looking for an amazing Metroidvania experience, you've found it here.  The stage designs and artwork are fantastic, the soundtrack is AMAZING, and the story is great given how short the game is.  I got 100% map completion, and hit level 99 at about 9 hours playtime, to help give a time-scale.

The actual gameplay is extremely polished, and the nod to Castlevania: Symphony of the Night is as clear as day (Deedlit's attack patterns, backwards slide, after-image, and even appearance are callbacks to Alucard).  However, everything is cranked up a notch. You can attack in seven directions (eight if in the air), have spells that you can slot and cast at will, a wide range of weapons to choose from, and a bow separate of those weapons.  Aerial movement feels extremely fluid, and the game promotes quick thinking when switching between Deedlit's spirits.

Again, I cannot recommend this enough to anyone that is looking for a good Metroidvania to play.

89272025.review:
Record of Lodoss War-Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth- could be best described as Symphony of the Night inspired take on the genre but on a considerably much smaller scale. While technically a Metroidvania, stage/map design is very light on exploration and there are only a handful of optional rooms to backtrack to and in general it feels like the game is more focused on the combat.

Implementation of combat is solid, controls feel precise and there are a good amount of weapons, spells, enemies and bosses. Gameplay wise most of the environments are somewhat bland, but they feature nice pixel art and in terms of visuals in particular character and enemy art are often gorgeous. Sadly the sound design and music are completely forgettable, which is a shame as they could have added much more to the experience.

In addition to that there are two aspects where the game takes a blunder and those are balancing and the narrative. 

Rather than having a well designed difficulty curve, the game starts off trivially easy and allows the players to cruise through multiple stages without requiring you to even take any advantage of items or spells. While the last two stages (or their bosses rather) ramp up the difficulty considerably - it feels like the whole experience doesn't really know which audience it wants to target.

Ultimately this might lead to a situation where many of the core fans of the genre will likely find the entire experience rather easy and be frustrated at a lack of hard mode of some form, while those who aren't experienced in these type of games may find the difficulty spike to be frustrating.

When it comes to narrative, not only it is bare-bones at best but it also assumes that you are familiar with the world and characters of Record of Lodoss War. While those familiar with the setting have the benefit of knowing who the characters are and are able to fill in some aspects of the story same can't be said for those without the existing context - most of the narrative will be meaningless chatter where seemingly important names and characters are dropped left and right yet the game never establishes why you should care about any of this.

That being said, it took me roughly 5 hours to beat the game and explore the map. Despite its downsides and even taking in account the fact that the game doesn't really have any replay value - I would recommend it to fans of the genre.

89261802.review:
I recommend it, but not at its current price of 20 dollars.

As far as graphics and sound, the game is top notch. other than so many enemies just exploding when they die, I don't have many complaints.

As far as gameplay, I have multiple issues but overall am positive about the experience. The game tries its best to emulate Symphony of the Night, and while it can't quite reach it, there's a lot of effort put into making it a wonderful attempt that is usually quite fun to play, but it is soured somewhat by two things.

First, the game at one point gives you a slide ability, which you can use with one of the elements to give you invincibility frames. it's even part of the little tutorial pop-up that shows up. so you'd probably expect to be able to use it during fights.

Unfortunately, due to the game deciding you aren't allowed to duck during the attack animation, (walking and jumping is fine, you aren't locked in place) you can't really easily use it in a fight. I feel like that really makes fights a lot less fun for me when I'm actually trying to use it. A lot of the time, you'll hold down and press jump after attacking only to jump into an attack you wanted to slide under!

Generally, if you put a slide in your game I'm going to try to play it like Megaman and dodge under attacks. this game doesn't allow me to do that, and that feels bad.

My second issue is actually something a whole lot of games do, and while it works fine in a lot of games, and it's making enemies have their own hitbox that hurts you when you walk into them. I feel like you might have a funny look on your face when you read this, because this is something lots and lots of platformers do. Well, the thing is a whole lot of games do this, and they work fine in those games, but when a lot of what you're trying to do is dodge big bright projectile attacks that you will walk into the dark enemy sprites. I was okay with this in luna nights because most bosses fly, so you can't walk into them, but there was at least one boss who I walked into repeatedly because i was focusing on the big orange and blue bullets.

As far as the story, I'm not someone who has watched or read anything about record of lodoss war, and I can tell you right now the story is doing nothing for me whatsoever. The game keeps introducing bosses and npcs i'm supposed to know, they say something baffling or talk down to the character i'm playing as, and then either leave, stay, or fight me. 

Let me give you an example. A big dragon or sorcerer or something shows up. The main character shouts what is presumably their name. They tell the main character that they're wrong about something without specifying what it really is, telling them they're foolish without elaborating enough to give me any details, and not elaborating on what they think I should do instead. Then, after they're done pretending to be my boomer grandma, they fight, they die, and either say something as they escape, or explode. There's no other outcome.

One boss even had the audacity to ask me if i even knew "what was at the end of the path I was walking" and I was so disappointed when my character didn't say something like "No, of course not, I don't know anything about where I am or what I am supposed to be doing because nobody will tell me.	"

Maybe if someone is a big fan of ROLW they'll love this, but as someone who basically only knows what the game told me, I know nothing about these characters, care nothing for these characters, and only care that people are constantly talking down to the main character because I'm playing as them.

Overall, this is a good game, but I would recommend Luna Nights instead, which is another game by the same developer. It's not too much more amazing, but I had no problems understanding the story despite knowing little about the characters, and you have a good ranged attack making dodging projectiles the focus instead of dodging projectiles and also enemy sprites.

I like that the combat seems fair, especially in boss fights. If I win I feel it's because I understood what the game wanted me to do. If I failed it's because I need to pay more attention and use the tools I have correctly.

This game has been on my radar for about a year, I've held back on playing it until the full release. I didn't want my opinion of the game to be framed by how it played in Early Access. 89225074.review:
I enjoyed all of Team Ladybug's other works and this is their best yet, IMO.  Jump-canceled greatsword spam hasn't felt this good since Castlevania: Aria of Sorrow.   The polarity mechanic makes for some good psychology in boss fights, where you can  stay in the enemy's face at risk of getting clocked by the wrong element, or hang back and take everything as it comes.   

Warp points are smartly placed from start to finish. Every time it felt like I was due for some backtracking, a warp point wasn't far away and I came out pretty close to where I needed to be.  

My main gripe is that some of the bosses are too easily face-tanked.  If you mash attack hard enough, you can refill your level 3 meter and keep regenerating HP faster than the enemy can hit you.  The end boss of stage 5 was leagues better than the actual final boss, since it was more aggressive and not as obviously absorb-cheesed.

89222440.review:
A short but sweet game. Much like the last game Team Ladybug developed, Luna Nights, the game is developed with several "gimmicks" in mind. The first, and more important, being the elemental system with Deedlit able to change her alignment, and thus resistances as well as damage type, on the fly. Other elements can be accessed via magic or certain weapons that have specific built in elemental alignments that Deedlit cannot override. There are more differences between the two, such as a hover or a different slide, but both remain useful for a few reasons. The second gimmick is the bow that, as shown in the trailer, can be aimed, and is used for traversal by manipulating certain objects.

The game has most of its fundamentals done well. There are a few cheap enemies, but generally the game plays fair. Deedlit has the ability to attack at odd angles, and has a pretty fast attack even with the slowest speed weapons. You have multiple upgrades, spells and there are some decently unique weapons to interest you, more so on the bow side such as homing arrows, multi shot and the like. While the early game is pretty easy, later bosses can provide a decent challenge. While not a fundamental, it does bear mentioning that the animation on everything is very good.

Unfortunately, while the enemies play fair, they gave a bit too much to Deedlit so it is far too easy for her to break the game. I did expect this, it is a Team Ladybug game, but it bears mentioning. The elemental system means that if you have the right magic or weapon for the job, you can absolutely devastate even the last boss. The two elements that Deedlit has access to are not exactly equal in terms of useful abilities. The wind hover is incredibly useful for traversal and combat both; while the fire ground slide is entirely combat related and it isn't as flexible. There are very few traversal abilities, and only the hover really stands out. There is not that much backtracking for a metroidvania. The bosses are somewhat disappointing; taken on their own they are each fine. The problem lies with the fact that many share movesets and some are repeated a bit too much and in a short time frame. The only show stopper boss would be the last boss. The game is also very short.

TL;DR: Pretty good fundamentals, and takes advantage of what it does differently. However, can be way too easy depending on how much you utilize what the game gives you and the bosses aren't as impressive as previous Team Ladybug games.

89216857.review:
The Short Version: 6.5-7/10.  
    + Fun concepts, pretty decent storytelling, cool atmosphere.
    - Way too short. Not enough secrets, exploration, or backtracking. Feels quite linear.

The Long Version:
    The comparisons to Symphony are valid. Deed's sprite seems to almost be a 1 for 1 rip from Alucard's (just with some obvious enough differences to differentiate the two) and a few of the melee weapon animations (the 2h swords in particular) are nearly identical to Soma's. There's enough gothic architecture here to give a 90's rave some envy. Magic, weapons, powerups... The whole shebang.

That being said...

    Wonder Labyrinth really shines when its focusing on its core mechanic: Wind and Fire spirit swapping. A lot of the challenges made the game feel like a metroidvania implementation of Ikaruga's light/dark system. This is a huge compliment, I think. It's hard to give the concept enough praise.  It's fun, it adds a nice dynamic element to combat, and it makes you think a bit more than usual.

    Unfortunately by the end of the game there are some pretty big problems. It becomes clear about halfway through that many of the enemies start to repeat themselves (at least, their fighting patterns and "roles") and the Fire/Wind system hits a ceiling near the end once you get into the swing of how to use it. The elemental weakness system can also be a bit confusing if you're not paying attention to it, or if you're missing an elemental spell. Even worse is the layout. Sometimes it gets *really* repetitious. Lots of zig zags to make the most of the game map which get a bit old.

    The time I did spend exploring and fighting was great though. It was a lot of fun backtracking to other spots and wondering what was next.  Too often I found myself going the "right" way though. The game's linearity really becomes a weakness about halfway through. There's almost a false sense of hope when see an obstacle and think "Oh I need a powerup for that!" Then the boss drops that powerup and you find a weapon in what turns out to be a small side room. Bit of a let down.

    In sum, while the game is short it has some bright moments and some great conceptual leverage going for it. The linearity hurts... *a lot*... but it seems more like a one-time affair anyways. Enjoy playing it and relish in what it offers! Just don't expect more.

Record of Lodoss War etc is a really good Metroidvania. Has a decent amount of exploration. Solid enemy and boss design. Good pixel art across the board. I'd say it's a very good game, a Metroidvania that leans more into the Castlevania side of the genre than the Metroid. 89194636.review:
Let me keep it short:

For old Lodoss fans who know the classic anime series about Parn, Deedlit and their party it's going to be a trip down Memory Lane - but a very well made one! Lots of references to old events etc, there are even some hints at the Manga series Chronicles of Flaim...

The story is simple, but very well made, but it takes a long time in order to make sense. Unexpectedly touching and emotional storytelling.

Now about the gameplay aspects:
It's a classic Metroidvania, it's NOT a "copy" of Castlevania Symphony of the Night, although naturally it has many similiarities due to being a game of the same genre:

- Rather big map
- Many weapons (that can be categorized in big 180° weapons, classic mid range swords/spears, and short ranged weapons), they feel mostly the same
- Very intuitive and unique magic battle system:
Deedlit switches between fire and wind magic, making her immune against attacks of the same element. This "element switching" is used for platforming parts, but naturally also fights and naturally boss fights.
- beautiful sprite graphics and animations
- Very "Lodoss-ish" soundtrack. There are no "headbangers" like in Symphony of the Night, but the music fits the game very well!
- About 5-6 hours of playtime if you really want to find most goodies.


Overall I would wholeheartedly recommend to Lodoss fans, Metroidvania fans should definitely give it a try too!
I really wouldn't mind playing more well made Metroidvania (and especially Lodoss) games of this quality level. :D

89194284.review: Short and sweet Metroidvania with some excellent boss fights and a fun Ikaruga-esque element swapping system. Plays and animates very smoothly, a step up even on Touhou Luna Nights, Team Ladybug's previous title. It's a little more "vanilla" than that game, trading the time stop and bullet hell mechanics for more standard inventory and sub weapon systems but if you were looking for a more traditional successor to Symphony of the Night this is it. It's also got a nice, heartwarming story that, while not requiring any previous knowledge of Record of The Lodoss War series to enjoy, serves as a nice cap on the end of Deedlit and Parn's story. Highly recommended!

89192342.review:

Apesar que, pelo preço, mesmo sem a lore valeria a pena, só talvez fique um pouco confuso, pois o material base para o enredo pressupõe que o leitor (ou jogador) já conheça as personagens.

89189820.review:
Team Ladybug/Why So Serious once again smashes it out of the park within the Indie Metroidvania community, the game shines instantaneously from the gorgeous art, relaxing and downright addicting music and the slick/smooth feeling movement. Everything feels just right, the games main mechanics of the spirits is pretty differential from other metroidvanias and add a unique charm to the game, whilst feeling fully fleshed out, adding tension to platforming and combat-alike, being able to slide, double or triple jump into a barrage of fireballs to quickly switch to the Fire spirit to make yourself immune feels great.

Having played the game throughout its early access period, each stage and update felt incredibly good, I was always left wanting more after finishing the additional stage/s (the last two updates added two stages respectively.) even within the longer gaps between some of the updates, I never felt dissatisfied with the Team Ladybug's progress, as each release added worthwhile weaponry (Melee and Bows.) and magic, the last 3 stages adding some of the most enjoyable spells in the game. Now that the game's finally hit 1.0 I can wholeheartedly recommend the game for anyone wanting to try out the Metroidvania genre, or play an entirely new one, the game's absolutely worth the price, and I'm excited to see what the team does next.

89186851.review:
So I am going to recommend this game but it has a few caveats which I will try to word in this review.  
  
First the good things.
- Great music(apart from 1 or 2 tracks that are a bit meh but still not horrible)
- Amazing pixel art
- The combat feels smooth and clean, very responsive, Deedlit always did exactly what I wanted her to do when I wanted her to.
- The last boss(of the full game) was quite fun, I enjoyed the fact I had to actually play well t and the elemental switching I had to do to beat it. This was the first time in the game I used a single potion to save my life cause I was so close to beating it and I didn't want to start over.

That's about where the good points end.

The bad points:
- It's insanely short, my playtime of ~5 hours includes roughly 30-45 minutes of afk time where I forgot to turn off the game and I beat the full game in that time. I didn't go back after beating the game to find all the hidden rooms and the likes.

- It's so easy you could probably beat this game with your eyes closed. None of the bosses really offer a challenge, spamming attack and occasionally dodging out of the way of an attack will win you a fight in no time. If you want to win faster you spam magic and just melt a boss.

- The vast array of weapons you have are all incredibly bland, they have some fun flavor texts that make you think "whoa this weapon sounds awesome! I wonder what it does!" only to find out it's just another weapon you have probably already swung before with a different look and increased stats this time. 

- The powers you get are incredibly underused, I never felt like I needed specific power to beat a boss. The first boss in the game sets the stage a bit where you have to float with wind and dodge an attack which was quite fun. That's the last time you have to use that in a boss fight. Although there is 1 exception to this rule, see good points^.

- The visual clarity in boss fights is [b]HORRIBLE[/b] with all the screen shake and effects going around and the fact you fight a lot of humanoid bosses so if you are hitting the boss with melee you get this effect over the boss so you can't see what the boss is doing.....at all.

Now this next one is a personal issue of mine that not everyone might have.
There is a few boss fights where the background changes to this green "tube" that you are moving through and that effect is absolute garbage. It triggered my motion sickness like no tomorrow and it was just the worst effect ever for an action game boss fight.

Now you might be wondering why I would still recommend this game? Despite so many negative points vs only a few good points. I still had fun playing the game and I bought it for 8 euro's(which was still too much for the playtime I got out of it but not for the fun I got out of it).
I cannot recommend this game for full price ever, wait for a sale to around 5-8 and it's good enough to blow an evening or 2 on. 

If you want a better game by this dev team buy their Touhou game, Touhou Luna Nights, it's cheaper, longer and has far more fun and engaging boss fights(I played this on game pass that's why it's not in my steam library)

88792234.review:
[b]Overall feelings / TL;DR:[/b] 
A fun 'metroidvania' with it's own unique imprint on the style of gameplay that made it easy to seek coming back to between other games I'm playing. The combat and movement is really fluid and fun, along with the elements system incorporating a better layered gameplay experience. This was certainly a game worth purchasing if you enjoy the genre. It's easily becoming one of my favorite games in the genre; It's fun, it's challenging, and combat and traversing the map feel satisfying

[b]The good:[/b]
I thought the overall controllability of the character felt great. An early tell for a game is about how good it feels to move around and it felt fluid when moving throughout the levels.

The music and sound engineering was satisfying and suited the game well. I have no complaints about it and enjoyed the music for each area.

[u]Combat[/u]
 The combat and movement had me onboard. The variance in weapon strikes in combination with the wind form's glide allowed for good choices of attack angles and allowed for some variance in style for approaching enemy encounters overall. In addition to this, the magic system creates more variance in combat style for the player, which is always a good thing. After much exploration, you can discover powerups for your fire/wind forms as well as unlocking new elemental spells, which enriches the flavor of the enemy weakness strategy during combat

Additionally, the boss fights and combat in general felt satisfying and boss fights felt genuinely difficult in moments with so much stuff happening on the screen.

Elemental swapping: 
I felt this was a great mechanic for this game. implementing swapping to drain enemy moves or avoid resists enabled me to have to think on a lot on the fly.

88561738.review:
Out of 10 points, I'd give this a 7. This is an excellent try at mimicking the magic of an older Castlevania, but it's not quite there. It looks and feels the same, but after completing level 4 thus finishing the pre-release version, it's just not as fun. The maps look too similar. The enemies are not as interesting and lack variety. There's a lot less weapons, magic, and items, with almost no hidden items inside walls (no turkey legs hidden in a wall). And the lore, eh, it's okay. It's about elves. It's not gothic, or dark, or scary. Still it's not bad, it's just not as good as its obvious target. 

On a positive note though, it does bring something NEW to the table. The game has a very unique and fun, fire or water/air element system, where you can switch between the two giving you different actions and interactions. With fire selected, you attacks are ignited, and you can pass through walls of fire or fire attacks. Water/air is the same except it also allows you to hover. They both also have gauges that fill-up the more  you don't get hit, and once at level 3, will restore health. This all makes for a system where you are constantly switching to match you situation, and it plays out very well. 

And while that element system is a great idea and implemented perfectly, the lack of variety in enemies, stuff you use, and levels brings it down.

88544769.review: very fun game, I love this IP but the game is quite good too.  the spirit mechanic reminds me a little of Ikaruga and the arrow puzzles are kind of neat.   It feels a little small right now, I played three hours and have progressed as far as possible on the map.

88458753.review:
A bit short but definitely a good game with a lot of potential and appealed to my sense of fantasy. I liked the atmosphere and IP. 

I absolutely loved the archery challenge. Probably the best part of the game and certainly the hardest. It took me a while to get S rank (an hour? maybe 30 minutes) but it was a really fun and interesting challenge. It seemed impossible at first but it's not, you just have to get good at it and you can in a reasonable amount of time. 10/10 minigame imo. 

It's also really cool that you get the best bow in the game from it. 

I wish there were more things like that.

[h1]Problems:[/h1]

There is no real replayability. It's very much a play through once and done type of experience. I think the game would have been better off with a more hardcore element of gameplay where you have to start again (without saves maybe? but that would be brutal) but with more variability such as skill builds or RNG items and RNG maps to create a replayable experience. 

It'd be fine if the story length was at least 10-20 hours but I finished it in 4 hours played. It's really too short. They're adding two stages this month and I will play them but even then, that'll be an extra hour or two max I imagine. 

 I would LOVE a reason to play the game again. There just isn't one. 

It's also a bit too easy. They've definitely made an effort to make the game hard. You have to give them credit for that and I do. Especially the boss fights. They're fun to play for sure but since the attacks are all patterns, you can learn them (some are harder than others) and then once you've beaten the boss you never play it again and it's just kinda forgotten. Again, going back to the lack of replayability issue.

It's not like I never died. I died a fair amount being sloppy and dumb but it's still rather easy for a few reasons.

* It's easy to get 'overgeared' and kill most creatures in a few hits before they get an attack off. I just brute forced most of the game due to the high damage. 

* Mobs take way too long to cast their spells. It'd be a lot better if there was almost no delay and your screen filled with elemental orbs. Some creatures cast spells that you can't avoid with your elements which is why I think they've chosen to not fill the screen. If however, all creatures did either fire or wind damage, then you could have as much action on the screen as you want because switching between elements is very seamless. The mechanic is somewhat wasted for that reason and the overall combat experience was more disappointing than the trailer made it out to be. This and the lack of replayability are my biggest complaints. 

* You can chug potions while stunned. It's expensive but since you don't really care about your money in this game. I only bought the sword at the beginning for 900 (huge upgrade) and another sword for the model to do the firestorm hack.

* Magic is OP. I used the invisibility spell to cheese the last boss fight (currently it's the dark elf) but the damage is also quite high. At least invisibility shouldn't work on boss stages. Your MP runs out quickly but again, you can eat MP restoration items like they're candy. Maybe remove that item, idk. Kind of defeats the purpose of not spamming storm spells.


Lastly, the story was 'okay' but rather generic and mostly just filler. There were lots of "who is this guy?" moments but since there was hardly any dialogue it didn't really matter. 

A large portion of the dialogue was extremely cryptic and condescending messages like "you don't know what you really want" or "you don't know why you're here? do you?" and then they would disappear and you'd be like "huh? ok"

It didn't really bother me while I was playing it (probably because I was reading in Japanese that immediately makes any story a positive experience for me) but thinking back, the story was objectively like a 2 out of 5 or something.

Overall I did like the game despite my critique and I would buy a sequel.

88440311.review:
Recommended but a qualified recommendation. 
DiWL is a very competent platformer, and a very pretty one too which is kind of a trademark of Team Ladybug.

However -- and this is written from playing the early access version -- it's like it's missing something. It feels too easy, there are tons of weapons but there's no reason not to pick the latest one and maybe it's my lack of knowledge of the Record of Lodoss War story but the overall effect is very bland in particular when compared to Touhou Luna NIghts. We meet some characters which I suppose are important to the Record of Lodoss War story but we are  never told who they are beyond their name, why they are there or why we should care.

Positives:
- very competently done and plays solidly
- a few nice tricks and puzzles
- superb sprite work

Negatives:
- Bland, almost nonexistent story
- Large inventory of weapons that are mostly useless
- A single music track (unless I failed to notice them, but coming from Touhou Luna Nights it's a big letdown)
- Protagonist is ridiculously OP and can cheese all bosses, unless you self-impose restrictions

I love what Team Ladybug does but this one seems a bit phoned-in, at least in its current state.
To be revised when the final version is out.

88439929.review:
Update:
Since my original review they added a boss rush, nice! And replaying from the start was enjoyable. I still find it very easy but it's obviously meant to be a Castlevania SOTN clone, which was the same in difficulty. So if you're looking for a short but polished metroidvania, go for it.

Pros
- very nice, gorgeous, polished visuals.
- nice music, and each area has it's own track.
- good boss fights.
- rebindable keys/buttons
- Solid controls.
- Good weight to your character, doesn't feel floaty.

Cons
- What this game needs is balancing. Because the game is so short, you come across new weapons and abilities very quickly. And you just feel overpowered early on. There are lots of save points, so maybe lowering the delay for enemies to start attacking you. Most of the time you can just walk up and mash through them before they get a chance to attack.
- The level design is an actual labyrinth. Reminded me of the original Zelda, you have to constantly look at the map.
- When you boot the game, you're greeted with an unintuitive white option screen.
- Not much story wise. NPC drops some vague line about destiny or love and protagonist is like "Wha?". And that's disappointing, because I thought, if they got a hold of the license, surely there's some meat to it.

Update: I've now completed the full version of the game. My thoughts are much the same as below. In summary, Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth is a great action-platformer/metroidvania and one that doesn't overstay it's welcome at about six hours to finish.

Original early access review: I've played through all four of the Early Access areas and found Record of Lodoss War: Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth to be a pretty enjoyable "Metroidvania", though I hesitate to call it that -- the game is split up into several areas with relatively little backtracking between them, and Deedlit doesn't get significant additional traversal abilities after the first section.

Compared to the team's previous game, Touhou Luna Nights, RoLW: DiWL is more polished but easier. I find the new polarity (fire/wind) system less exciting than the graze/time-stop mechanic of Luna Nights, but there might be more to it in the full game. (I'll note that I'm only slightly familiar with the anime series, but I imagine fans of it would get a kick out of seeing these characters again.)

The full game, dated March 27, 2021, adds two additional areas. If they're about as lengthy as the existing areas, I'd imagine the whole game would take most players around 6 hours to play though.
